It was at her Rinconada estate near [[Granja de Torrehermosa]]<ref>for its recent fate see ''El Confidencial Digital'' 02.11.05, available [http://www.elconfidencialdigital.com/dinero/Hitos-carismatica-Badajoz-Extremadura-escrituras_0_402559742.html here], also ''CEE Finca el Río, SA'' [in:] ''Servicio de Información sobre Discapacidad'' service, available [http://sid.usal.es/centrosyservicios/discapacidad/2378/2-1-2-2/cee-finca-el-rio-sa.aspx here]</ref> where Francisco and his only brother<ref>the couple had 2 children, both boys, ''ABC'' 21.12.56, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1956/12/21/071.html here]</ref> spent most of their childhood, raised in the profoundly Catholic ambience. Though born in [[Madrid]], he considered Extremadura his mother region.<ref>"nacido en Madrid, pero de patria extremeña" – quoted after ''Fundación Elías de Tejada'' service, available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/ here]. See also Miguel Ayuso Torres, ''Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola, 30 años después'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'' XIV (2008), p. 15. Some scholars claim that in a metaphorical way, he was also (and felt himself so) "napolitano, sardo y contés, catalán y aragonés, vasco y portugués, andalúz y gallego", Estanislao Cantero, ''Francisco Elías de Tejada y la tradición española'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'' I (1995), p. 123. He even distinguished a specific Andalusian identity and admitted it, Lorca Navarrete, José F. Lora Navarrete, ''La tradición andaluza sagún Elías de Tejada'', [in:] Angel Sanchez de la Torre (ed.), ''Francisco Elías de Tejada. Figura y pensamiento'', Madrid 1995 {{ISBN|8486926890}}, pp. 103-108, María del Carmen Fernandez de la Cigoña, ''Varios autores. Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spinola: Figura y pensamiento'' [review], [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'' 2 (1996), p. 192. Some scholars refer to his „extremeñismo apasionado”, see Goytisolo 1981, p. 106</ref>
Since early childhood consuming sophisticated books<ref>Goytisolo 1981, p. 106</ref> and gifted with excellent memory,<ref>according to an anecdote, during college meals one student used to read aloud passages from a book, and afterwards Tejada could have repeated them almost literally</ref> the young Francisco was first educated in the [[Jesuit]] college of Nuestra Señora de Recuerdo in the Madrid quarter of [[Chamartín (Madrid)|Chamartin]].<ref>''ABC'' 27.07.77, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/blanco.y.negro/1977/07/27/067.html here]</ref> After its premises were [[:es:Quema de conventos de 1931 en España|ransacked in May 1931]]<ref>José Martín Brocos Fernández, ''Una pequeńa historia del Carlismo del siglo XX a través de tres semblanzas: Tomás Domínguez Arévalo, José María Arauz de Robles y Francisco Elías de Tejada'', [in:] ''Arbil'' 120 (2005), available [http://www.arbil.org/120broc.htm here]</ref> and the order was expulsed soon afterwards, he continued his learning in the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[Estremoz]], still with the Jesuits.<ref>Goytisolo 1981, p. 106, Bartyzel 2015, p. 239</ref> In 1933 Tejada obtained [[bachillerato]], nostrified by [[University of Seville]].<ref>Jesús Vallejo, ''Elías de Tejada y Spínola, Francisco (1917-1978)'' entry, [in:] ''Diccionario de Catedráticos Españoles de Derecho'' service 2015, available [http://portal.uc3m.es/portal/page/portal/instituto_figuerola/programas/phu/diccionariodecatedraticos/lcatedraticos/etejada here]</ref> Inspired by his Jesuit mentor Fernando María de Huidobro<ref>born 1903, he volunteered to Nationalist troops and was killed in action on April 5, 1937 on the Madrid front, Cantero 1995, p. 128, also Goytisolo 1981, p. 106, Bartyzel 2015, p. 238</ref> he decided to study law, though at [[:es:Universidad de Madrid|Universidad Central]] in Madrid he pursued also philosophy and letters. Having graduated in both in 1935<ref>Goytisolo 1981, p. 107, also ''Elías de Tejada Spínola, Francisco'' entry, [in:] Gonzalo Díaz Díaz, ''Hombres y documentos de la filosofía española'', v. 3, Madrid 1998, {{ISBN|9788400067038}}, p. 22</ref> he left to study in [[Nazi Germany|Germany]].<ref>in Berlin and Frankfurt a/M, Vallejo 2015</ref> Outbreak of the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] caught him in [[Berlin]];<ref>Goytisolo 1981, p. 107</ref> Tejada returned to Spain<ref>crossing the Pyrenees from France to Navarre, Vallejo 2015</ref> to learn that tens of his relatives were executed by the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republicans]] in Granja.<ref>according to his own statement, "la horda roja asesinó veintitrés parientes próximos", quoted after Vallejo 2015. For events in Granja de Torrehermosa in September 1936 see Rodrigo González Ortín, ''Extremadura bajo la influencia soviética'', Badajoz 1937, pp. 65-68, available [http://laextremaduraroja.blogspot.com/2010/01/extremadura-bajo-la-influencia_7752.html here], also ''ABC'' 24.09.39, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1939/09/24/026.html here]. The nationalist troops conquered Granja de Torrehermosa in early October 1936, see ''ABC'' (Seville) 06.10.1936, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1936/10/06/005.html here], though the area remained in the immediate rear of the frontline until early 1939, compare e.g. ''ABC'' (Seville) 05.02.38, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1938/02/05/007.html here]. In January 1939 Granja was conquered by the Republican troops during [[:es:Batalla de Valsequillo|their last offensive of the war]]; exact day is not clear, compare ''La Vanguardia'' 10.01.39, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1939/01/10/pagina-1/33119967/pdf.html here], and ''La Vanguardia'' 17.01.39, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1939/01/10/pagina-3/33120017/pdf.html here]. Some time afterwards – probably in February 1939 – Granja was re-taken by the Nationalists</ref> In September in [[Calera de León|Calera de la Sierra]] he enlisted to [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist troops]],<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> first advancing to [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]]<ref>Goytisolo 1981, p. 107</ref> and then as artillery man serving during the [[battle of Madrid]].<ref>and stayed there until December 1936, Vallejo 2015</ref> In February 1937 he was admitted to Alféreces Provisionales school in [[Seville]], soon abandoned due to health reasons.<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> In May 1937 he intended to join aviation, but in August he was nominated alférez asimilado at a logistics unit in Seville,<ref>Alférez asimilado de Ingenieros at Parque de Automovilismo del Ejército Sur</ref> remaining at this post until the end of the war.<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> [[File:Verano 2003 091a.jpg|thumbnail|summer in rural [[Extremadura]]]] Though described as heavily attracted to females,<ref>José Manuel Cuenca Toribio, ''M. Ayuso Torres: La filosofía jurídica y política de Francisco Elias de Tejada, Madrid, Fundación Elias de Tejada, 1994'' [review], [in:] ''Revista de Estudios Políticos (Nueva Época)'' 85 (1994), p. 370</ref> Elías de Tejada married as late as in 1962, at the age of 45.<ref>''ABC'' 01.05.62, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1962/05/01/039.html here]</ref> He wed an [[Italians|Italian]] 20 years his junior, Gabriella Pèrcopo Calet (1937-1986),<ref>Pablo Ramírez Jerez, ''La biblioteca de D. Francisco Elías de Tejada'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'' 19 (2013), p. 205</ref> descendant to a distinguished Neapolitan family of immense intellectual heritage,<ref>her grandfather, Erasmo Pércopo was a distinguished scholar of the University of Naples</ref> fluent in Spanish, perfectly familiar with the Spanish cultural realm and the [[PhD]] herself. Throughout the rest of his life she supported Tejada on all possible fields, as a secretary, [[proofreader]], editor, erudite partner, co-author, organizer, academic inspiration and a soul mate.<ref>Bartyzel 2015, p. 241</ref> The couple had no children.<ref>Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 9, ''ABC'' 27.07.77, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/blanco.y.negro/1977/07/27/067.html here]</ref> [[Francisco Elías de Tejada Lozano]], a Spanish diplomat in the 21st century serving as ambassador and high Foreign Ministry official,<ref>compare ''ABC'' 23.01.11, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2011/01/23/081.html here]</ref> is descendant to Elías’ brother.<ref>''ABC'' 19.04.77, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1977/04/19/059.html here]</ref>
==Academic career== [[File:ClaustrodelaMercedMurcia.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|[[University of Murcia|Murcia]], Law Faculty]] Already in 1935 Tejada was nominated [[Assistant professor|Profesor Ayudant]]e de Derecho Político in Madrid, an assignment held shortly as he soon left for Germany.<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> When in the Nationalist army he was giving lectures at letters and philosophy courses<ref>titled ''El pensamiento jurídico-político español en nuestros clásicos de los siglos XVI y XVII'', Vallejo 2015</ref> organized by Universidad de Sevilla,<ref>''ABC'' (Sevilla) 17.10.37, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1937/10/17/018.html here]</ref> in 1939 publishing his first works.<ref>''ABC'' (Sevilla) 18.01.39, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1939/01/18/020.html here]</ref> Having obtained PhD laurels thanks to a thesis on [[:es:Jerónimo Castillo de Bobadilla|Jerónimo Castillo de Bobadilla]], in 1939 Tejada returned to Madrid as Professor Ayudante<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> to assist [[Nicolás Pérez Serrano]]<ref>Bartyzel 2015, p. 239</ref> at Derecho Político.<ref>Brocos Fernández 2005</ref> In 1940 he applied for chair of philosophy of law in Seville and [[Oviedo]], but during the [[:es:Oposición (examen)|routine contest]] he was defeated by counter-candidates; referees described him as erudite and brilliant speaker, but also disoriented, immature, not adhering to the point, lacking reflexive spirit, excessively lyrical and repetitive.<ref>there were 4 candidates for 2 chairs vacant, see Yolanda Blasco Gil, Jorge Correa Ballester, ''Primeras oposiciones y concursos de Filsofía del Derecho tras la Guerra Civil (1940-1941)'', [in:] ''Facultades y grados. X Congreso Internacional de Historia de las universidades hispánicas'', vol. 1, Valencia 2010. Tejada came with the most imposing publishing record, but referees noted that he „no responde a las cuestiones de la filosofía del derecho”, suffers from "falta de reflexión" and "exceso de transcripción" (264), is too much sociology oriented and not adhering to the point (265), disoriented, with some "inexactitudes" and lyrical divagations (266), and finally, immature (267)</ref> Also in 1940<ref>exact sequence of the events is not clear</ref> Tejada left to pursue research abroad,<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> having the unique opportunity to compare the early wartime realm in Berlin and in [[Oxford]].<ref>Francisco Fernandez Serrano, ''Francisco Elias de Tejada y Spínola, extremeño universal'', [in:] ''Alcantara'' 191 (1978), p. 24</ref>
In March 1941 Tejada won the contest for chair of Derecho Natural y Filosofía del Derecho in [[University of Murcia|Murcia]];<ref>Brocos Fernández 2005</ref> in 1942 he moved to [[University of Salamanca|Salamanca]], having been the only contender.<ref>Brocos Fernández 2005, Vallejo 2015</ref> In 1951 he swapped chairs with [[Joaquín Ruiz-Giménez|Joaquín Ruiz Giménez Cortés]]<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> and left for [[University of Seville|Seville]], where he headed philosophy of law for the next 26 years, periodically chairing also the history of ideas. However, except the 1960-1961 course he spent the 1956-1964 period mostly pursuing research in Naples, with massive admin gimmicks on part of the University to find a legal framework for such a lengthy stay.<ref>the University was initially unwilling to concede such a long leave, Vallejo 2015</ref> Since 1964 he worked under the dedicación exclusiva contract.<ref>according to the Spanish system of the time, it limited Tejada right to teach to one institution, Vallejo 2015</ref> In 1969 nominated consejero honorario del Consejo Nacional de Educación,<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> though his academic relations with the Francoist education authorities remained thorny.<ref>described as "isolated sniper" waging war against the regime, in the 1970s Tejada protested official designs aiming at curtailing academic liberties, Alberto Carrillo-Linares, ''Subversivos y malditos en la Universidad de Sevilla (1965-1977)'', Sevilla 2008, {{ISBN|9788461273522}}, pp. 264, 495, 520. For conflicting views on his stance towards students see Carrillo-Linare 2008, p. 343 (defending students' participation in academic life) and Vallejo 2015 (authoritarian policeman)</ref> [[File:Sevila19.JPG|thumbnail|160px|[[University of Seville|Seville]], Recorate]] Since the early 1970s Tejada intended to move to Madrid, but his 1971<ref>bid for Filosofía del Derecho at [[Universidad Complutense]]; he withdrew, Vallejo 2015</ref> and 1974<ref>for the post of Profesor Agregado de Historia del Pensamiento Político Español de la Facultad de Ciencias Políticas y Sociología de la Universidad Complutense de Madrid; it appears that the contes was an obligatory procedure for certain category of scholars, Vallejo 2015</ref> bids for Complutense failed. His 1975 bid for [[Autonomous University of Madrid|Universidad Autónoma]]<ref>for cátedra de Derecho Natural y Filosofía del Derecho de la Universidad Autónoma de Madrid</ref> took an awkward turn, when Tejada challenged the referees appointed as linguistically incompetent.<ref>according to Tejada, the works he produced as references required knowledge of Akkadian, Agni, Akikuyu, Arab, Ashanti, Baoule, Bete, Czech, Chinese, Croatian, Danish, Finnish, Gouro, modern Greek, Hebrew, Dutch, Icelandic, Japanese, Malay, Norwegian, Polish, Romanian, Russian, Sanskrit, Senoufo, Swedish, Swahili, Basque, Vietnamese and Zulu</ref> His protest was dismissed and in 1976 he lost to [[:es:Elías Díaz|Elías Díaz García]],<ref>allegedly his defeat produced a sigh of relief among the Madrid staff; opinion of his rival Elías Díaz, see Elías Díaz, ''Autobiografia intelectual'', [in:] ''Anthropos. Revista de Documentacion Cientifica de la Cultura'' 62 (1986), pp. 7-9</ref> appealing the decision; the issue was not settled before his death.<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> However, in 1977 he was appointed with no contest to cátedra de Derecho Natural y Filosofía del Derecho at Complutense; death interrupted his first course in Madrid.<ref>Vallejo 2015; according to some scholars he died when delivering a lecture, see Jacek Bartyzel, ''Franciszek Elías de Tejada y Spínola - hidalgo, filozof, karlista'', [in:] ''haggard'' service, available [http://haggard.w.interiowo.pl/tejada.html here]</ref>
Though member of a number of scientific institutions around the world,<ref>e.g. the Brazilian Academy of Social Sciences and the Argentine National University of Buenos Aires</ref> recipient of a few [[doctor honoris causa]] titles,<ref>also outside Europe, Bartyzel 2015, p. 240</ref> a vastly prolific author and during his lifetime himself subject of 4 PhD dissertations,<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> Tejada did not make it to the top elite of Spanish law scholars and did not enter [[Real Academia de Jurisprudencia y Legislación]]. There are conflicting accounts of his standing in the academic realm. Some claim that he was universally highly regarded as doctrinally intransigent but pro-student<ref>he defended students’ participation in academic governance bodies against the official schemes, Carrillo-Linares 2008, p. 343</ref> open-minded, tolerant scholar,<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, ''Franciszek Elías de Tejada y Spínola - hidalgo, filozof, karlista''</ref> as demonstrated by his supervision of PhD bid of [[Enrique Tierno Galván]], the future key [[PSOE]] politician.<ref>also later mayor of Madrid and co-author of the 1978 constitution, César Alonso de los Ríos, ''El viejo profesor'', [in:] ''El Mundo'' 121, available [http://www.elmundo.es/larevista/num121/textos/profe1.htmlothers here]. For a sample of PhD thesis written under Tejada guidandce see Vicente Marrero Suárez, ''La fundamentación filosófica de una filosofía jurídico-social en la obra del P. Ramírez'' [PhD Universidad de Sevilla, 1970], available [http://fondosdigitales.us.es/tesis/tesis/699/la-fundamentacion-filosofica-de-una-filosofia-juridico-social-en-la-obra-del-p-ramirez/ here]</ref> Others present him as a feared „inquisidor”,<ref>Elías Díaz 1986, pp. 7-9</ref> extremely quarrelsome hypocrite pursuing private goals<ref>which consisted mostly of embarking on voyages around the world, posed as scientific research missions, Vallejo 2015</ref> and eager to call security when dealing with manifestations of student dissent towards him.<ref>students voiced their disgust with de Tejada by interrupting his lectures with [[charivari]] demonstrations, Vallejo 2015; the case is dubbed "banal" and his complaints to university authorities are deemed "illustrative of his character and ideas"</ref>
==Theorist of law== [[File:Franciscus Suarez, S.I. (1548-1617).jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Francisco Suarez]]]] Tejada is considered member of the natural law school and its key representative during the Franco era,<ref>Antonio-Enrique Pérez Luño, ''Natural Law Theory in Spain and Portugal'', [in:] ''The Age of Human Rights Journal'' 1 (2013), pp. 7-8</ref> influenced by early modern Spanish jurists like Francisco Suarez<ref>also Francisco de Vitoria and Domingo de Soto, Samuele Cecotti, ''F. Elías de Tejada: Europa, Tradizione, Liberta'' [review], [in:] ''Rassegna Bibliografica Mensile'' 3 (2005), p. 209, also Miguel Ayuso Torres, ''Francisco Elías de Tejada en la ciencia jurídico-política'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'' 3 (1997), p. 21</ref> but mostly following the [[Aquinas]]; he regarded own work merely a gloss to the opus of St. Thomas.<ref>Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 12</ref> Hence, within iusnaturalismo he is classified as representative of [[Neo-Scholasticism|Neo-Scholastic school]], as opposed<ref>he claimed supremacy of "prudencia iuris" over what he considered technical or scientific threads, Ayuso 2008, pp. 15-16</ref> to Axiological, Neo-Kantian and Innovative Natural Law schools.<ref>compare Pérez Luño 2013</ref> Together with [[:fr:Michel Villey|Michel Villey]] deemed a renovator of classical European iusnaturalismo of the mid-20th century,<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 22</ref> Tejada clearly distinguished own vision<ref>see his ''El Derecho Natural, fundamento de la civilización'', [in:] ''Revista chilena de derecho'' 1 (1974), pp. 287-303</ref> from "iusnaturalismo racionalista".<ref>Ayuso 2008, p. 16</ref> Within this framework, he agreed that the role of [[jurisprudence]] was discovering rather than inventing.<ref>Goytisolo 1981, p. 112</ref>
Tejada's work consisted of systematizing concepts falling into [[ontology]], [[anthropology]], [[logic]] and [[axiology]].<ref>Fernandez de la Cigoña 1986, p. 190</ref> His original contribution was merging them into a complete system<ref>falling into 4 sections: saber jurídico común (commonly shared knowledge), saber técnico (juridical formulas), saber científico (systematic, specialized and verifiable knowledge) and saber filosófico (ultimate, permanent, invariable principles), Goytisolo 1981, p. 117</ref> and introducing a set of own concepts. He is considered not a mere follower but a scholar who developed Thomist juridical philosophy, credited for attempting a synthesis with [[Existentialism|existentialist school]];<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 22, also Luis Legaz y Lacambra, ''Die Tendenzen der Rechtsphilosophie in Spanien in den letzten zehn Jahren'', [in:] ''Archiv fur Rechts- und Sozialphilosophie'' 45/4 (1959), p. 573</ref> some even view him as representative of legal [[Existentialist Christianity|Catholic Existentialism]], a definition not accepted universally.<ref>Pérez Luño 2013, pp. 7-8</ref> He is noted as the moving spirit behind emergence of Asociación Internacional de Iusnaturalistas Hispánicos "Felipe II".<ref>Ayuso 2008, p. 20; now the institution is transformed into Consejo de Estudios Hispánicos "Felipe II", see its website available [https://consejofelipesegundo.wordpress.com/ here]</ref> Last but not least, Tejada is acknowledged as the one who inspired a number of scholars, both in Spain and in wider Hispanic realm, though not all his proposals have been accepted by his followers.<ref>for discussion of controversies see Fernandez de la Cigoña 1986, p. 190</ref> [[File:Herrera thomas aquinas.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Thomas Aquinas]] by [[Francisco Herrera the Younger]]]] For Tejada the law resulted from God assuming a decisive role, but rendering it possible to find acceptable reasons for an objective-value-based human agency;<ref>Pérez Luño 2013, p. 8; the author classifies this view as Catholic Existentialism, though Tejada himself did not use the term</ref> natural law stemmed from conjunction of divine power and human liberty.<ref>Goytisolo 1981, p. 113, Auso 2008, p. 16, Ayuso 1997, p. 21</ref> Its purpose was twofold: salvation and vocation,<ref>Estanislao Cantero, ''Sobre una interpretación de la definición del derecho de Elías de Tejada'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Elías de Tejada'' 2 (1996), p. 152</ref> corresponding to justice in relations to God and security in relations to other people.<ref>Cantero 1996, p. 152-3</ref> Though some scholars point to some confusion as to the terms used,<ref>for his ambiguous distinction if not indeed confusion of a law, a right and a norm see Cantero 1996, p. 152</ref> most agree that for Tejada law was "la norma política con contenido justo", colloquially described as where politics and ethics overlapped,<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 21. According to Tejada, a law is political norm with ethical content, a 3-dimensional definition covering formal (norm), factual (politics) and axiologic (ethics) dimensions, Fernandez de la Cigoña 1986, p. 190</ref> a sovereign normative system related but clearly separate from religion.<ref>see opinions of Mariano Hurtado Bautista referred after Fernandez de la Cigoña 1986, pp. 197-205</ref> Some students conclude that Tejada was close to normativism,<ref>Francisco Puy, referred after Ayuso 2008, p. 16, Cantero 1996, p. 145</ref> others<ref>Cantero 1996, p. 145</ref> find this suggestion too restrictive<ref>Cantero 1996, p. 147</ref> and claim that for him, law was far more than a norm.<ref>Cantero 1996, pp. 150-1, 157</ref> A distinctive thread of his jurisprudential discourse was its application to vastly distinct cultural realms,<ref>starting with Spain, but covering also major European entities like Germany and England, smaller countries like Romania, Finland or Norway, Asian civilisations like Japan, Thailand or the Borneo tribes, and even the Soviet Union</ref> though he attempted to sublimate a specific Hispanic natural law.<ref>some scholars flag lingering questions as to how general principles of law should be substituted by hispanic natural law, see Cantero 1996, p. 149</ref>
Tejada kept writing on theory of law throughout all of his academic career; his first contribution was published in 1942<ref>''Introducción al estudio de la ontología jurídica''</ref> and his new pieces are being published posthumously.<ref>e.g. ''Relaciones entre política y derecho'', [in:] ''Verbo'', 461-462 (2008), pp. 13-35</ref> Except two volumes of ''Historia de la filosofía del derecho y del Estado'' (1946), until the very late of his life Tejada’s works were mostly articles in specialized reviews, lectures delivered at jurisprudential conferences or compendium-like textbooks intended for students. Tejada's vastly erudite<ref>discussing over 800 authors, referred after Fernandez de la Mora 1989, pp. 9-10</ref> opus magnum,<ref>considered also his single most important work of all, Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 9</ref> a systematic in-depth lecture gathering all his ideas on law theory was ''Tratado de filosofia del derecho'', published in Seville in two volumes respectively in 1974 and 1977.<ref>its 4 main areas were ontologia jurídica, sociología jurídica, lógica jurídica and derecho natural, Ayuso 2008, p. 9</ref> It is not clear how many of his almost 400 works<ref>according to a dedicated bibliographical study - Consuelo Caballero Baruque, ''Francisco Elias de Tejada: bibliografia'', Perugia 1984 - Tejada wrote 278 books (libros, opúscolos y monografías) and authored or co-authored 374 works including minor ones, referred after Ayuso 1997, p. 15, also Miguel Ayuso Torres, ''La filosofía jurídica y política de Francisco Elías de Tejada'', Madrid 1994, {{ISBN|8460495728}}, p. 40. The largest number of his works is available either via Fundacion Ignacio Larramendi available [http://www.larramendi.es/i18n/consulta/resultados_navegacion.cmd?busq_autoridadesbib=POLI20090017962&descrip_autoridadesbib=El%C3%ADas%20de%20Tejada,%20Francisco here] or via the ''Dialnet Unirioja'' service, available [https://dialnet.unirioja.es/buscar/documentos?querysDismax.DOCUMENTAL_TODO=elias+de+tejada here]</ref> fall into theory of law, though their number might near one hundred.<ref>either the key or the most representative ones are: ''Introducción al estudio de la ontología jurídica'' (1942); ''El hegelismo jurídico español'' (1944); ''Historia de la filosofía del derecho y del Estado'' (I-II, 1946); ''La filosofía jurídica en la España actual'' (1949); ''La filosofía del derecho y del Estado en Rumanía'' (1949); ''Si es posible una filosofía jurídica existencialista acristiana'' (1950); ''Filosofía del Trabajo, Madrid, Editorial Revista de Derecho Privado'' (1955), ''La filosofía del derecho en Finlandia'' (1951), ''La filosofía jurídica en la Noruega contemporanea'' (1954), ''Il tempo nella filosofia giuridica di Kant'', [in:] ''Rivista Internazionale di Filosofia del Diritto'' 24 (1957), ''Derecho y ley en José Ortega y Gasset'', [in:] ''Anales de la Cátedra Francisco Suárez'' 5-6 (1965-66), ''Memoria sobre el concepto, método, fuente, programa y plan de la asignatura Filosofía del Derecho y Derecho Natura'' (1968), ''Ciencia, ciencias y filosofía en Hegel'', [in:] ''Anales de la Cátedra Francisco Suárez'' 9-10 (1969-70), ''El Adat de los dayak de Borneo ante la filosofía del Derecho'', [in:] ''Revista de Estudios Políticos'' 183-184 (1972), ''La cuestión de la vigencia del derecho natural'', [in:] Francisco Puy (ed.), ''El derecho natural hispánico. Actas de las I Jornadas Hispánicas de Derecho Natural'' (1973), ''El saber filosófico en la aplicación del Derecho'', [in:] ''Anuario de Filosofía del Derecho'' 17 (1973-74), ''El derecho natural, fundamento de la civilización'', [in:] ''Revista Chilena de Derecho'' 1-2 (1974), 287-303; [with José F. Lorca Navarrete and Pablo Badillo O’Farrell:] ''Estudios de derecho bantú. Trabajos realizados en el Seminario de Derecho Africano en el Departamento de Filosofía del Derecho de la Facultad de Derecho de la Universidad de Sevilla'' (1974), ''El futuro del derecho bantú'', [in:] ''Anuario de Filosofía del Derecho'' 19 (1976-77), ''Tratado de filosofía del derecho'' (I-II, 1974-1977), ''Los principios generales del derecho en el artículo 1 del Código civil reformado en 1973'', [in:] ''El título preliminar del Código civil'' v. 1 (1977)</ref>
==Historian of political thought== [[File:FvfHagonoy1772 18.JPG|thumbnail|left|''Hispanidad: observing [[Good Friday]]'', [[Philippines|11,600 km from Madrid]]]] As historian of political ideas Tejada clearly focused on broad Hispanic realm: he published studies on [[Castile (historical region)|Castile]],<ref>''Gerónimo Castillo de Bovadilla'' (1939)</ref> [[Catalonia]],<ref>''Las doctrinas políticas en la Cataluña medieval'' (1950), ''Historia del pensamiento político catalán'' (co-authored with Gabriella Pèrcopo, 1963-1965), ''Balmes en la tradición política de Cataluña'', [in:] ''El otro Balmes'', Sevilla 1974</ref> [[Navarre]],<ref>''Navarra-España en los escritores navarros medievales'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 5/17 (1944), ''La literatura política en la Navarra medieval'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 17/63 (1956)</ref> [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]],<ref>''El Señorío de Vizcaya hasta 1812'' (1963), ''La provincia de Guipúzcoa'' (1965)</ref> Extremadura,<ref>''Tres escritores extremeños: Micael de Carvajal, José Cascales Muñoz, José López Prudencio'' (1950), ''El concepto de lo extremeño. En la filosofia y en el arte'' (1949), ''Para una intepretación extremeña de Donoso Cortes'' (1944), ''José Cascales Muñoz, sociólogo extremeño del 98'', [in:] ''Revista de la Facultad de Derecho de Madrid'' 17 (1949)</ref> [[Kingdom of Valencia|Valencia]]<ref>''El concepto del Reino de Valencia'' (1974)</ref> and [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]],<ref>''La tradición gallega'' (1944)</ref> produced works intended as synthetic accounts for Spain<ref>''Historia de la literatura política en las Españas'' (I-III, 1991), ''Las Españas. Formación histórica, tradiciones regionale''s (1948)</ref> and Portugal,<ref>''Las doctrinas políticas en Portugal. Edad Media'' (1943), ''La Tradición portuguesa. Los orígenes 1140-1521'' (1999)</ref> dedicated separate works to [[Franche-Comté]],<ref>''El Franco-Contado hispánico'' (1975), ''La Franche-Comté hispanique'', (1977), ''El pensamiento político del Franco-Contado de Borgoña'', [in:] ''Anales de la Universidad Hispalense'' 27 (1966)</ref> [[Sardinia]],<ref>''Cerdeña hispánica'' (1960), ''El pensamiento político del reino hispánico de Cerdeña'' (1954)</ref> Naples,<ref>''Nápoles hispánico'' (I-V, 1958-1964)</ref> [[Sicily]], [[Flanders]] and [[Malta]]<ref>referred after Cantero 1995, p. 145, Ayuso 2008, p. 19</ref> and wrote on Hispanic [[Florida]], [[Texas]] and [[California]], [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese holdings in Africa and Asia]],<ref>Ayuso 2008, p. 19</ref> [[the Philippines]], [[Chile]], [[Brazil]],<ref>''As doctrinas políticas de Farías Bito'' (1952); ''Las doctrinas políticas de Raimundo Farías Bito'' (1953), ''José Pedro Galvão de Sousa en la cultura brasileña'', [in:] ''Verbo'' 221-222 (1984)</ref> [[Colombia]]<ref>''El pensamiento político de los fundadores de Nueva Granada'' (1955)</ref> and [[Latin America]] in general. However, his comparatistic zeal made him discuss history of political thought also beyond the [[Lusitanic]] and Hispanic realm, e.g. in [[England]], [[Arabic]] and [[Sephardi Jews|Sephardic]] traditions, [[Germany]], [[Greece]], [[Sweden]], [[Norway]], [[Iceland]], [[Hungary]], [[Japan]], [[Thailand]], [[Borneo]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Mozambique]] and elsewhere.<ref>Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 11</ref>
Tejada strove to reconstruct and define a Hispanic political tradition<ref>detailed discussion in Bernardino Montejano, ''Las Españas Americanas seguñ Elías de Tejada'' (pp. 109-119), Clovis Lema García, ''As Espanhas Luso-Brasileiras'' (pp. 121-126), Silvio Vitale, ''La Napoli Ispanica'' (pp. 127-133), [all in:] Angel Sanchez de la Torre (ed.), ''Francisco Elías de Tejada. Figura y pensamiento'', Madrid 1995, {{ISBN|8486926890}}</ref> and vacillated between the role of historian and theorist.<ref>Cantero 1995, p. 131</ref> His understanding of Hispanidad was based on the concept of Las Españas, seen as embodied in confederal political shape<ref>Ayuso 1997, pp. 24-5</ref> but its essence having been pre-state commonality.<ref>Ayuso 2008, p. 18</ref> Relying on the [[unity in diversity]] recipé<ref>Cantero 1995, p. 144</ref> and incorporating local traditions, including the [[fueros]],<ref>Cantero 1995, p. 148</ref> Hispanic tradition consisted of two features: Catholic vision of life combined with missionary universalist spirit pursued by a federative monarchy.<ref>Cantero 1995, pp. 129, 141</ref> According to Tejada Hispanidad was born in the Middle Ages, climaxed during the early [[Habsburg Spain|España de los Austrias]]<ref>Cantero 1995, pp. 143, 145</ref> and declined due to centralist French tradition imported by the [[Enlightenment in Spain|Borbones]].<ref>Cecotti 2005, p. 209</ref> His recurring subject<ref>more in Consuelo Martínez-Sicluna y Sepúlveda, ''La antinomia Europa-España según Elías de Tejada'', [in:] Angel Sanchez de la Torre (ed.), ''Francisco Elías de Tejada. Figura y pensamiento'', Madrid 1995 {{ISBN|8486926890}}, pp. 75-93</ref> was confronting Hispanic and European traditions, the latter born out of anti-Catholic,<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 25</ref> revolutionary, modernist thought<ref>Cecotti 2005, p. 205</ref> and ultimately responsible for breaking the Hispanic community by force.<ref>Ayuso 1997, pp. 24-5</ref> [[File:Amtrack-82.jpg|thumbnail|160px|''Hispanidad: fighting the British'', [[Falkland Islands|11,600 km from Madrid]]]] Tejada understood political thought as a vehicle of sustaining tradition<ref>Cantero 1995, p. 151</ref> and ignored the imperial and ethnic dimensions of Hispanidad. He viewed the Hispanic political community as forged by will of the people forming its components, not as a result of conquest.<ref>Ayuso 1997, pp. 24-5</ref> Ethnic features were merely means of transmitting heritage and a nation was defined as commonality of tradition,<ref>Cantero 1995, p. 132</ref> as opposed to positivist definitions focusing on features like language, geography, regime etc.;<ref>Cantero 1995, p. 142</ref> it enabled implantation of Hispanidad in vastly different settings of the Philippines, [[Uruguay]] or Franche-Comté. Tejada saw the Hispanic tradition against a decisively [[Providentialism|providential]] background, e.g. when confronting [[Islam]], [[Protestantism]] or the [[New World]];<ref>Cantero 1995, p. 134</ref> scholars saw this approach as indebted to the vision of [[Giambattista Vico]].<ref>Cantero 1995, p. 147, Goytisolo 1981, p. 113</ref> Another frequently applied personal comparison was that to [[Marcelino Menéndez y Pelayo|Marcelino Menéndez Pelayo]]: the two shared passion for Hispanic patrimony,<ref>Cuenca Toribio 1994, p. 370</ref> massive erudition, reconstructive profile and Traditionalist leaning;<ref>Cantero 1995, pp. 123-4, Fernandez de la Mora 1989, pp. 11-12</ref> Tejada’s approach is dubbed "menéndezpelayismo".<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 23. Indeed Tejada started reading Menendez at the age of 13, Cantero 1995, p. 128</ref>
Tejada's first work on history of political thought appeared in 1937<ref>''Notas para una teoría del Estado según nuestros autores clásicos, siglos XVI y XVII'' (1937), ''Ideas políticas de Ángel Ganivet'' (1939)</ref> and the last ones in 1977.<ref>''La Franche-Comté hispanique'' (1977)</ref> Unlike in case of theory of law, he did not produce a synthesis which would stand out; his thought is scattered across countless books, articles or minor opuscolos. Single works to be listed first are perhaps [[Case study|case studies]], the monumental<ref>and considered – after ''Tratado de Derecho'' – Tejada's second most important work, Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 10</ref> ''Nápoles hispánico'' (1958-1964)<ref>spanning across 5 volumes and 2300 pages, co-authored with his wife and the result of 7 years spent on research mission in Naples</ref> and an unfinished ''Historia del pensamiento político catalán'' (1963-1965).<ref>it was intended to cover 11 volumes; only 3 were published, 2 of them co-authored with his wife</ref> Publications attempting more general overview to be named are ''La causa diferenciadora de las comunidades políticas'' (1943), ''Las Españas'' (1948) and ''Historia de la literatura política en las Españas'' (1952, published 1991).
==Theorist of politics== {{main|Traditionalism (Spain)}} [[File:JuanDonosoCortes.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|Traditionalism: [[Juan Donoso Cortés|Donoso]]]] Initially Tejada developed a Hispanidad-oriented<ref>a contemporary scholar notes that the young Tejada seemed determined to prove that even the works of Aristotle led straight to the caudillaje theory, though he paid particula attention to mounting it within a Hispanic tradition, Bartyzel 2015, pp. 253-4</ref> [[Caudillo|leadership theory]]<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 32</ref> of [[Authoritarian leadership style|authoritarian state]];<ref>''La figura del Caudillo'' (1939), contributed to theoretical basis of Francoism and placed de Tejada in line with Juan Beneyto Pérez, Francisco Javier Conde García and Luis Legaz Lacambra, key law theorists of the early regime, Bartyzel 2015, p. 253, also Sergio Fernández Riquelme, ''Sociología, corporativismo y política social en España. Las décadas del pensamiento corporativo en España: de Ramiro de Maeztu a Gonzalo Fernández de la Mora'', 1877-1977 [PhD thesis Universidad de Murcia] 2008, pp. 447, 560-561</ref> according to some in the early 1940s<ref>''Monarquía y Caudillaje'' (1941) already differentiated between a fundamental caudillaje and a circumstantial dictatorship, Bartyzel 2015, p. 257, also Sebastián Martín, ''Los juristas en la gènesis del franquismo ¿Un contraste posible?'', [in:] Italo Birocchi, Luca Loschiavo (eds.), ''I giuristi e il fascino del regime'', Roma 2015, {{ISBN|9788897524410}}, pp. 412-413</ref> he performed a volte-face<ref>Cuenca Toribio 1994, p. 374</ref> becoming a vehement anti-Francoist,<ref>anti-Francoist pamphlets of the era pamphlets remained in manuscripts: ''Los principados carismáticos según los clásicos españoles'', ''El caudillaje es la tiranía anticatólica'' and ''Tríptico sobre las dictaduras'' (dating uncertain, most likely early or mid 1940s), Bartyzel 2015, p. 260</ref> according to the others during decades to come his theory was progressively dissociated<ref>according to a sympathetic author Tejada relationship with Franquism was fluctuating and justified impression of some collaboration, but in fact was marked by refusal to compromise ideals, Ayuso 1997, pp. 32-3</ref> from Francoism,<ref>Fernandez de la Mora 1989, pp. 7-8; Traditionalist thinkers in general remained cautious towards Francoism, though there were exceptions, the most notable one Vicente Marrero, Ayuso 1997, p. 33</ref> some see 3 phases of his evolution<ref>"in the first and shortest stage, between 1939 and 1941, Elías de Tejada was an enthusiast of the national-syndicalist state and theorist of the caudillaje system of power. In the second stage (1941–1955), starting from a distinction between dictatorship and caudillaje, now equated only with rightful and traditional monarchy, he became a radical and intransigent opponent of General Franco’s personal dictatorship, calling it scornfully “Caudiland” and seeing the authoritarian regime as one of the forms of political modernism and totalitarianism, contrary to the Spanish and Catholic tradition. In the third stage (from 1955 to Franco’s death), while not changing his critical opinion of the regime and its leader, he tended to pursue a “possibilistic cultural policy” within the regime", Jacek Bartyzel, ''Tradycjonalizm a dyktatura. Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola wobec frankizmu'', [in:] Marek Maciejewski, Tomasz Scheffler (eds.), ''Studia nad Autorytaryzmem i Totalitaryzmem'' 36/2 (2014), p. 7</ref> and some advance rambling summaries.<ref>e.g. "enmarcado dentro de la ideologia carlista, tradicional-conservadora y defensora del regimen del general Franco", ''Elías de Tejada, Francisco'' entry [in:] Gran Enciclopedia de España vol. 8, Madrid 1992, {{ISBN|8487544088}}, p. 3520</ref> Some scholars highlight 1938-1940 works and consider him „superfascista”,<ref>Anna Caballé, Arcadi Espada, ''Entrevista a Alonso de los Rios'', [in:] ''Boletin de la Unidad de Estudios Biograficos'' 3 (1998), p. 78; this opinion has also filtered out to popular discourse abroad, compare "Übereinstimmend mit ihren faschistischen Vorbildern, herrschte auch in der Falange das Führerprinzip. Die Partei verkörperte den Willen des Volkes, Franco brachte ihn zum Ausdruck. Seine Entscheidungen waren als "Quell der Souveränität" und "Wurzel irdischer Macht" unanfechtbar, wie der Rechtsphilosoph Francisco Elías de Tejada 1939 pathetisch ausführte", Carlos Collado Seidel, ''Der General, der Krieg und die Kirche'', [in:] ''Die Zeit'' 27.08.13</ref> most students tend to downplay caudillaje-related writings<ref>see e.g. a theory that the caudillaje period of Tejada was brief and ambiguous, hence he can not be named theorist of caudillaje or nacional-sindicalismo, Ayuso 1997, p. 32; notably, starting early 1940s Tejada in private ironically referred to the Francoist Spain as "caudillandia", see Bartyzel 2015</ref> and focusing on the 1942-1978 period see Tejada as a Traditionalist;<ref>or more specifically, as a „Carlist Traditionalist”, Ayuso 1997, p. 32</ref> few advance an in-between option of "franquismo neotradicionalista".<ref>Jorge Novella, ''El pensamiento reaccionario español, 1812-1975: tradición y contrarrevolución en España'', Madrid 2007, {{ISBN|9788497425483}}, pp. 248-9, esp. the chapter ''El franquismo tradicionalista: Elías de Tejada y Fernández de la Mora''</ref> Among those supporting the Traditionalist tag many consider him "maximo representante del pensamiento tradicionalista español en la segunda mitad del siglo XX"<ref>Pablo Ramírez Jerez, ''La Biblioteca de D. Francisco Elías de Tejada'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'' 19 (2013), p. 206</ref> or at least one of the key ones,<ref>along Gambra, d’Ors and Canals, who elevated the Carlist doctrine to its highest levels just when the Carlist movement started to fall into profound crisis, Miguel Ayuso, ''El Carlismo y su signo'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'' 14 (2008) [furtherly referred as Ayuso 2008 (2)], p. 125; some commentators noticed that "[https://de.wikiquote.org/wiki/Georg_Wilhelm_Friedrich_Hegel die Eule der Minerva beginnt erst mit der einbrechenden Dämmerung ihren Flug]"; there are scholars who think that "among the Carlist thinkers of the post-war period, the first place goes to Rafael Gambra", Adam Wielomski, ''Hiszpania Franco'', Biała Podlaska 2008, {{ISBN|8392158695}}, p. 234</ref> though some present him as a second-rank theorist.<ref>in a recent, 6,000-word encyclopaedic entry on Traditionalism, Elías de Tejada is treated marginally; paragraphs dedicated to the Francoist period highlight rather Rafael Calvo Serrer and other Juanista intellectuals. De Tejada is named representative of "tradicionalismo carlista", presented as a secondary thread accommodated within a broad scope of Calvo Serrer’s project. Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Tradicionalismo'', [in:] Javier Fernández Sebastián (ed.), ''Diccionario político y social del siglo XX español'', Madrid 2008, {{ISBN|9788420687698}}, pp. 1171-1172; similar perspective in Pedro Carlos Gonzalez Cuevas, ''El pensamiento político de la derecha española an el siglo XX'', Madrid 2005, {{ISBN|9788430942237}}; Tejada is noted 4 times, Calvo Serrer is noted 8 times and Gonzalo Fernandez de la Mora 18 times</ref>
Tejada perceived Traditionalism as a unique Spanish response<ref>other Catholic countries capable of developing own response failed to do so, Germany falling into Romantic speculativism, France disintegrating into post-revolutionary schemes and Poland pursuing independentist political illusion. Tejada clearly distinguished between Spanish traditionalism, rooted in history and religion, and European neotraditionalisms, as speculative and deprived of the godly and monarchical ingredient,Ayuso 2008 (2), p. 129-130, Ayuso 1997, pp. 26-27. European quasi-Traditionalism was created with anti-revolutionary intention, but deprived of religious and onthological ingredient and was a strategy rather than a system of thought, Joaquim Veríssimo Serrão, Alfonso Bullón de Mendoza, ''La contrarrevolución legitimista, 1688-1876'', Madrid 1995, {{ISBN|9788489365155}}, pp 24-25</ref> to the 1515-1648 rupture in European political thought;<ref>the rupture took place on 5 levels: the religious one of Luther, the moral one of Machiavelli, the political one of Bodin, the juridical one of Grocio and Hobbes and the administrative one of the Westphalia Treaty, Ayuso 2008 (2), p. 129, Ayuso 1997, p. 25, Cantero 1995, p. 149</ref> the latter afterwards degenerated into [[Absolute monarchy|absolutism]], [[liberalism]], [[totalitarism]],<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 26</ref> and most recently into secular, parliamentarian, free-market, nation-state<ref>Cecotti 2005, p. 208; Tejada despised nation-states as born out of nationalisms, new movements not rooted in traditions, Ayuso 2008, pp. 17-18, 23</ref> [[Liberal democracy|democracies]]. Traditionalism itself was politically best embodied<ref>Tejada clearly differentiated Traditionalism from Carlism, Ayuso 2008 (2), p. 127</ref> in Carlism.<ref>he considered Carlism the guardian and depositary of the Spanish tradition if not Traditionalism itself, Cantero 1995, p. 154. He also noted that "un tradicinalismo español sin carlismo se mueve en el orden de una consideración de la esencia sin la existencia", quoted after Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 562</ref> Its essence was threefold. First, it consisted of Catholic unity;<ref>he deemed religion the key unifying factor of Hispanic realm, though unlike Gambra, d’Ors or Canals, he did not make it the primary and decisive topic, see Ayuso 2008 (2).</ref> some scholars claim that Tejada was opposed to religious liberty,<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 30</ref> others maintain that he was opposed to equality of faiths and advocated a state-endorsed Catholic orthodoxy.<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, ''Elías de Tejada y Spinola Francisco'', [in:] ''legitymizm'' service, available [http://www.legitymizm.org/pef-elias-de-tejada-y-spinola here]. As a Catholic he remained deeply conservative, very uneasy with the Second Vatican Council and never reconciled with its outcome (Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 8, Jacek Bartyzel, ''Franciszek Elías de Tejada y Spínola - hidalgo, filozof, karlista''). Profoundly religious but not clerical, he commenced to assume anti-clerical shape following increasingly democratic and progressive stand of the Church – both global and Spanish (see his pun "Pablo Sexto – Mao Sexto", Bartyzel 2015, p. 241), or kept referring to Paul VI as "Montini" (Aquilino Duque, ''Menéndez Pelayo y la Universidad Internacional de Verano'', [in:] ''Fundacion Nacional Francisco Franco'' service, available [http://www.fnff.es/Menendez_Pelayo_y_la_Universidad_Internacional_de_Verano_795_c.htm here]). Invitation for him to join the Second Vatican Council has been issued, but for unclear reason has never reached him (Brocos Fernández 2005). Tejada was particularly hostile to the Christian-Democratic format of religion-inspired policy making, and allegedly developed hatred for its embodiment, Opus Dei, Javier Lavardin [José Antonio Parilla], ''Historia del ultimo pretendiente a la corona de España'', Paris 1976, p. 146</ref> Second, it embraced historical,<ref>i.e. rooted in local traditions and based on common historical identity. He kept claiming that peoples (pueblos) are traditions, not nations, and repeated after [[Enrique Gil Robles]] that there is no life beyond tradition, Ayuso 2008, pp. 17, Ayuso 1997, p. 23</ref> [[sociedalismo (theory)|social]],<ref>Tejada remained vehemently against the free-market idea, deemed born out of the liberal concept; instead he advocated a Christianity-guided state-exercised control, which would prevent excesses of exploitation and injustice, Cecotti 2005, p. 208</ref> accountable,<ref>by no means absolutist, monarchical rights were limited by traditionalist bodies and the laws of God, permitting deposition of a monarch who does not obey, Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 12, Ayuso 1997, p. 31</ref> [[Political representation|representative]],<ref>representation is to be channeled via traditional bodies and not by means of universal suffrage; all individuals were entitled to representation, but not as equals, Ayuso 1997, p. 31</ref> [[Fuero|foral]],<ref>a fuero was considered an intrincic element of political order, embodying all traditional rights and forming organic part of the totality, as opposed to allegedly invented anthropologic abstractions and mechanicist politics fuelling revolutionary thought, Ayuso 1997, p. 27, Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 561</ref> [[Federation|federative]],<ref>distinctive pueblos are to be self-governed, united by the same faith and same monarch, Ayuso 2008 (2), p. 131</ref> [[Apostle (Christian)|missionary]],<ref>Ayuso 2008 (2), p. 131; it is also referred to as "apostolic", i.e. exercising a mission with respect to other political entities</ref> [[Organicism|organic]]<ref>i.e. society of societies, all separate components united in one integrity which does not infringe their plurality, commonality, autonomy, decentralisation, natural hierarchy, localisation and personalization, Ayuso 1997, p. 29; other scholars consider Tejada'a organicism a smoke-screen formula intended to disguise dictatorial nature of the Francoist regime, Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 540</ref> and [[Hereditary monarchy|hereditary]] monarchy.<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 30, Evaristo Palomar Maldonado, ''La Monarquía Tradicional en el pensamiento de Elías de Tejada'', [in:] Angel Sanchez de la Torre (ed.), ''Francisco Elías de Tejada. Figura y pensamiento'', Madrid 1995 {{ISBN|8486926890}}, pp. 177-196, also Fernandez de la Cigoña 1996, p. 193; also "partidario de una Monarquia tradicional, [...] catolica, social, representativa y federativa, como alternativa al totalitarismo franquista", Gonzalez Cuevas 2005, p. 190</ref> Third, it was based on a [[Subsidiarity|subsidiary state model]].<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, ''Elías de Tejada y Spinola Francisco'', [in:] ''legitymizm'' service</ref> The latter marked total reversal from original Tejada's penchant for omnipotent leadership<ref>he later lambasted "estatolatría hegeliana", Cuenca Toribio 1994, p. 371; in 1954 he criticised fascism and falangism as "modernist movement, confronting liberalism and marxism by means adopted from Renan, Sorel and finally, Hegel", quoted after Wielomski 2006, p. 234</ref> and reflected the Traditionalist logic of state serving society, society serving man, and man serving God. A de-centralized<ref>allegedly rooted in Catholic, Thomist and foralist inspirations, pitted against regalist, ontology-based and centralised designs, in theory of politics, see ''Fundación Elías de Tejada'' service available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/ here], Ayuso 2008, p. 20</ref> withdrawn state,<ref>there is even a theory for Tejada state was a historic (i.e. not primordial, emergent in specific circumstances) concept with no given ideological content, Ayuso 1997, p. 29</ref> with is functions reduced, is to provide merely a framework for communities making it up, developed historically and safeguarded by separate legal establishments;<ref>far beyond a juridical concept, the fueros constituted a basis of organicismo and stod for de-centralization, self-government (named "autarquía"), and "less state more society" recipé, Ayuso 1997, p. 28</ref> The communities in question are to be governed by autonomous intermediary bodies<ref>Cecotti 2005, p. 207, Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 12, Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 562</ref> and should participate in state politics represented in the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] by delegates of various "gremios, hermandades, agrupaciones, cámaras, comunidades y cofradías";<ref>Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 12, Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 562</ref> Tejada juxtaposed Spanish communitarian fueros<ref>by no means reducible to "regionalism", Ayuso 1997, p. 29; the question whether fuero was a law or a norm seems left open, see Cantero 1996, p. 148</ref> against the French individual liberties.<ref>Cecotti 2005, p. 206</ref> According to some, the proposal advanced by Tejada was intended as a discussion how Spain should look like after Franco.<ref>Cuenca Toribio 1994, p. 374</ref> [[File:RequeteViladot.JPG|thumbnail|160px]] Tejada's works on theory of politics are visibly less numerous than those on theory of law or on history of political thought; moreover, some of them resemble political manifestos rather than scholarly writings. Preceded by caudillaje-oriented brochures of the late 1930s,<ref>''La figura del Caudillo. Contribución al derecho público nacional-sindicalista'' (1939), ''El nuevo Estado nacional-sindicalista. Antecedentes y teoría, con un esbozo de una nueva teoría del Estado'' (1938), ''El pensamiento político de Falange Española y de las J.O.N.S.'' (1939, 1940)</ref> the main body of his Traditionalism was laid out mostly in the 1950s, following activity in Academia Vazquez de Mella; its most complete and straightforward lecture was ''La monarquía tradicional'' (1954),<ref>published in Italy as ''La monarchia tradizionale'' (1966, 2001)</ref> though some, like ''El tradicionalismo político español'', remained in manuscript.<ref>another title to be noted is ''Sacrum Imperium und überstaatliche Ordnung'' (1952)</ref> The vision was further refined in details in the 1960s, especially during Congresses of Traditionalist Studies<ref>''Discurso inaugural del Primer Congreso de Estudios Tradicionalistas'' (1964), ''Discurso inaugural del Segundo Congreso de Estudios Tradicionalistas'' (1968)</ref> and systematically revisited in the early 1970s, mostly as result of political struggle taking place within Carlism: a lengthy manuscript was reduced into a manual-styled script - officially co-authored with [[Rafael Gambra Ciudad]] and [[:gl:Francisco Puy Muñoz|Francisco Puy Muñoz]]<ref>actual contribution of all 3 authors is not clear; some scholars claim that the document was written mostly by Tejada</ref> - ''¿Qué es el carlismo?'' (1971),<ref>co-athored with Gambra and Puy Muñoz (1971)</ref> with late re-workings and compilations published either shortly before death or posthumously.<ref>''Decálogo del tradicionalismo español'' (manuscript, 1977), ''Europa, tradizione, libertà. Saggi di filosofia politica'' (2005), ''Poder y libertad. Una visión desde el tradicionalismo hispánico'' (2008)</ref>
==Carlist: around Francoism (1936-1950)== [[File:Desfile de tropas por las calles de San Sebastián (8 de 20) - Fondo Car-Kutxa Fototeka.jpg|thumb|left|[[Requete]] on parade]] Some authors maintain that there were no Carlist antecedents in the Tejada family;<ref>Rafael Gambra, ''Elías de Tejada en el tradicionalismo político español'', [in:] Angel Sanchez de la Torre (ed.), ''Francisco Elías de Tejada. Figura y pensamiento'', Madrid 1995 {{ISBN|8486926890}}, p. 5, Bartyzel 2015, p. 238</ref> however, records reveal that a Justiniano Elías de Tejada,<ref>exact relation is unclear; he was probably either Francisco’s paternal grandfather or Francisco’s paternal grandfather’s brother</ref> though initially opposing [[:es:Neocatólico|neo-Catholic]] designs in the 1860s,<ref>''La Discusión'' 24.04.64, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002308350&page=3 here]; Tejada graduated in 1865, ''Datos Estadísticos'' 1865-1866, available [http://gredos.usal.es/jspui/bitstream/10366/84138/1/bg_revistas_1178_1-12_9.pdf here]</ref> in the early 1870s turned president of Junta Carlista de Castuera<ref>''La Esperanza'' 14.05.70, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002514931&page=1 here]</ref> and was even subject to jokes because of that.<ref>''El Solfeo'' 25.07.75, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004041841&page=3 here]</ref> Francisco himself claimed he had joined [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]] at the age of 15, remained a Carlist during his adolescence<ref>e.g. taking part in the massive Quintillo gathering of Andalusian Carlists, see also his ''Por qué fuí a Requete y porqué voy a Quintillo'', [in:] ''Fundación Ignacio Larramendi'' service, available [http://www.larramendi.es/i18n/consulta/registro.cmd?id=1464 here]</ref> and in 1936 returned from Germany to enlist to the Nationalist army responding to the call of his king, [[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Alfonso Carlos]],<ref>according to himself "desde 1932, contando apenas quince años, milité en una de las dos organizaciones inspiradoras del Movimiento Nacional, la Comunión Tradicionalista, tomando parte activa en todas las luchas estudiantiles contra la Anti-España", quoted after Vallejo 2015</ref> though he provided also conflicting or confusing accounts.<ref>which suggest that he had little to do with Carlism prior to 1936. Asked why he joined the Carlists, Tejada allegedly responded: "porque en el mapa político de España en 1936 el Requeté era la sola encarnación completa de la savia patria: el único movimiento que enarbolaba la bandera de las edades de oro de nuestros pueblos: las aspas rojas de sangre sobre el blanco teológico de la verdad católica. El Requeté era a secas España y yo soy español. Porque la amenaza europea y protestante contra las Españas sigue en pie: ejemplo, la vergonzosa actitud de las Europas "yankees" contra el hermano Portugal. Porque 1936 no fue más que un eslabón más en la larguísima cadena de nuestras luchas defendiendo la Cristiandad contra Europa: Pavía, Mühlberg, la Invencible, Nordlingen, Rocroy, el reparto de Utrecht, la ayuda inglesa al separatismo americano, el filibusterismo anglosajón del 98, la ayuda franco-inglesa a Negrín... Porque mientras las Españas sean el postrer reducto de la Cristiandad, los carlistas estaremos montando la guardia contra sus seculares enemigos", quoted after ''¿Por qué fue carlista Francisco Elías de Tejada?'', [in:] ''Reino Granada'' service 22.06.15, available [http://reinodegranada.blogspot.com/2015/06/por-que-fue-carlista-francisco-elias-de.html here]</ref>
Nothing is known about Tejada political activity during the Civil War and soon afterwards; though seconded to a [[Falange Española de las JONS|Falangist]] unit,<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> he is not mentioned as engaged in Carlist, Falangist or other party structures until the early 1940s. However, his writings published in 1938-1939 clearly identified him as enthusiast of [[national syndicalism]] and the [[Caudillo|caudillaje]] system;<ref>''La figura del Caudillo. Contribución al derecho público nacional-sindicalista'' (1939), ''El nuevo Estado nacional-sindicalista. Antecedentes y teoría, con un esbozo de una nueva teoría del Estado'' (1938), ''El pensamiento político de Falange Española y de las J.O.N.S.'' (1939)</ref> some consider him concerned primarily with justifying the regime.<ref>Anna Caballé, Arcadi Espada, ''Entrevista a Alonso de los Rios'', [in:] ''Boletin de la Unidad de Estudios Biograficos'' 3 (1998), p. 78</ref> He admitted great juvenile admiration for [[Hitler]].<ref>which he admitted himself many years afterwards as an error, Cecotti 2005, p. 210</ref> It was the second stay in Germany in 1940 that got him disillusioned with omnipotent state and [[One-party state|single party]]; his 1940 article discussing caudillaje was notably tuned down and introduced a cautious tone.<ref>see his ''Monarquía y caudillaje'', [in:] ''Revista de la Facultad de Derecho de Madrid'' 6-7 (1941), pp. 69-88, discussed at length in Bartyzel 2015, pp. 257-258</ref> In the early 1940s he was assuming an increasingly dissenting stance. In 1942 he referred to "misería" of the Francoist system;<ref>confronted with "grandeza" of its heroic origins; he advoated a new "alzamiento moral", Bartyzel 2015, p. 249; his authorship is not clear and attributed by Galarreta, see Manuel de Santa Cruz (ed.), ''Apuntes y documentos para la historia del tradicionalismo español (1939-1966)'', vol. 4, Sevilla 1979, pp. 135-139</ref> the same year he was briefly detained for opposing subscriptions to [[División Azul]].<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> Though he had no chance to publish writings lambasting the system as anti-Catholic tyranny,<ref>''Los principados carismáticos según los clásicos españoles'', ''El caudillaje es la tiranía anticatólica'' and ''Tríptico sobre las dictaduras'', Bartyzel 2015, p. 260</ref> Tejada made little secret of his views and in the Salamanca law faculty he voted against granting Franco doctorado honoris causa.<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> In 1944<ref>Bartyzel 2015, p. 261</ref> a [[Falange Española Tradicionalista y de las Juntas de Ofensiva Nacional Sindicalista|Falangist]] hit-squad stormed into his house, dragged him to the nearby [[Retiro Park|Retiro park]] and left him beaten unconscious.<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, ''Tradycjonalizm a dyktatura. Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola wobec frankizmu'', [in:] ''Legitymizm'' service, available [http://www.legitymizm.org/tradycjonalizm-dyktatura here], also Idoia Estornes Zubizarreta, ''Francisco Elías de Tejada'', [in:] ''Aunamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/38106 here]</ref> [[File:Duarte Nuno de Braganza.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Duarte Nuno, Duke of Braganza|Dom Duarte Nuno]]. 1945]] In the mid 1940s Tejada again neared Carlism, at that time with no king, divided into few factions and politically bewildered. First commencing co-operation with their periodicals,<ref>in 1942 with ''La Misión''. Bartyzel 2015, p. 249</ref> in the Madrid cafes he mixed with Carlists of different persuasions, including the pro-collaborationist [[Carloctavismo|Carloctavistas]]<ref>Brocos Fernández 2005</ref> and the intransigent orthodox [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Javieristas]]; he also took part in their minor public manifestations against the regime.<ref>with the three Hernando Larramendi brothers, two Zabala brothers, Rafael Gambra, Fernando Polo, Pueyo Alvarez, González Quevedo, Amancio Portabales, Luis Ortiz y Estrada, Luis Alonso, Rafael Lluys and others; their demonstrations included e.g. not raising a hand in the Francoist salute when standing in the crowd saluting Franco during football matches in Madrid, Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009, p. 205</ref> In unspecified circumstances, though most likely acting in agreement if not on request of the then Carlist political leader [[Manuel Fal Conde]], Tejada ventured to co-organize a semi-official Traditionalist cultural network, which materialized as the Madrid Academia Vázquez de Mella; in the late 1940s he was among its most active lecturers.<ref>Bartyzel 2015, pp. 246-7</ref> Now openly confronting the regime and in 1947 advocating a "no" vote in the [[Spanish law of succession referendum, 1947|Ley de Sucesión referendum]],<ref>Tejada ridiculed the referendum it in his mock ''Hoja Oficial del Lunes'', referred after Manuel de Santa Cruz (ed.), ''Apuntes y documentos para la historia del tradicionalismo español (1939-1966)'', vol. 9, Sevilla 1981, pp. 124-129, referred after Bartyzel 2015, pp. 261-2</ref> politically Tejada avoided clear identification with any of the Carlist groupings. He seemed closest to supporters of [[Duarte Nuno, Duke of Braganza|Dom Duarte Nuño de Braganza]] as a potential Carlist heir;<ref>Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias: el carlismo, 1962-1977'', Pamplona 1997, {{ISBN|9788431315641}}, p. 13. One of possible readings of the Carlist succession theory was that in case all male descendant branches are either extinguished or excluded from the throne, hereditary rights might be passed to the oldest daughter of the last king. While some Carlists applied this reading to the oldest daughter of Carlos VII, the others - including Tejada - applied it to the oldest daughter of Felipe V as the last king ruling all Spains, and successively to her last legitimate male descendant, Don Duarte, [[Melchor Ferrer Dalmau|Melchor Ferrer]], ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'', vol. XXX, Sevilla 1979, pp. 71-72</ref> according to other sources he merely considered the Portuguese claimant a viable candidate.<ref>Bartyzel 2015, p. 248</ref> The period of vacillation ended in 1950, when Tejada aligned with the Javieristas<ref>though Tejada claimed he was not a politician and did not make politics, Cantero 1995, p. 153</ref> and accepted seat in their national executive, in 1951 nominated by Don Javier commissioner of Comunión Tradicionalista external affairs.<ref>Bartyzel 2015, p. 251</ref>
==Carlist: ''Javierista'' (1950-1962)== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] In the early 1950s Tejada got firmly engaged in mainstream Carlism and demonstrated an uncompromising political stand. He lambasted the dissenting Carloctavistas,<ref>e.g. in his manifesto intended for Frente Nacional Carlista, in which using his erudition he argued against dynastical claim of Carlos Pio, styled as Carlos VIII, Ayuso 1994, p. 335, Bartyzel 2015, p. 252</ref> complained to Fal about permissive, increasingly [[Christian democracy|Christian-Democratic]] profile of a semi-official Carlist daily ''Informaciones'',<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 337</ref> and advocated that Don Javier goes bold by terminating the long overdue [[regency]]. He co-drafted ''Declaración de Barcelona'', the statement which was issued by Don Javier in 1952 and which indeed announced his own claim to the Carlist throne,<ref>Mercedes Vázquez de Prada Tiffe, ''El papel del carlismo navarro en el inicio de la fragmentación definitiva de la comunión tradicionalista (1957-1960)'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 72 (2011), p. 395, Lavardin 1976, pp. 145-6</ref> though the episode is not entirely clear.<ref>some scholars claim he did not father the ''Declaración'', Bartyzel 2015, p. 252</ref> With the 1954 publication of ''La monarquía tradicional'' Tejada became the top Carlist theorist; the same year within the party top body, Junta Nacional, he formed part of Comisión de Cultura y Propaganda.<ref>the comisión was led by José María Valiente and was divided into 2 sub-commissions; Tejada led the one of culture, Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''La metamorfosi del carlisme català: del "Déu, Pàtria i Rei" a l'Assamblea de Catalunya (1936-1975)'', Barcelona 2014, {{ISBN|9788498837261}}, p. 138</ref> At that time he was considered among key politicians of Carlism.<ref>according to Gambra, Fernandez de la Cigoña 1996, p. 191. Similar impression might be gained in Mercedes Vázquez de Prada, ''El final de una ilusión. Auge y declive del tradicionalismo carlista (1957-1967)'', Madrid 2016, {{ISBN|9788416558407}}, p. 40</ref>
When in 1955 Fal Conde was released from Jefatura and when Carlism abandoned intransigent opposition to the regime in favor of cautious co-operation, Tejada was left puzzled.<ref>some scholars claim that in mid-1950s Tejada considered intransigent position of Fal a mistake and advocated cautious opening towards Francoism, Bartyzel 2015, p. 263; others note that he voiced against collaborationist stand of Valiente, Mercedes Vázquez de Prada Tiffe, ''El nuevo rumbo político del carlismo hacia la colaboración con el régimen (1955-56)'', [in:] ''Hispania'' 69 (2009), p. 190</ref> He did not hesitate to voice his doubts about collaboratice strategy advocated by the new leader [[José María Valiente Soriano|Jose Maria Valiente]],<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2009, p. 190</ref> yet he decided to comply and accepted appointment to the newly formed Secretariat;<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 393</ref> moreover, at one point he suggested that the body be dissolved as ineffective and replaced by Valiente's personal jefatura.<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 41</ref> Executing the rapprochement policy<ref>he advocated traditionalist monarchy as the only viable longtime option using his personal contacts, e.g. in 1956 talking with Jesús Salas, then vice-secretary of Movimiento, Vázquez de Prada 2009, p. 203</ref> he did not believe in its success and was getting increasingly frustrated by [[Francisco Franco|Franco’s]] rejection of the Carlist offer.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 432. In 1959 he was fined 30,000 ptas by the civil governor of Huelva for organizing a conference deemed hostile to the regime, Vallejo 2015</ref> However, he readily engaged in new formats of activity, now permitted by the regime: Tejada was active in the Carlist publishing house<ref>''El profesor Francisco Elias de Tejada y Spinola'', [in:] ''Fundacion Elias de Tejada'' service, available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/ here]</ref> Ediciones Montejurra<ref>some claim that he co-founded Ediciones Montejurra, Jacek Bartyzel, ''Tradycjonalizm a dyktatura. Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola wobec frankizmu'', [in:] ''Legitymizm service'', available [http://www.legitymizm.org/tradycjonalizm-dyktatura here], the same opinion in Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 124</ref> and became its director,<ref>e.g. he is listed as such in Melchor Ferrer, ''Breve historia del legitimismo español'', issued by Ediciones Montejurra in 1958, p. 2</ref> animated the elitist Traditionalist periodical ''Reconquista'',<ref>''El profesor Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spinola'', [in:] ''Fundación Elias de Tejada'' service, available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/ here]</ref> contributed to new periodicals like ''Azada y Asta''<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 54</ref> and especially threw himself into organizing Círculos Culturales Vázquez de Mella, a semi-official Carlist institutional network.<ref>see Manuel de Santa Cruz (ed.), ''Apuntes y documentos para la historia del tradicionalismo español (1939-1966)'', vol. 20, Madrid 1989, pp. 119-124, 274-284; de Tejada soon developed doubts about perceived Opus Dei influence in the Circulos, which led some Carlists politicians, e.g. Zamanillo, to believe that he was biased against the network, Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 126</ref> In 1960 he entered Comision de Cultura of the Carlist executive<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 114</ref> and advocated setting up an "Instituto de Estudios Jurídicos".<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 167</ref> [[File:Don Javier 1960.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]], 1960]] Having moved on longtime scientific research mission to Italy, at the turn of the decades Tejada was getting increasingly detached from daily Carlist politics. Within the Secretariat and numerous cultural outposts<ref>e.g. in the early 1960s taking part in Semanas de Estudios Tradicionalistas, organized by Sección Universitaria of AET, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 465</ref> he was somewhat sidetracked by a new breed of young activists forming the entourage of prince [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Carlos Hugo]].<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 445</ref> Though he knew some, especially their leader [[Ramón Massó Tarruella|Ramón Massó]], from the Academia Vázquez de Mella years of the 1940s,<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 382, Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''Carlos Hugo frente a Juan Carlos.: La solución federal para España que Franco rechazó'', Madrid 2014, {{ISBN|9788477682653}}, p. 45</ref> Tejada developed grave doubts about Carlist orthodoxy and genuine intentions of the hugocarlistas,<ref>Carlos Hugo and his supporters from the onset – though only among themselves - considered Tejada a rotten reactionary, admitting that only the fuerista thread in his writings was worth considering, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 412, Martorell Pérez 2014, p. 80</ref> suspecting them of pursuing a hidden agenda.<ref>though initially Tejada could have not properly identified their political profile; in 1961 he issued a warning against Christian-Democratic opusdeistas (Massó was engaged in Opus Dei), subversively active in Traditionalism, Bartyzel 2015, p. 251; for his doubts about Opus and Masso see also Vázquez de Prada 2016, pp. 121-123</ref> Co-operation deteriorated into crisis and then open conflict in the early 1960s, when Don Carlos Hugo started to sidetrack most hard-line Traditionalists. Tejada did not illude himself about Don Javier potentially confronting his progressist son,<ref>in the late 1950s Tejada had some hope in Don Javier, e.g. he addressed him with a letter, pointing that a semi-official Carlist daily ''Informaciones'' was promoting men of the Left; by that he meant Chrtistian-Democrats aligned with the Paul Lesourd; some scholars claim that the ''Informaciónes'' issues largely contributed to Tejada leaving Don Javier in the early 1960s, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 446</ref> and in July 1962<ref>Vázquez de Prada 2016, p. 175</ref> he decided to break with the Borbón-Parmas;<ref>some say that after expulsion of Zamanillo, Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 187, Bartyzel 2015, p. 265. One author claims that the key motive behind de Tejada's departure was not his suspicion of socialist, subversive leanings of Carlos Hugo, but rather suspicions that he and Don Javier became pawns of the Opus Dei, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 446</ref> some authors claim that he was expulsed.<ref>in December 1962, see Lavardin 1976, p. 145; other claim that following de Tejadas venomous press articles aimed against "monsieur Hugues de Bourbon-Busset" Masso and his entourage indeed intended to expulse de Tejada, but they do not specify whether the expulsion indeed took place, Vázquez de Prada 2016, pp. 174-175</ref> He declared to Don Carlos Hugo that he could not make him king, but could prevent him from becoming one.<ref>"yo no tengo poder para hacerle Rey de Espańa, pero puedo hacer que no lo sea", quoted after Brocos Fernández 2005; the same author underlines a personal thread, suggesting that Tejada turned against Don Carlos Hugo during gear-up to his audience with Franco; allegedly Tejada felt offended that though he was initially to accompany the prince, he was eventually replaced by Alvaro d’Ors. The same version is repeated in Lavardin 1976, p. 146; the author presents Tejada as highly extravagant and unpredictable figure. Similar, though not bold portrait presenting Tejada as "apasionamente impulsivo" in Francisco de las Heras y Borreo, ''Un pretendiente desconocido. Carlos de Habsburgo. El otro candidato de Franco'', Madrid 2004, {{ISBN|8497725565}}, pp. 41-42</ref> In 1963 Tejada already referred to Don Carlos Hugo as "este aventurero francés de sangre bastarda".<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 184. The insult is related to a long-standing controversy related to aristocratic standing of the Bourbon-Busset family, it is the family of Don Carlos Hugo's mother. According to a long-repeated version, the branch was set up by illegitimate child of [[Louis de Bourbon, Bishop of Liège]]</ref>
==Carlist: fighting the progressists (1962-1978)== [[File:Charles-Hugues de Bourbon-Parme.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Don Carlos Hugo]], 1964]] After the breakup Tejada did not join any Carlist faction, though he was reportedly sympathetic to [[Maurici de Sivatte i de Bobadilla|RENACE]]: he liked its format of depositary of Traditionalist values with no support for any specific claimant.<ref>José Fermín Garralda Arizcun, ''Miguel Ayuso Torres, La filosofía jurídica y política de Francisco Elías de Tejada'' [review], [in:] Verbo 5 (1995), p. 197, Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo. Dos siglos de contrarrevolución en España'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788420639475}}, p. 365</ref> He embarked on building a network of institutions marketing orthodox Traditionalism. In 1963 he co-founded the Madrid-based Centro de Estudios Históricos y Políticos General Zumalacárregui;<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 176, Vallverdú i Martí 2014, p. 230</ref> though officially affiliated with Secretariado General de Movimiento Nacional,<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, ''Tradycjonalizm a dyktatura. Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola wobec frankizmu'', [in:] ''Legitymizm'' service</ref> it was intended as a Carlist think-tank.<ref>''El profesor Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spinola'', [in:] ''Fundación Elias de Tejada'' service, available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/ here], Ayuso 2008, p. 20</ref> Its activity climaxed in two Congresos de Estudios Tradicionalistas, staged in 1964 and 1968;<ref>''El profesor Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spinola'', [in:] ''Fundación Elias de Tejada'' service, Ayuso 2008, p. 20, Brocos Fernández 2005, Jacek Bartyzel, ''Tradycjonalizm a dyktatura. Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola wobec frankizmu'', [in:] ''Legitymizm'' service</ref> Centro issued also periodicals and organized so-called Jornadas Forales across the country.<ref>Bartyzel 2015, p. 265</ref>
In the first half of the 1960s Tejada emerged as chief ideologue of [[Juntas de Defensa del Carlismo]], network mushrooming across the country and united by opposition to hugocarlismo;<ref>Vallverdú i Martí 2014, p. 172, Canal 2000, p. 364, Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 176</ref> he also contributed to launch of a new periodical, ''Siempre''.<ref>Vallverdú i Martí 2014, p. 173</ref> In mid-1960s Tejada was firmly established among leaders of loosely organized<ref>Canal 2000, p. 382</ref> followers of orthodox Traditionalism;<ref>Canal 2000, p. 373</ref> his activity was increasingly leaning towards vague dynastical compromise,<ref>sort of a new "compromiso de Caspe", Bartyzel 2015, p. 266</ref> intended to block the Borbón-Parmas;<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 181</ref> this strategy led him close to Carloctavistas and [[Maurici de Sivatte i de Bobadilla|Sivattistas]].<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 185</ref> In 1966 he supported [[Spanish organic law referendum, 1966|referendum on Ley Organica]], considering it a stepping stone towards a Traditionalist ideal;<ref>and closing the door on French constitutionalism, Santa Cruz 1989, pp. 119-124, 274-284, referred after Bartyzel 2015, p. 267</ref> despite this, some scholars dub him "isolated anti-regime sniper".<ref>Carrillo-Linares 2008, p. 50</ref> In 1968 Franco, always keen to exploit differences, received Tejada to discuss the monarchical question; during their only personal meeting,<ref>though Tejada also met the dictator during larger receptions, e.g. on February 22, 1961, when Franco received Junta Nacional of Circulos Culturales Vazquez de Mella, Lavardin 1976, p. 93</ref> the dictator was treated to legitimist discourse reverting to the Braganza solution.<ref>"lo que como carlista y como jurista sostengo, tuve el honor de exponerlo de palabra a S.E. el Jefé del Estado el 20 marzo de 1968, única ocasión en que mereci hablar a solo con S.E. Puesto que entonces lo razoné ante tan altísima autoridad, no voy a repetir aquá mi tesis de que jurídicamente la legitimidad española paréceme ir per S.M. el señor duque de Braganza y sus descendientes", ''El Pensamiento Navarro'' 01.03.73, quoted after Heras y Borreo 2004, p. 42, also Bartyzel 2015, p. 266</ref>
The turn of the decades spelled a political disaster for Tejada: the [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Alfonsist pretender]] was nominated as the future king and Carlism was firmly taken over by the hugocarlistas.
