On the official front, in 1972 he was trialed for anti-government remarks.<ref>stating that "autoridad que se aparta de la ley no merece consideración de autoridad", Vallejo 2015</ref> On the Carlist front, his 1971 last-minute doctrinal summary, ''¿Qué es el carlismo?'',<ref>published jointly with Rafael Gambra and Francisco Puy Muñoz, full digital version available [http://www.carlismo.es/librosElectronicos/queeselcarlismo.pdf here]</ref> made the Traditionalist position crystal clear, but failed to prevent transformation of Javierismo into the socialist-dominated [[Partido Carlista]].<ref>Bartyzel 2015, p. 265</ref> During last years of Francoism he witnessed and indeed contributed to increasing decomposition of Traditionalism. In 1972 he was skeptical about launching an anti-hugocarlista organization on the [[Requeté]] basis<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, pp. 231-2, the organization materialized as Hermandad de Maestrazgo</ref> and ridiculed its leaders,<ref>Tejada mocked Ramón Forcadell as "ridiculo tigre", an ironic reference to Cabrera as "Tigre de Maestrazgo", Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 236</ref> attracting some criticism in return.<ref>some Traditionalists did not like Tejada as the one who "sabe tirar la piedra y esconder la mano", a reference to him not appearing at a meeting intended to launch organization which later materialized as Hermandad de Maestrazgo</ref> However, he engaged in another anti-hugocarlista initiative, Real Tercio de Requetés de Castilla, and neared the youngest of the Borbón-Parmas, [[Sixtus of Bourbon-Parma|Don Sixto]], considered even his intellectual mentor.<ref>opinion of Fal Conde, Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 271</ref> In 1975 he accepted Don Sixto as royal leader, though neither as a claimant nor regent but as a vaguely styled "abanderado de la Tradición".<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 271</ref> [[File:ToledoElecciones15Jun77.jpg|thumbnail|[[Spanish general election, 1977|elections in Spain, 1977]]]] In bitter public skirmishes with partisans of Partido Carlista,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 05.10.76, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1976/11/02/pagina-34/33620510/pdf.html here], also ''La Vanguardia'' 24.09.76, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1976/11/02/pagina-24/33617522/pdf.html here]</ref> following death of Franco Tejada attempted to build a new Carlist organization, born in 1977 as Comunión Católico-Monárquica-Legitimista.<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, ''Elías de Tejada y Spinola Francisco'', [in:] ''legitymizm service'', available [http://www.legitymizm.org/pef-elias-de-tejada-y-spinola here]; according to other authors the name of the party was Comunión Católico-Monárquica, Canal 2000, p. 393. In 1986 it merged into Comunión Tradicionalista Carlista, César Alcalá, ''D. Mauricio de Sivatte. Una biografía política (1901-1980)'', Barcelona 2001, {{ISBN|8493109797}}, p. 191</ref> During the [[Spanish general election, 1977|electoral campaign]] it joined forces<ref>pre-agreed with Don Sixto, Brocos Fernández 2005</ref> with [[Spanish National Union|Unión Nacional Española]] and [[Fuerza Nueva]] in [[:es:Alianza Nacional del 18 de Julio|Alianza Nacional 18 de Julio]]; Tejada was scheduled to run from the Seville<ref>some sources claim he was to run from Huelva, ''La Vanguardia'' 10.05.77, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1984/10/04/pagina-16/33747023/pdf.html here]</ref> list for the [[Senate (Spain)|Senate]].<ref>Bartyzel 2015, p. 268</ref> When leaders of the alliance declared themselves faithful to the thought of Franco he replied in public that Franco was the greatest ever enemy of Carlism<ref>Ayuso 1994, p. 339</ref> and withdrew.<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> In one of his last interviews he expressed anxiety about forthcoming partidocracia.<ref>''ABC'' 27.07.77, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/blanco.y.negro/1977/07/27/067.html here]</ref>
==Reception and legacy== [[File:ULL.19.84.11.jpg|thumbnail|left|Fundación Elías de Tejada logo]] In the post-war Spain Tejada gained prominence principally as a theorist of law; present day scholars either suggest that Francoist setting provided a favorable background for domination of iusnaturalismo against other schools,<ref>"it would clearly be an overstatement to sustain that the political regime established in Spain by Franco after the Civil War pretended to support a “revival” of the Spanish Natural Law Classics. It is obvious that the so-called Movimiento Nacional (National Movement) had to address more urgent issues, culture not being among their primary concerns. Nevertheless, peculiar circumstances explain a favourable context for an invocation and manipulation of the Salamanca School as it had never been known before", Pérez Luño 2013, pp. 7-8</ref> or bluntly claim that Neoescolástica was the regime’s means of auto-legitimization,<ref>by claiming that freedom is "una opción subjetiva entre premisas puestas objetivamente por Dios para cada caso concreto" it presented the Francoist regime and its limitations as determined by supreme order, Josefa Dolores Ruiz Resa, ''Los derechos de los trabajadores en el franquismo'', Madrid 2015, {{ISBN|9788490852064}}, p. 436</ref> enforced and disguised as "pluralism".<ref>the only systems allowed were Neoescolástica, pursuing a dogmatic Catholic line, and Existentialism, which might or might have not contained a Catholic thread, Ruiz Resa 2015, p. 415</ref> His writings on history of political thought were appreciated if could have been presented as picturing the regime as ultimate climax of Hispanic tradition, while Traditionalist theory of politics – acceptable in the 1950s – when assuming a decisively Carlist flavor was clearly unwelcome in the 1970s.<ref>e.g. in 1972 Tejada was trialed for arguing that "autoridad que se aparta de la ley no merece consideración de autoridad", Vallejo 2015</ref>
During and after the [[Spanish transition to democracy|Second Restoration]]<ref>Tejada preferred this name to "transición", Ferrnandez de la Mora 1989, p. 7</ref> Tejada's opus went dramatically out of fashion; already by the end of his life he was invoked in the press as a ridiculous fanatic who did not even merit a response,<ref>see the letter of Juan Cabre Cires, ''La Vanguardia'' 05.10.76, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1976/11/02/pagina-34/33620510/pdf.html here]</ref> while later – among occasional courteous references<ref>''ABC'' 20.04.84, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1982/04/20/044.html here]</ref> – he was venomously denounced as "distinguida personalidad del franquismo".<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 06.06.97, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1995/05/06/pagina-45/34635826/pdf.html here]</ref> In 1986 Gabriella Pèrcopo co-founded Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada,<ref>''Quiénes somos'', [in:] ''Fundación Elías de Tejada'' service, available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/quienes-somos/la-fundacion/ here]</ref> which pays tribute<ref>by means of reprinting his works, publishing related books, issuing annuals and irregularly conferring Premio Francisco Elías de Tejada, awarded e.g. to Estanislao Cantero, ''Francisco José Fernández de la Cigoña, Antonio de Capmany (1742-1812). Pensamiento, obra histórica, política y jurídica'', Madrid 1993, {{ISBN|8460483843}}, José Joaquín Jerez, ''Pensamiento político y reforma institucional durante la guerra de las Comunidades de Castilla'', Madrid 2007, {{ISBN|9788497684156}}</ref> to his thought<ref>it hails him as one of key Spanish political and law theorists of the second half of the 20th century, see ''El profesor Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spinola'', [in:] ''Fundación Elias de Tejada'' service</ref> by promoting Hispanic studies.<ref>"promover el estudio y la difusión del pensamiento católico hispánico anterior a 1800 y asimismo promover la investigación histórico-literaria en el campo de los autores hispánicos, en el sentido amplio que comprende los integrados en la Confederación hispánica de los siglos XVI, XVII y XVIII, respetando las directrices del profesor Francisco Elías de Tejada"</ref> Two institutions he set up, Centro Zumalacárregui<ref>compare Centro Zumalacarregui website, available [https://centrodeestudiosgeneralzumalacarregui.wordpress.com/centro-de-estudios-general-zumalacarregui/ here]</ref> and Asociación "Felipe II",<ref>the institution evolved into Consejo de Estudios Hispanicos „Felipé II”, currently presided by Miguel Ayuso under patronage of Don Sixto de Borbón, see its website available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/que-hacemos/consejofelipeii/ here]. It staged Jornadas Hispánicas de Derecho Natural, organised 3 times since Tejadas death, compare [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/que-hacemos/consejofelipeii/jornadas-hispanicas-de-derecho-natural/ here]</ref> are active until today, organizing conferences and issuing own publications;<ref>compare program of the conference titled ''Maestros del tradicionalismo hispánico de la segunda mitad del siglo XX'', available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/PROGRAMA-MAESTROS-DEL-TRADICIONALISMO.pdf here], a congress celebrating 175th anniversary of Carlism, available [https://consejofelipesegundo.wordpress.com/2008/09/28/celebrado-congreso-175%C2%BA-aniversario-carlismo/ here] or ''Annales'', most of them available online [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/que-publicamos/anales-de-la-fundacion-elias-de-tejada/ here]</ref> some of these initiatives are supported financially<ref>setting up the Foundation appears to be part of a deal with RACMYP, Ramírez Jerez 2013, p. 209, also Fernandez de la Mora 1989, p. 13</ref> by Ministry of Education<ref>see ''BOE'' 159 (2008), available [http://fundacioneliasdetejada.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/VI-PREMIO.pdf here]</ref> and [[:es:Real Academia de Ciencias Morales y Políticas|Real Academia de Ciencias Morales y Políticas]].<ref>''VII Premio Francisco Elías de Tejada'', [in:] ''RACMYP Noticias'' 18.07.13, available [http://www.racmyp.es/prensa/noticia.cfm?id=56 here]</ref> RACMYP holds also a massive<ref>his bibliophilia was bordering bibliomania: Tejada accumulated one of the largest private libraries in Spain, consisting of some 60,000 volumes, Goytisolo 1981, p. 107. It included some rarities from the 16th century, Ramírez Jerez 2013, pp. 210-211</ref> Tejada's library.<ref>the part handed over to RACMYP consisted of 24,000 books, Ramírez 2013, p. 210. In principle RACMYP accepts only full donations; as Tejada's widow was unwilling to cede ownership, it took complex negotiations to get the deal closed, Ramírez Jerez 2013, pp. 207-210</ref>
Already in 1977 Tejada lamented that Spanish universities were becoming mimetic replicas of the European ones;<ref>he noted that "nuestra universidad es la que corresponde a unas gentes que han perdido su identidad de patria", ''ABC'' 27.07.77, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/blanco.y.negro/1977/07/27/067.html here]</ref> some claim that indeed, in the 1980s and 1990s Traditionalism as scientific school was almost entirely eradicated from Spanish academic realm,<ref>Garralda Arizcun 1995, p. 198</ref> though they also point to a number of active scholars<ref>brief list of PhD hopefuls he supervised in Salamanca and currently active in José Barrientos García, ''Francisco de Vitoria y la facultad de teología de la Universidad de Salamanca'', [in:] Vinvent S. Olmos (ed.), ''Aulas y saberes: 6 Congreso Internacional de Historia de las Universidades Hispánicas'', Valencia 2003, {{ISBN|9788437056852}}, p. 215</ref> who might be considered either Tejada's disciples<ref>those counted in are Francisco Puy Muñoz, Nicolás María López Calera, Emilio Serrano Villfañe, Jaime Brufau Prats, Mariano Hurrado Bautista, Vladimiro Lamsdorff-Galagne, Manuel Fernández-Escalante, José F. Lorca Navarrete, Pablo Badillo O’Farrell, José Iturmendi Morales, Antonio Enrique Pérez-Luño, Gustavo Villapalos Salas, José Delgado Pinto, Alberto Montoro Ballesteros, Ramón Maciá Manso, Carolina Rovira Florez de Quiñones and Juan Antonio Sardina Páramo, Ayuso 1997, p. 16. Monographic work on him listed 727 persons related one way or another, Garralda Arizcun 1995, p. 193</ref> or heavily influenced by his thought.<ref>key names are Álvaro d´Ors, Juan Vallet de Goytisolo, Osvaldo Lira, and José Pedro Galvão de Sousa, ''El profesor Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spinola'', [in:] ''Fundación Elias de Tejada'' service</ref> Beyond the Hispanic and Lusitanian realm it hardly made an impact, though there are exceptions.<ref>[[Frederick D. Wilhelmsen]] and Alexandra Wilhelmsen in the United States and [[:pl:Jacek Bartyzel|Jacek Bartyzel]] in Poland</ref> Bibliography on Elías is nearing a hundred titles. The key one is a monograph by [[:es:Miguel Ayuso|Miguel Ayuso]] (1994);<ref>Miguel Ayuso Torres, ''La filosofía jurídica y política de Francisco Elías de Tejada'', Madrid 1994, {{ISBN|9788460495727}}; by some reviewers the book is considered "la obra definitiva sobre la obra de Francisco Elías de Tejada", Cristián Garay Vera, ''Miguel Ayuso Torres, La filosofía jurídica y política de Francisco Elías de Tejada'' [review], [in:] ''Revista chilena de derecho'' 21/1 (1994), p. 210; other reviewers, though also enthusiastic remain a bit more restrained, praising "elevado valor científico", Cuenca Toribio 1994, p. 375 or claiming that "la investigadón que el dr. Ayuso nos presenta es digna de aplauso", Garralda Arizcun 1995, p. 200</ref> apart from three other volumes,<ref>a bibliography - Consuelo Caballero Baruque, ''Francisco Elias de Tejada: bibliografia'', Perugia 1984, and two joint works, ''Francisco Elías de Tejada (1917-1977 [sic!]). El hombre y la Obra'', Madrid 1989; and Angel Sanchez de la Torre (ed.), ''Francisco Elias de Tejada. Figura y pensamiento'', Madrid 1995, {{ISBN|8486926890}}</ref> the remaining titles are articles fathered mostly by his followers and published in specialized reviews.<ref>by, among others, Julieta Amaro Marques, Miguel Ayuso Torres, Pablo Badillo O’Farrel, Jacek Bartyzel, Consuelo Caballero Baruque, Estanislao Cantero Núñez, Daniela Capaccio, Samuele Cecotti, Julio Cienfuegos Linares, José Manuel Cuenca Toribio, Gonzalo Díaz Díaz, Idoia Estornes Zubizarreta, Giovanni Ferracuti, Manuel Fernández de Escalante, Rafael Gambra, Francesco M. Di Giovine, Mariano Hurtado Bautista, Vladimir Lamsdorff Galagane, Roberto de Mattei, José Francisco Lorca Navarette, Consuelo Martínez-Siduna y Sepúlveda, Diego Medina Morales, Bernardino Montejano, Evaristo Palomar Maldonado, Francisco Puy, Pablo Ramírez Jerez, Raúl Sánchez Abelenda, Angel Sanchez de la Torre, Juan Antonio Sardina Páramo, Rudolf Steineke, Emilio Suñe Llinas, Giovanni Turco, Jesús Vallejo, Juan Vallet de Goytisolo, Piero Vassallo, Silvio Vitale, Pier Francesco Zarcone and Enrique Zuleta Puceiro</ref> The 2008 anniversary of Tejada's death produced a few memorial articles ranging from Chile<ref>Luis R. Oro Tapia, ''Elías de Tejada, Francisco (2008): Derecho político'' [review], [in:] ''Revista chilena de derecho'' 36 (2009), pp. 669-670</ref> to [[Poland]].<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, ''Franciszek Elías de Tejada y Spínola – hidalgo, filozof, karlista. W 30. rocznicę śmierci'', [in:] ''Najwyższy Czas!'' 14 (2008), pp. XXXV-XXXVI</ref> [[File:ULL.17.13.99.jpg|thumbnail|260px|CdEH "Felipé II" logo]] General assessment of Tejada's scholarly standing seems far from agreed. Some point to his massive production<ref>at times published in distant places, mostly in Latin America, Ayuso 1997, p. 15, Ayuso 1994, p. 40, Ayuso 1997, pp. 15-16; apart from Italian, few translations were recorded</ref> and suggest that having been among greatest intellectuals of his time<ref>"one of the leading figures of university and cultural life of Spain in the 20th century" - Cuenca Toribio 1994, p. 375, "más preclara inteligencia de la Filosofía española del Derecho en este siglo, y una de las cumbres del pensamiento iusfilosóficq en toda la historia de la península" - Gonzalo Ibáñez Santamaría, ''El Mercurio dé Santiago de Chile'' 02.04.78, quoted after Goytisolo 1981, p. 105, "una de las figuras más eminentes del iusnaturalismo europeo del pasado siglo" - Vázquez de Prada 2011, p. 395, great humanist, moving spirit of an entire school, mecenas and inspirator - Garralda Arizcun 1995, p. 198</ref> he led a school of his own,<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 16</ref> building a holistic "sistema tejadiano"<ref>Cecotti 2005, p. 205</ref> or "pensamiento tejadiano".<ref>Fernandez de la Cigoña 1996,p. 190</ref> Others consider him either mostly a law theorist<ref>Fernandez de la Cigoña 1996, p. 188</ref> or mostly a student of Hispanidad.<ref>Cantero 1996, p. 147</ref> His followers point also to his charming personality<ref>according to Gambra he was a combination of Athene and Dionisos, referred after Bartyzel 2015, p. 241. The list of his features includes "descuidado, bohemio, torrencial, extrovertido, abierto, vehemente, generoso, inexorable, radical, noble, agresivo, despreocupado, alegre, religioso, creyente, austero, enciclopédico, cáustico, atrabiliario, original, fogoso, ingenuo, portentoso viajero, polígloto asombroso, involvidable narrador, magnánimo, dispuesto, apasionado, cordial, vital, español, terco, infatigable trabajdor, intransigente, talentoso, bondadoso por encima de las cóleras y de un cieto humor grueso, limpio de ánimo, estudioso, curioso, sensible, agudo, firme, indoblegable, patriota. En resumen, un monstruo, un genio, un superman", Ayuso 1997, p. 15, similar comments in Fernandez de la Mora 1989, pp. 7-8, Goytisolo 1981, p. 107. His only addictions were travelling - ''El profesor Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spinola'', [in:] ''Fundación Elias de Tejada'' service – and languages, as Tejada mastered 12 tongues and learnt to some extent further 26, Bartyzel 2015, p. 243</ref> and acknowledging massive erudition, call him a genius monster.<ref>Ayuso 1997, p. 15</ref> Others suggest that he was a little-minded, vindictive,<ref>the point advanced by Eusebio Fernández García, ''Las tareas y la Filosofía del Derecho de Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola'', [in:] Adela Mora Cañada (ed.), ''La enseñanza del derecho en el siglo XX'', Madrid 2004, {{ISBN|849772318X}}, pp. 192-205; the author presents Tejada as biased servant of the regime, persecuting his own colleagues; "una de las personas que fueron víctimas de la persecución de Francisco Elías de Tejada fue Elías Díaz" (pp. 194-5), the opinion based on Elías Díaz, ''Un itinerario intelectual de filosofía jurídica y política'', Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|9788497421485}}, pp. 34-35</ref> impossible to deal with bigot of an overgrown ego,<ref>Vallejo 2015</ref> his career enabled by anti-democratic nature of the Francoist regime,<ref>Ruiz Resa 2015, pp. 415, 436; Anna Caballé, Arcadi Espada, ''Entrevista a Alonso de los Rios'', [in:] ''Boletin de la Unidad de Estudios Biograficos'' 3 (1998), p. 78</ref> dubbed "reaccionario"<ref>"autor reaccionario" - Antoni Jutglar, ''Introducción al "Manifiesto del Partido Comunista", y otros escritos'', Madrid 1984, {{ISBN|9788485887460}}, p. 93, "pensamiento reaccionario" - Ramón Cotarelo, ''Las ciencias sociales en España: historia inmediata, crítica y perspectivas'', Madrid 1992, {{ISBN|9788474914887}}, p. 89</ref> and the passion of his life, "tradición española", referred to as "ni es tradición ni es española".<ref>Manuel-Reyes Mate Rupérez, ''Pensamientos a media luz'', [in:] ''El País'' 16.07.88</ref> In the compromise version, he is either presented as notable but second-rate representative of Traditionalism<ref>González Cuevas 2008, pp. 1171-1172</ref> or as an erudite eminent for some of his case studies.<ref>Díaz Díaz 1998, p. 22</ref>

Scott Hubbard''' is an adjunct professor at [[Stanford University]] in the department of aeronautics and astronautics and has been engaged in space-related research as well as program, project and executive management for more than 40 years including 20 years with [[NASA]], culminating as director of NASA’s [[Ames Research Center]]. Currently, Scott Hubbard chairs [[SpaceX]] Safety Advisory Panel,[http://www.socaltech.com/spacex_aiming_at_carrying_nasa_crews_names_safety_panel/s-0041825.html SpaceX, Aiming At Carrying NASA Crews, Names Safety Panel], SocCalTech.com website, March 29, 2012. he previously served as the NASA representative on the [[Columbia Accident Investigation Board]], was NASA’s first [[Mars]] program director and restructured the Mars program in the wake of mission failures.[http://www.nasa.gov/offices/nac/members/hubbard-bio.html#.U8KrirHCeM0 Dr. G. Scott Hubbard] (biography), NASA, NAC Science Committee, updated to April 4, 2014. Retrieved July 13, 2014. He is the founder of [[NASA Astrobiology Institute|NASA’s Astrobiology Institute]]; conceived the [[Mars Pathfinder]] mission with its airbag landing and was the manager for NASA’s [[Lunar Prospector]] Mission. Prior to joining NASA, Hubbard led a small start-up high technology company in the San Francisco Bay Area and was a staff scientist at the [[Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory]]. Hubbard has received honors including NASA’s highest award, the [[NASA Distinguished Service Medal|Distinguished Service Medal]].[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2012/02/28/DD5B1ND4N4.DTL '' 'Exploring Mars','' by Scott Hubbard] (book review), ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' website, February 29, 2012. In 2014 Hubbard also held the office of Sentinel Program Architect at the [[B612 Foundation]], dedicated to protecting the Earth from [[Impact event|asteroid strikes]] and led mainly by scientists, former astronauts and engineers from the [[Institute for Advanced Study]], the [[Southwest Research Institute]], NASA and the [[space industry]]. Hubbard holds a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree from [[Vanderbilt University]] and a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] degree from [[University of California, Berkeley]].{{Cite news|url=https://news.vanderbilt.edu/2018/10/10/six-alumni-join-vanderbilt-student-media-hall-of-fame-in-2018/|title=Six alumni join Vanderbilt Student Media Hall of Fame in 2018|work=Vanderbilt University|access-date=2018-10-10|language=en}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|G. '''Harvey Bialy''' (born 1945, New York City) is an American [[molecular biology|molecular biologist]] and [[AIDS denialist]]. He was one of the signatories to a [[letter to the editor]] by a group of AIDS sceptics calling themselves the Group for the Scientific Reappraisal of the HIV-AIDS Hypothesis.<ref>Epstein, Steven. ''Impure Science'', University of California Press, 1996. pp 143-144.</ref> He was also a member of the controversial and heavily criticized South African Presidential AIDS Advisory Panel convened by [[Thabo Mbeki]] in 2000.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.villagevoice.com/news/0027,schoofs2,16283,1.html | title = Debating the Obvious: Inside the South African Government's Controversial AIDS Panel | first= Mark |last = Schoof | work = [[Village Voice]] | date = July 5–11, 2000 | accessdate= April 6, 2007}}</ref>
Bialy is the author of ''Oncogenes, Aneuploidy, and AIDS: A Scientific Life and Times of Peter H. Duesberg'' (2004).
==Education and early career== Bialy graduated from [[Bard College]] in 1966 and was awarded a Ph.D. in [[molecular biology]] in 1970 by the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. He joined the journal ''[[Nature Biotechnology]]'' (part of the [[Nature Publishing Group|''Nature'' family of publications]]) as its scientific editor in 1984,<ref>''[[Nature Biotechnology]]'' '''2''', p. 109 (01 Feb 1984).</ref> and edited its peer-reviewed content from 1984–1996.
==Publications== He has co-authored papers in [[molecular genetics]], including articles presenting evidence that [[phage]] [[gene]]s can subvert [[host (biology)|host]] functions.<ref name="Lindahl">{{cite journal | doi=10.1073/pnas.66.3.587 |vauthors=Lindahl G, Sironi G, Bialy H, Calendar R | title=Bacteriophage Lambda; Abortive Infection of Bacteria Lysogenic for Phage P2 | journal=PNAS | year=1970 | pages=587–94 | volume=66 | issue=3 | pmid=4913204 | pmc=283090}}</ref><ref name="Sironi">{{cite journal | doi=10.1016/0042-6822(71)90040-7 |vauthors=Sironi G, Bialy H, Lorenzon HA, Calendar R | title=Bacteriophage P2:interaction with phage lambda and with recombination-deficient bacteria | journal=Virology | year=1971 | pages=387–96 | volume=46 | issue=2 | pmid=4943192}}</ref> He has also written numerous editorials and commentaries on contemporary issues in biotechnology in Nature Biotechnology and other journals.<ref name="Curriculum Vitae">Bialy, Harvey. [http://www.harveybialy.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/cv.pdf Curriculum Vitae]. Accessed 16 November 2009.</ref>
He is the author of ''Oncogenes, Aneuploidy, and AIDS'' ({{ISBN|1556435312}}), a book about the scientific life of fellow molecular biologist and AIDS sceptic [[Peter Duesberg]], with special emphasis on Duesberg's version of the [[aneuploidy]] theory of cancer, on Duesberg's HIV/AIDS scepticism, and on the politics of modern science.
==Later career== Bialy's CV indicates that he was the co-recipient of a grant from the Charles Merill Trust to study [[antibiotic resistance|antibiotic resistant]] pathogens in Nigeria in 1978. He received a [[World Health Organization]] grant to study the [[epidemiology]] and genetics of antibiotic resistant enteric pathogens in Nigeria in 1982. He worked as a visiting researcher or research fellow at several universities in the United States and Africa throughout the 1980s and 1990s. He was advisor to the Center for Biotechnology and Genetic Engineering in Havana, Cuba from 1986–1996.<ref name="Curriculum Vitae"/>
Bialy's CV also indicates that he was a resident scholar of the IBT at UNAM in [[Cuernavaca]] between 1996 and 2006,<ref name="Curriculum Vitae"/> where he also founded and directed the Virtual Library of Biotechnology for the Americas.<ref>[http://biblioteca.ibt.unam.mx/vcba/index.php Virtual Library of Biotechnology for the Americas] homepage, accessed October 6, 2009.</ref>
In April 2006, [[Ordo Templi Orientis]] formed the International OTO Cabinet, an advisory, non-voting panel made up of both OTO Initiates and Non-Initiates. Along with [[David Tibet]], Bialy was named among the initial non-member appointments.<ref>[http://www.oto.org/news0806.html OTO International Cabinet appointments]. Published August 31, 2006. Last accessed June 2012.</ref>
==Artistic life== He is also a poet<ref>Lopez, Richard. [http://jacketmagazine.com/25/lopez-beck.html "Unprotected Text: Tom Beckett in Conversation with Richard Lopez"], ''Jacket Magazine'', Issue 25, February 2004.</ref> and artist.<ref>[http://www.harveybialy.org Bialy's website featuring his artwork], accessed 16 November 2009.</ref> He has published several books of poetry,<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_ss?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=harvey+bialy&x=0&y=0 Amazon.com search results for "Harvey Bialy"], accessed November 3, 2009.</ref> and in 1976, he received a fellowship in poetry from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]].<ref name="Curriculum Vitae"/> Since May 2007, he has devoted his time to his art, of which an exposition "Telestics ... The Art of the Ordinary" was presented 23–31 August 2007 at the Catedral de Cuernavaca. The painter Rafael Cauduro admired Bialy's work and spoke in its praise for several minutes at the inauguration ceremony, which was also attended by the Minister of Culture of the [[Morelos|State of Morelos]].<ref>''El Sol de Cuernavaca'', 28 August 2007</ref> More recently, in February through April 2012, Bialy's work was featured at the Nalanda Gallery of [[Naropa University]].<ref>[http://www.93current.de/aggregator?page=157 "Harvey Bialy: To the Memory of Harry Smith"], ''The 93 Current: A Thelemic Resource Page'', February 10, 2012</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2013}} The '''Indian spin quartet''' is the collective name given to the [[India national cricket team|Indian]] [[spin bowler]]s of the 1960s and 1970s: [[E. A. S. Prasanna|Erapalli Prasanna]] and [[Srinivas Venkataraghavan]] (both [[off spin]]ners), [[Bhagwat Chandrasekhar]] (a [[leg spin]]ner), and [[Bishen Singh Bedi]] (a [[left-arm orthodox spin|left-arm spinner]]). Between them, they played 231 [[Test cricket|Test matches]], taking 853 wickets. They were one of the most deadly combinations in world cricket, especially on the dusty subcontinental pitches.
The spin quartet was instrumental in producing many Indian [[Test cricket|Test]] victories. There was only one match in which all four of them were in the starting XI: usually one of the off spinners, Prasanna or Venkataraghavan, was left out. However, these four men made important contributions to some of India's greatest triumphs, including Test series victories in the West Indies and [[England cricket team|England]], as well as Test victories in [[Australian cricket team|Australia]] and [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]].
In 2004, the [[Board of Control for Cricket in India]] conferred on them the [[CK Nayudu]] award, named after India's first Test captain.
==Beginnings== By the 1966-67 season, the interest in cricket in India had risen to unprecedented levels. Despite being beaten by the West Indies at home, the Indian team's spirits were not dampened. The captain [[Nawab of Pataudi, jun|Nawab of Pataudi]] thought that it would be a good idea to introduce more quality spinners into the team in order to compensate for the absence of good new-ball bowlers in the country.<ref>The birth of a spin quartet, ESPNCricinfo: http://www.espncricinfo.com/india/content/story/122156.html</ref> Bhagwat Chandrasekhar, the leg spinner, had already established his place in the team with solid performances against Australia and the West Indies. Erapalli Prasanna was making him comeback having been out of the team for five years, while both Venkatarghavan and Bedi played in the series against West Indies. All four of them played their first (and only game together) against England at Birmingham in the summer of 1967.<ref>Scorecard, 3rd Test, India vs England, Birmingham, 1967: http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/63006.html</ref> Prasanna and Chandrasekhar impressed in that game, claiming 7 and 6 wickets respectively, and all four bowlers bowled a tight line. Even though these four bowlers continued to play for 11 more years, this remained the only Test where all of them featured in the Indian test XI.
==Successes== Over the years, the spin quartet played vital roles in several memorable victories for the Indian team, starting with an overseas series win against New Zealand in 1967-68. Some of the major Test successes spin quartet were a part, are as follows * [[Indian cricket team in New Zealand in 1967–68|Away series victory against New Zealand, 1967-68]] * [[Indian cricket team in West Indies in 1970–71|Away series victory against West Indies, 1970-71]] * [[Indian cricket team in England in 1971|Away series victory against England, 1971]] * [[English cricket team in India in 1972–73|Home series victory against England, 1972-73]] * [[New Zealand cricket team in India in 1976–77|Home series victory against New Zealand, 1976-77]] * [[West Indian cricket team in India and Sri Lanka in 1978–79|Home series victory against West Indies, 1978–79]] * [[Australian cricket team in India in 1979-80|Home series victory against Australia, 1979-80]] * [[Pakistani cricket team in India in 1979-80|Home series victory against Pakistan, 1979-80]] * [[Indian cricket team in Australia in 1980–81|Drawn away series against Australia, 1980-81]] * [[English cricket team in India in 1981-82|Home series victory against England, 1981-82]] Out of the four, only Venkataraghavan and Bedi played regular one-day cricket for India. Prasanna never played [[One Day International|ODIs]], and Chandrasekhar played just one game, against New Zealand in 1976. Bedi and Venkatarghavan played in 10 ODIs together, which included the World Cups of [[1975 Cricket World Cup|1975]] and [[1979 Cricket World Cup|1979]].
==Statistics== The spin quartet played a combined 231 Tests for India from 1962 to 1983, and grabbed 853 wickets, with 43 five-wicket inning hauls.<ref>Hall of Fame- The Spin Quartet, Indian Cricket Fever: http://www.cricketnetwork.co.uk/main/s119/st25857.php</ref> Much of this success can be attributed to the different bowling styles these bowlers possessed. Bedi was an orthodox left arm-spinner, while Chandrasekhar an attacking leg-break bowler whereas Prasanna and Venkataraghavan were both off-spinners. This way, they could target all kinds of batsmen in the opposition and give their captains plenty of options. It was Chandrasekhar and Bedi who were the leaders of the attack. The two played 42 Tests alongside each other and had almost similar figures, of 184 wickets each. Bedi averaged 27.22, while Chandra averaged 28.70 in these games.<ref>Bowling records, Test matches- Bishen Bedi and Bhagwat Chandrasekhar: http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=1;filter=advanced;orderby=wickets;player_involve=1219;player_involve=1290;player_involve_type=all;template=results;type=bowling</ref>

[[Engineer's degree|Ing]] '''Jaroslav Mareš''' (born 28 December 1937 in [[Brno]], [[Czechoslovakia]]) is a Czech [[biologist]], [[wiktionary:traveller|traveller]] and [[writer]].
He graduated from The University of Economics in [[Prague]], getting a degree of Ing (he studied international business). He worked for [[Czech Airlines|ČSA]] in [[Iran]] and later in [[Canada]]. He has visited 85 countries and organised several expeditions for research of [[cryptids]], such as [[Kongamato]] (for this he was offered the membership of the [[International Society for Cryptozoology]] which he accepted), [[Nandi Bear]], [[Megalania prisca]], [[Bigfoot]], [[Yeti]], [[Nessie]], [[Ogopogo]], [[Champ (cryptozoology)|Champ]], [[Megalodon]], [[Lusca]], Ambazombi and others. In 1978 he organised an expedition to the [[tepui]] which probably inspired [[Sir Arthur Conan Doyle]] for writing [[The Lost World (Conan Doyle novel)|The Lost World]] (a book based on stories told to Doyle by [[Colonel]] [[Percy Fawcett]]).
He also studies [[dinosaur]]s (he visited most of the famous [[fossil]] sites, such as [[Nemegt Formation|Nemegt]] in [[Mongolia]], [[Tendaguru]] in [[Tanzania]], [[Red Deer, Alberta|Red Deer]] in [[Alberta]], and other localities in [[Utah]], [[Colorado]], [[Montana]] and [[Patagonia]]) and corresponds with the world-leading [[palaeontologists]]. Another field of his interest is [[shamanism]].
In 1976 he discovered and later scientifically described the world's strongest [[carnivorous]] [[beetle]], ''Manticora imperator'', of the [[tiger beetle]] group. He became a specialist in this group of beetles and later described three more [[species]].
He has published seventeen [[books]] and numerous [[magazine]] [[Article (publishing)|articles]].

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Judith Munk | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Judith Munk (April 10, 1925 –).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1925|4|10}} | birth_place = [[San Gabriel, California]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|2006|5|19|1925|4|10}} | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = United States | education = | alma_mater = [[Bennington College]] | occupation = Artist | years_active = | employer = [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]] | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- {{height|cm=}} --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|weight in kg|kg|lb}} --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = <!-- unmarried life partner; use ''Name (1950–present)'' --> | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | footnotes = }} '''Judith Munk''' (April 10, 1925 – May 19, 2006) was an American artist and designer associated with [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]]. She was inducted into the [[San Diego Women's Hall of Fame]] posthumously, in 2008.
==Early life and education== Judith Kendall Horton was born in 1925, in [[San Gabriel, California]]. Her parents were Winter Davis Horton and Edith Kendall Horton. The actor [[Edward Everett Horton]] was her uncle.<ref>"'Brazil' Booked Two Days at Geitner" ''Dunkirk Evening Observer'' (February 17, 1945): 5. via [[Newspapers.com]]{{open access}}</ref>
Horton attended [[Bennington College]] and earned degrees in art and architecture, with [[Richard Neutra]] as a mentor. She had just begun graduate studies at [[Harvard University]] School of Design when she became ill with [[poliomyelitis]], and left to recover at the home of her maternal grandmother in San Diego. She studied with sculptor [[Donal Hord]] instead of returning to Harvard.<ref name="Aguilera">Mario Aguilera, [http://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/archive/newsrel/general/jmunkobit.asp "Obituary Notice: Judith Munk, Friend and Artistic Influence"] ''UCSD News'' (May 24, 2006).</ref> She used a wheelchair for much of her adult life.<ref>Jack Williams, [http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/uniontrib/20060525/news_1m25munk.html "Judith Munk, 81, Influenced Scripps Campus Planning"] ''San Diego Union-Tribune'' (May 25, 2006).</ref>
==Career== Judith Horton worked as an illustrator and model builder at the Scripps Aquarium as a young woman.<ref>J. Baylor Roberts, [http://vintagenational.tumblr.com/post/30390966755/ektachrome-by-j-baylor-roberts-from-la-jolla "An Artist Fashions Replicas of Strange Sea Dwellers"] a photograph accompanying "La Jolla, a Gem of the California Coast" ''National Geographic'' (December 1952).</ref> After marriage, she worked mainly in sculpture and architectural design in the nearby community.<ref>Helen M. Rozwadowski, [https://books.google.com/books?id=fj0sCBGo1DEC&lpg=PA338&ots=_tHi2E0Hod&dq=Mrs.%20Munk%20Scripps&pg=PA338#v=onepage "Engineering, Imagination, and Industry: Scripps Island and Dreams for Ocean Science in the 1960s"] in Helen M. Rozwadowski and David K. Van Keuren, eds., ''The Machine in Neptune's Garden: Historical Perspectives on Technology and the Marine Environment'' (Science History Publications 2004): 338. {{ISBN|9780881353723}}</ref> She worked on several buildings on the campus of Scripps, including The Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics (IGPP, a 1962 building of redwood and glass, overlooking the ocean from cliffs), Scripps Seaside Forum, and the Scripps Crossing, a cable footbridge linking two parts of campus. She was also active in the restoration of the 1913 "Director's House."<ref>Adriane Tillman, [http://www.sdnews.com/view/full_story/299184/article-Judith-Munk--81--artist--designer "Judith Munk, 81, Artist, Designer"] ''SDNews.com'' (June 22, 2006).</ref> She was responsible for bringing a Donal Hord statue to campus, now located outside the Munk Laboratory.<ref>[https://www.sandiegohistory.org/collection/photographs/hordtour/ "Donal Hord Self-Guided Outdoor Tour"] San Diego History Center.</ref>
Working with her husband,<ref>Philip Yam, [https://books.google.com/books?id=0ox5Y6EYctQC&lpg=PA127&ots=I6HhTKll0b&dq=Judith%20Munk&pg=PA121#v=onepage&q=Judith%20Munk&f=false "The Man Who Would Hear Ocean Temperatures"] ''Scientific American'' (January 1995).</ref> she traveled to Italy, China, the Soviet Union, and American Samoa. During 1963 she and Walter lived at the village of [[Vailoatai, American Samoa|Vailoatai]] on [[Tutuila]] in American Samoa. They were both working on a documentary film, ''Waves Across the Pacific'' (1967).<ref name="Dutton2013">{{cite book|author=Lee S. Dutton|title=Anthropological Resources: A Guide to Archival, Library, and Museum Collections|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rcbIgOCqreIC&pg=PA77|date=May 13, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1-134-81893-9|page=77}}</ref> She co-founded the International Center to host guests at the [[University of California at San Diego]].<ref name="Aguilera" />
Horton also served on the La Jolla Town Council. She won a grant from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] to design an amphitheater for the town, but the project failed. She was an honorary member of the San Diego chapter of the [[American Institute of Architects]].<ref name="Aguilera" />
==Personal life== Judith Horton married oceanographer [[Walter Munk]] as his second wife, in 1953, and had two daughters, Kendall and Edie. The Munks designed their home in La Jolla, "Seiche," and frequently hosted campus social gatherings there.<ref>[http://tos.org/oceanography/assets/docs/19-3_munk.pdf "Judith Munk, 1925–2006: A Friend of Oceanography"] ''Oceanography'' 19(3)(September 2006): 9.</ref> Judith died in 2006, age 81, from pneumonia. In 2008, she was posthumously inducted into the San Diego Women's Hall of Fame.<ref>[http://womensmuseumca.org/hall-of-fame/judith-munk Judith K. Munk], San Diego Women's Hall of Fame, 2008 inductee.</ref>
The IGPP laboratory Munk helped to design was renamed for Walter and Judith Munk in 1993.<ref>Klaus Hasselmann, [https://books.google.com/books?id=L05XT9zIcvsC&lpg=PA85&ots=wXeZG9V5qk&dq=Walter%20and%20Judith%20Munk%20Laboratory&pg=PA85#v=onepage&q=Walter%20and%20Judith%20Munk%20Laboratory&f=false ''Seventy Years of Exploration in Oceanography: A Prolonged Weekend Discussion with Walter Munk''] (Spring Science and Business Media 2010): 85. {{ISBN|9783642120879}}</ref>

'''Kaikhosrov D. Irani''' (May 1, 1922 – June 29, 2017)<ref name="Obituary">[https://fezana.org/zagnys-beloved-prof-kaikhosrov-irani-passes-away/ Kaikhosrov D. Irani's obituary]</ref> was a philosopher specializing in [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] and the [[philosophy of science]]. Born in [[Mumbai|Bombay]], India, he was the eldest son of Dinshah Jijibhoy Irani and Banu Mithibai Sethna. He studied at [[Princeton University]] and was a student of [[Albert Einstein]]. He taught for 41 years in the philosophy department at [[City College of New York]], where he served as Chairman for nine years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kdirani.com/bio.htm|title=Kaikhosrov D. Irani|accessdate=January 26, 2014}}</ref> He was a member of the Academy of Science in New York, the American Philosophical Association, the Philosophy of Science Association, and the American Academy of Religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zoroastrian.org.uk/vohuman/Author/Irani,KeikhosrowDinshah.htm|title=Kaikhosrov D. Irani|publisher=A Zoroastrian Educational Institute}}</ref> He was a judge for the [[Templeton Prize]] given to individuals for "affirming life’s spiritual dimension."<ref>[http://www.templetonprize.org/judges.html The Templeton Prize]</ref> He was active in New York's [[Zoroastrian]] community.

[[File:Kudjo Affutu 2007.Foto Regula Tschumi.JPG|thumb|Kudjoe Affutu (2007)]] '''Kudjoe Affutu''' (born 1985) is a Ghanaian artist and [[Fantasy coffin|figurative coffin]] and [[Figurative palanquin|palanquin]] builder. He was born and still lives in [[Awutu Bawyiase]], [[Central Region, Ghana|Central Region]], Ghana. Affutu has made a name for himself in [[Europe]] by participating in various art projects and exhibitions.
==Biography== From 2002 to 2006, he trained with the internationally renowned coffin artist [[Paa Joe]] in the [[Greater Accra Region]]. Since 2007 he has been running his own workshop in the town of his birth, producing figurative coffins and sculptures for Ghanaian funerals, art museums and private collectors. He collaborated among others with [[Ataa Oko]], with the artist couple [[M.S. Bastian & Isabelle L.|M.S. Bastian and Isabelle L]]., with [[Saâdane Afif]] and [[Thomas Demand]].

[[File:LairdWilcox.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Laird Wilcox]] '''Laird Maurice Wilcox''' is an American researcher specializing in the study of [[political fringe movements]]. He is the founder of the "Wilcox Collection of Contemporary Political Movements,"<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://voluntaryist.com/backissues/027.pdf |title=What Is Political Extremism? |last=Wilcox |first=Laird |date=August 1987 |editor-last=Watner |editor-first=Carl |publisher=The Voluntaryists |location=Gramling, South Carolina |pages=3–4 |format=PDF |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031010144918/http://www.voluntaryist.com/articles/027a.php |archive-date=October 10, 2003 |access-date=December 2, 2016 |volume=27}}</ref> said to be one of the largest collections of American political material in the United States. It is housed in the Kenneth Spencer Research Library at the [[University of Kansas]].<ref name=freespeech>[http://spencer.lib.ku.edu/exhibits/wilcox/ Free Speech and the Wilcox Collection: Forty Years of Collecting Political Documents] Wilcox Collection of Contemporary Political Movements, Kansas Collection, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, [[University of Kansas]].</ref> Wilcox worked as carpenter, investigator and writer while living in [[Olathe, Kansas]].<ref name="NewsKU">[http://www.news.ku.edu/2005/october/12/wilcox.shtml KU News Release] article ''Wilcox Collection of political literature to celebrate 40 years at KU'' by University of Kansas published October 12, 2005.</ref>
In 1968, Wilcox signed the "[[Writers and Editors War Tax Protest]]" pledge, vowing to refuse tax payments in protest against the Vietnam War.<ref>"Writers and Editors War Tax Protest" January 30, 1968 ''New York Post''</ref>
==Wilcox Collection of Contemporary Political Movements== The Wilcox Collection of Contemporary Political Movements, in the Kansas Collection of Kenneth Spencer Research Library, [[University of Kansas]], includes coverage of "more than 10,000 individuals and organizations. The bulk of the collection covers 1960 to the present and comprises nearly 10,000 books, pamphlets and periodicals, 800 audio tapes, {{convert|73|ft|m}} of manuscript materials and more than 100,000 pieces of ephemera including flyers, brochures, mailings, clippings and bumper stickers." Wilcox continues to make regular donations.<ref>[http://spencer.lib.ku.edu/kc/wilcox.shtml University of Kansas] Wilcox Collection of Contemporary Political Movements, Kansas Collection, Kenneth Spencer Research Library, University of Kansas</ref>
The collection began in 1963-1964, when Wilcox, then a student at the University of Kansas, kept a scrapbook while he was chair of the Student Union Association Minority Opinions Forum. According to its website, the forum was very active that year, with speakers invited to discuss civil liberties, freedom of expression, [[History of South Africa in the apartheid era|apartheid]], [[communism]], the [[American Nazi Party]], and the [[Socialist Labor Party]]. In 1965, the university purchased a number of books, serials, and pamphlets from Wilcox, and the Wilcox Collection began.<ref name=freespeech/>
In 1989, Wilcox received the "Kansas City Area Archivists Award of Excellence" for his role in founding and maintaining the Wilcox Collection.<ref>[http://www.umkc.edu/kcaa/Awards/recipients.htm KCAA Award of Excellence Recipient].</ref> In 1993, he was awarded the Myers Center Award for the Study of Human Rights in the United States. In 1994, he was awarded the Freedom of Information Award of the Kansas Library Association/SIRS "For outstanding commitment to intellectual freedom."
In 1995, he received the [[Mencken Award]] of the [[Free Press Association]] "For outstanding journalism in defense of liberty."{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} In 2005, the University of Kansas honored Wilcox, then 63, in the Spencer library's North Gallery for his role in founding the collection.<ref name="NewsKU"/> He has been a member of the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] since 1961 and a member of [[Amnesty International]] since 1970.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
==Criticism of "Watchdog" groups== In his 1997 self-published book, ''The Watchdogs'',<ref name=Watchdogs>''The Watchdogs'', self-published through "Editorial Research Service," [http://www.lairdwilcox.com/publish/watchdogs.html available at lairdwilcox.com]; extensively footnoted. ({{ISBN|0-933592-89-2}})</ref> Wilcox criticized an "industry" of such groups "whose identity and livelihood depend upon growth and expansion of their particular kind of victimization." He holds such groups use "links and ties" to imply connections between individuals and groups. And they collect millions of dollars by greatly exaggerating the size and danger of such groups, becoming "a massive extortion racket."
He names groups like the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]], the [[Anti-Defamation League]], [[Political Research Associates]], and the [[Center for Democratic Renewal]]. Mark Potok of Southern Poverty Law Center told a reporter that Wilcox "had an ax to grind for a great many years" and engaged in name calling against others doing anti-racist work. [[Chip Berlet]] of Political Research Associates told a reporter that "Laird Wilcox is not an accurate or ethical reporter… He simply can't tolerate people who are his competition in this field."<ref>[[Robert Stacy McCain|McCain, Robert Stacy]]. [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-61963980.html "Researcher Says 'Watchdogs' Exaggerate Hate Group Threat"], ''[[The Washington Times]]'', May 9, 2000.</ref>
==Books== *''[[Nazis, Communists, Klansmen, and Others on the Fringe]]'', by John George (professor of political science and sociology at the University of Central Oklahoma) and Laird Wilcox, 1992. It is an examination of [[politic]]al [[extremism]] of both the [[far left]] and [[far right]] in the [[United States]].<ref>Published by [[Prometheus Books]] (Buffalo, New York) in 1992 as a 523-page hardcover ({{ISBN|0-87975-680-2}}). In 1996, Prometheus Books (Amherst, New York) republished it as the paperback ''American Extremists: Militias, Supremacists, Klansmen, Communists and Others'', (Paperback), 443 pps. ({{ISBN|1-57392-058-4}})</ref> *''Crying Wolf: Hate Crime Hoaxes in America'', 1994.<ref>http://www.fakehatecrimes.org/Crying-Wolf-by-Laird-Wilcox.pdf</ref> *''Be Reasonable: Selected Quotations for Inquiring Minds,'' by Laird Wilcox and John George, 1995. It is a large collection of quotations on twenty topics, including civil liberties, Freedom of Speech and of Press, Ideologies and Ideologues, Propaganda, and Public Opinion and Mass Media. "This is a unique reference work consisting of provocative quotations meant to challenge tendencies toward censorship an suppression of ideas as well as the stifling effects of 'politically correct' behavior."<ref>''Be Reasonable: Selected Quotations for Inquiring Minds,'', Prometheus Books, 1995, 361 pps. ({{ISBN|0-87975-867-8}}).</ref> *''The Watchdogs: A Close Look At Anti-Racist "Watchdog" Groups'', self-published by Laird Wilcox, 1997. "Included are documented instances of illegal spying, theft of police files, fund-raising irregularities, questionable "hate crime" statistics, irresponsible and fraudulent claims, perjury, harassment and stalking, violence, and deep and longstanding involvements with Marxist–Leninist extremists."<ref name=Watchdogs/>
==See also== *[[Extremism]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Wilcox, Laird. "What Is Political Extremis'?," ''Free Inquiry'', Council for Democratic and Secular Humanism. Fall 1990, Vol. 10, No. 4., pp. 13–16. A more recent (2005?) and shortened version of this essay appears [http://www.docstoc.com/docs/28477095/What-Is-Political-Extremism here] *"[https://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/12/washington/campus-journal-far-left-and-far-right-meet-in-a-midwest-library.html?scp=1&sq=Laird+Wilcox&st=nyt Far Left and Far Right Meet in a Midwest Library ]," Education Section, ''New York Times'' (12 August 1992) . *Farney, Dennis. "Emergence of Extremist Groups Reflects Changing U. S. Society, Researcher Says." ''Wall Street Journal'' (27 April 1995). *Wilcox, Laird. "Who Watches The Watchmen?," in ''The Cultic Milieu: Oppositional Subcultures in an Age of Globalization'', Edited by Jeffrey Kaplan and Helene Loow, Alta Mira Press, 2002. {{ISBN|978-0-7591-0204-0}} *Wilcox, Laird. "[http://www.lairdwilcox.com/news/defame.html The Protocols of Ritual Defamation: How Values, Opinions and Beliefs Are Controlled in Democratic Societies]". Essay written in 2002. *Wilcox, Laird. ''[http://www.overalltech.net/pub/Quotes5Writer_sRights.pdf The Writer's Rights]'': Over 1,600 Selected Quotations on Freedom of Expression, Civil Liberties and Individual Rights. 136 pp. {{ISBN|0-9761337-4-1}}. 2005. *Wilcox, Laird. ''[http://www.overalltech.net/pub/Quotations-Propaganda.pdf Propaganda, Persuasion & Deception]'': Over 1,125 Selected Quotations for the Ideological Skeptic. 124 pp. {{ISBN|0-9761337-0-9}}. 2005. *Wilcox, Laird. ''[http://www.overalltech.net/pub/Quotations-Rationality.pdf Rationality, Rhetoric, Skepticism & Logic]'': Over 835 Selected Quotations for the Ideological Skeptic. 80 pp. {{ISBN|0-9761337-3-3}}. 2005. *Wilcox, Laird. ''[http://www.overalltech.net/pub/Quotations-Fanaticism.pdf Fanaticism, Dogmatism & Ideological Thinking]'': Over 1,050 Selected Quotations for the Ideological Skeptic. 95 pp. {{ISBN|0-9761337-1-7}}. 2005. *Wilcox, Laird. ''[http://www.overalltech.net/pub/Quotations-PoliticalPsych.pdf Political & Social Psychology & Behavior]'': Over 1,250 Selected Quotations for the Ideological Skeptic. Compiled by Laird Wilcox. 121 pp. {{ISBN|0-9761337-2-5}}. 2005.
==External links== * [http://www.lairdwilcox.com Official website] * [http://spencer.lib.ku.edu/exhibits/wilcox/ Free Speech and the Wilcox Collection: Forty Years of Collecting Political Documents]

{{Infobox writer |name = Laurie Wolf |image = |image_size = |caption = |alt = |birth_name = Laurie Gail Goldrich |birth_date = {{circa}} {{birth year and age|1956}} |birth_place = New York City |nationality = American |education = [[The Culinary Institute of America]] |genre = [[Children's books]], [[Food writing]] |spouse = {{marriage|Bruce Wolf|1984}} }} '''Laurie Goldrich Wolf''' (born {{circa}} 1956<ref name=Pollack2015/>) is an American [[food writing|food writer]] and entrepreneur. Her husband since 1984, Bruce Wolf, who is a professional photographer,<ref name=NYT1984/><ref name=Hamilton1998/> sometimes collaborates with her.<ref name=Butler2012/>
==Education and early career== Wolf graduated from the [[Calhoun School]] in Manhattan<ref name=NYT1984/> and [[The Culinary Institute of America]], worked as a chef and caterer, and as food editor for ''[[Mademoiselle (magazine)|Mademoiselle]]'' and ''[[Child (magazine)|Child]]'' for 18 years.<ref name=Onstad2012/><ref name=OPB2012/> Wolf and her husband moved from New York to Portland in 2008.<ref name=OPB2012/>
==Book writing== Wolf has written several [[children's books]]. ''Candy 1 to 20'' (photography by her husband Bruce), which teaches children to read and count numbers with photographs of candy, received a ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' writeup that noted its "transformation of the familiar into the sweetly surprising",<ref name=Kirkus/> and a review from ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' that called it an "especially kid-friendly approach to counting".<ref name=PW/>
Her 2014 ''Portland, Oregon Chef's Table'' was described as "both as a cookbook and a restaurant guide",<ref name=OPB2012/> and a "powerful tour of Portland's current [[Portland, Oregon#Cuisine and breweries|restaurant scene]]".<ref name=Onstad2012/> The book contains a full chapter on [[brunch]],<ref name=Williams2012/><ref name=Butler2012/> a uniquely prominent facet of Portland's restaurant scene.<ref name=brunch/>
Her [[Crowdfunding|crowdfunded]] 2015 cookbook ''Herb: Mastering the Art of Cooking with Cannabis'' was coauthored with Melissa Parks, a graduate of [[Le Cordon Bleu]] in Minneapolis.<ref name=Bull2015/> It has been noted as one of the first pertaining to cooking with cannabis after legalization in several U.S. states. A ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'' review said it rose to the challenge of improving on existing edibles lore that "just doesn't taste very good",<ref name=Rupp2016/> and a ''[[The New Republic|New Republic]]'' review, while calling it an "ambitious attempt to bring together the weed brownie set and the dinner party set" that "aims to do for weed what [[Julia Child]] did for French cuisine" was somewhat critical of its "murky positioning somewhere between 'basics' and 'cuisine'", with short [[wikt:headnote|headnotes]] and a lack of focus on kitchen fundamentals for novice chefs.<ref name=Bull2015/>
Since 2014, she has been the food writer for ''[[The Cannabist]]''.<ref name=Cannabist2015/><ref name=McDonough2015/>
==Business== Laurie and Bruce Wolf's Portland business Laurie & MaryJane produces sweet and savory [[cannabis edibles]].<ref name=Sevcenko2016/><ref name=McDonough2015/><ref name=Rillos2016/>
==Personal life== Wolf is a member of Portland's Jewish community.<ref name=JTA/> Laurie and Bruce Wolf have two children.<ref name=Hamilton1998/>

'''Leon Jay "Lee" Schipper''' (April 7, 1947 – August 16, 2011) was a physicist and energy efficiency expert who authored more than 100 technical papers and a number of books on energy economics and transportation. He was "often a critic of the conventional wisdom."<ref name="NYT">{{cite news | last = Wald | first = Matthew L. | title = Leon Schipper, Physicist and Iconoclast, Dies at 64 | newspaper = New York Times | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = August 18, 2011 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/19/science/earth/19schipper.html | access-date = }}</ref> He was remembered by climate scientists as "a giant" who "was brilliant at articulating the connections among technology, economics, culture, policy and politics."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://ccap.org/we-were-all-his-students-in-memory-of-lee-schipper/ | title = We were all his students – In Memory of Lee Schipper | last = Winkelman | first = Steve | date = | website = | publisher = | access-date = | quote = }}</ref>
==Education== Schipper attended the [[University of California at Berkeley]]. He earned Bachelor's degrees in Physics and Music in 1968, and a Ph.D. in Astrophysics.
==Career== Schipper worked at the [http://www.lbl.gov Lawrence Berkeley National Lab (LBNL)] for more than 20 years. In addition, he worked at the [http://erg.berkeley.edu Energy and Resources Group at UC Berkeley], [http://www.shell.com Shell International] in London, as well as being [[Fulbright Scholar]] at the [http://www.beijer.kva.se Beijer Institute of Ecological Economics] in Stockholm. He was a guest researcher at the [[World Bank]], VVS Tekniska Foereningen, the [http://www.oecd.org/ OECD], and the [http://www.sei-international.org Stockholm Environment Institute]. He worked closely with the [[Global Business Network]] and [[Cambridge Energy Research Associates]].
He served on the editorial boards of five major journals and was a member of the Swedish Board for Transportation and Communications Research. For four years he was a member of the U.S. [[National Academy of Science]]’s [http://www.trb.org/Main/Home.aspx Transportation Research Board]’s Committee on Sustainable Transport and Committee on Developing Countries.
At the time of his death, Schipper was a senior research scientist at both [http://metrostudies.berkeley.edu University of California Berkeley’s Global Metropolitan Studies] and at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20141207091745/http://peec.stanford.edu/index.php Precourt Institute of Energy Efficiency at Stanford University] conducting research and policy analysis on efficient energy use in transportation systems.
===Energy Efficient Housing=== Schipper's first seminal contribution came in 1976, when he published an influential paper in ''Science'' pointing out that Sweden consumed far less energy per unit of economic activity than the United States did.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Schipper | first = Lee | author-link = | last2 = Lichtenberg | first2 = Allan J. | title = Efficient Energy Use and Well-Being: The Swedish Example | journal = Science | volume = 194 | issue = 4269 | pages = 1001–1013 | date = 3 December 1976 | language = | url = http://igov.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/schipper%20science%20sweden%201976.pdf | jstor = | issn = | doi = 10.1126/science.194.4269.1001 | pmid = 17840289 | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | access-date = | bibcode =1976Sci...194.1001S}}</ref> His work on the energy efficiency of Swedish housing culminated in his 1985 book ''Coming in from the Cold'' with Stephen Meyers and Henry Kelly. Schipper testified before Congress on this subject in March 1984.<ref>[http://hdl.handle.net/2027/pur1.32754066853353?urlappend=%3Bseq=457 Review of federal policies and building standards affecting energy conservation in housing]</ref>
===Transportation=== Schipper shifted his primary attention to transport in the 1980s and started the Berkeley Lab’s International Energy Studies group with [[Jayant Sathaye]], and the two co-led the group for many years.
He was co-founder of [https://web.archive.org/web/20090219000211/http://www.embarq.org/ EMBARQ], the World Resources Institute Center for Sustainable Transport, and remained as a senior associate emeritus.
===Climate Change=== From 1995 to 2001, he was a senior scientist at the [http://www.iea.org [[International Energy Agency]]] in Paris.
He contributed to the Second and Third Assessment Reports of the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]], which was awarded the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 2007. He was due to act as Review Editor for the chapter on Transport in Working Group III's contribution to the Fifth Assessment Report, released in April 2014.<ref>http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/press-releases/ipcc-wg3-ar5-authors.pdf</ref>
==Legacy== [[John Holdren]], later to become Science Advisor to President [[Barack Obama]], was the first person to hire Schipper as an energy specialist, at Berkeley in the early 1970s. He said ‘‘Lee was one of the first people to point out that people don’t want to consume energy, but they want to consume energy services, like transportation, comfortable rooms, cold beer and so forth. And that there was an enormous variation in the amount of energy needed to perform those services.’’<ref name="NYT" />
Mark Levine, who was Schipper’s superviser for most his career at LBNL, said: "Lee was the founding father of a school of energy analysts, a tradition carried on with vigor in the Energy Analysis Department at LBNL.... The work he did has been carried on here. He created an important tradition of understanding energy by studying it from the bottom up, which means by end user."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://newscenter.lbl.gov/2011/08/17/berkeley-lab-energy-efficiency-expert-lee-schipper-dies/ | title = Berkeley Lab Energy Efficiency Expert Lee Schipper Dies | last = Chao | first = Julie | date = August 17, 2011 | website = | publisher = | access-date = | quote = }}</ref> Schipper broke new ground by analyzing energy data sector by sector and end-use by end-use in various countries and comparing them. He demonstrated that energy intensity did not correlate with GDP in any simple way and was able to show why.
==Personal== He was described as being an irrepressible iconoclast<ref name="NYT" /> with a wonderful knack of turning a phrase to excellent effect. Evidence for this was publishing 15 letters to the editor in the ''New York Times'' on energy efficiency. For example, in his view the "cash for clunkers" program—which offered rebates to people who bought a new car with better mileage than their old one—did little to save energy, although it may have reduced air pollution. In many cases, buyers used the rebate to buy something bigger and more high-powered than they would have otherwise. "The effect is inverse of what we were hoping for" he said.<ref name="NYT" />
Schipper was also an accomplished musician. He was the leader of the University of California Jazz Quintet in 1968.<ref>[https://research.archives.gov/description/130296 "Lee Schipper, leader of the University of California Jazz Quintet"] interview, 27 May 1968.</ref> As a UC Berkeley student and vibraphonist, he led his jazz group to victory at the Notre Dame Jazz Festival in 1967. In 1969 Danish saxophonist Carsten Meinert invited him to record on his album "C.M. Musictrain" in Denmark (Spectator Records). In 1973 he recorded "The Phunky Physicist" with Swedish guitar player Janne Schaffer. He would reprise the role as band leader with an ad hoc jazz group, Lee Schipper and the Mitigators, who performed primarily in conjunction with energy-related conferences.
He was also one of the world’s experts on [[Wilhelm Furtwängler|Wilhelm Furtwangler]], a 20th century symphonic and operatic conductor, and collected one of the most complete sets of his recordings.
==Publications== *1985: (lead author) ''Coming in from the Cold: Energy-wise Housing in Sweden'' (American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy) *1992: (lead author) ''Energy Efficiency and Human Activity: Past Trends, Future Prospects'' (Cambridge University Press) *1992: (co-author) [http://www.accessmagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/7/2016/07/access01-04-Environmentally-Benign-Automobiles.pdf "Environmentally Benign Automobiles"] ''Access Magazine'' *1993: (lead author) [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/030142159390268K "Mind the Gap: The Vicious Circle of Measuring Automobile Fuel Use"] ''Energy Policy'' *2001: (co-author) [http://escholarship.org/uc/item/7m97k9mg|''Transportation in Developing Countries: Greenhouse Gas Scenarios for Delhi, India''] (Institute for Transportation Studies, UC Davis) *2005: (co-author) [http://www.wri.org/publication/growing-greenhouse|''Growing in the Greenhouse: Protecting the Climate by Putting Development First''] (World Resources Institute) *2006: (co-author) [http://www.wri.org/publication/measuring-invisible-1|''Measuring the Invisible: Quantifying Emissions Reductions from Transport Solutions - Querétaro Case Study''] (World Resources Institute) *2008: (lead author) [http://www.wri.org/publication/measuring-invisible-hanoi-case-study|''Measuring The Invisible: Quantifying Emissions Reductions From Transport Solutions - Hanoi Case Study''] (World Resources Institute) *2009: (lead author) [https://think-asia.org/bitstream/handle/11540/1402/adb-wp09-transport-co2-emissions.pdf?sequence=1|''Transport and Carbon Dioxide Emissions: Forecasts, Options Analysis, and Evaluation''] (Asian Development Bank)

{{infobox nobility | name = Nils Ravaldsson | death_date = 1505 | death_place = [[Västergötland]] }} '''Nils Ravaldsson''' (died 1505) was a leader of the [[Knut Alvsson|Alvsson's]] [[Dano-Swedish War (1501–12)|rebellion]]. He was the leader of the rebellion after Knut Alvsson was murdered.
Ravaldsson did in the early stages of the rebellion an occupation of [[Marstrand]] and [[Sarpsborg]], and became the leader of the rebellion in 1502 and was the leader to 1504 when the rebellion was crushed on Christmas night at [[Olsborg Castle]] in [[Båhuslen]]. Ravaldsson died in exile at a farm in [[Västergötland]] the next year.<ref>Store norske leksikon: [https://snl.no/Nils_Ravaldsson Nils Ravaldsson]</ref>
