{{one source|date=January 2014}} [[File:Beijing - Huimin Xiaoxue - CIMG3664.JPG|thumb|Niujie]]
'''Niujie''' ({{zh|c=牛街|p=Niú jiē|w=Niu-chieh}} "Oxen Street"<ref name=WangZhouFanp112>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 112.</ref>) is a neighborhood at [[Guang'anmen]],<ref name=China.org.cn>"[http://china.org.cn/travel/where_to_go/2008-04/21/content_14989563.htm Culinary delights: Beijing's Muslim cuisine]." ([https://archive.is/NvFbL Archive]) [[China Internet Information Center]] (China.org.cn). Retrieved on 5 January 2014.</ref> in [[Xicheng District]] in southwest [[Beijing]], [[China]]. The name "Niujie" can refer to the street ''Niujie'' or to the neighborhood ''Niujie''.<ref name=WangZhouFanp113>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 113.</ref> The community was previously in [[Xuanwu District, Beijing|Xuanwu District]] before the district was merged into Xicheng in 2010.
The Niujie district is administered by the Niujie Street Administrative Office. The core area of this district is along the street Niujie.<ref name=WangZhouFanp112/> The Niujie core area, a [[Hui people]] neighborhood,<ref name=WangZhouFanp104>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 104.</ref> has Beijing's largest concentration of Muslim people.<ref name=China.org.cn/> As of 2013 there is a Muslim-oriented hospital as well as social services, cafés, shops, restaurants, and schools catering to the Muslim population.<ref name=WuWeipingGaubatzp254>Wu, Weiping and Gaubatz. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=EcPEykizV3gC&pg=PA254 254].</ref> In 2002 Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and C. Cindy Fan, authors of "Growth and Decline of Muslim Hui Enclaves in Beijing," wrote that Niujie "continues to thrive as a major residential area of the Hui people in Beijing and as a prominent supplier of [[Chinese Islamic cuisine|Hui foods]] and services for the entire city."<ref name=WangZhouFanp104/> The neighborhood has the [[Niujie Mosque]], which according to Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan, "mark[s] the identity of Niujie" and has an element of centrality in the community.<ref name=WangZhouFanp117>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 117.</ref> Most larger Hui neighborhoods in Beijing have their own mosques.<ref name=WangZhouFanp113/>
==History== [[File:Beijing-Niujie-Minzu-Tuanjie-Da-Jiating-3660.JPG|thumb|left|A fence in Niujie depicting the ethnicities in China, including the Hui (回族)]] At up to the [[Tang Dynasty]], what is now Niujie would have been on the city's periphery according to archival research and historical documents.<ref name=WangZhouFanp112113>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 112-113. "Historical documents and archival research indicate that from as early as the Tang dynasty (618–907), the location of today’s Niujie had been on the periphery of the city of Beijing"</ref> The [[Niujie Mosque]] was built between 916 and 1125. Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan stated that the establishment of the Hui settlement "probably" was related to Muslims joining the army of [[Genghis Khan]], who had conquered Beijing, and that based on some gravestones of imams encountered at the Niujie Mosque, a significant community of Hui people had lived in the Niujie area dating back to the [[Yuan Dynasty]]. During that dynasty many Muslims moved to Beijing.<ref name=WangZhouFanp113/> Therefore, soldiers were the first Hui people in Niujie.<ref name=WangZhouFanp115>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 115.</ref>
During the Yuan Dynasty Niujie was located in proximity to and outside of the main [[Beijing city wall]], and it had the name Willow River Village.<ref name=WangZhouFanp113/> [[Dru C. Gladney]], author of ''Muslim Chinese: Ethnic Nationalism in the People's Republic'', wrote that according to stories from that Dynasty, Han people rarely walked in the neighborhood alone. In addition, the stories state that during the dynasty, 2,953 households resided on Niujie.<ref name=Gladneyp175>[[Dru C. Gladney|Gladney]], p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=_hJ9aht6nZQC&pg=PA175 175].</ref> Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan wrote that "peripheral location reflected separation between the Hui people living there and the Mongolian residents living within the city wall."<ref name=WangZhouFanp113/> In 1544 an outer city wall was established and Willow River Village was within this outer city wall. Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan wrote that wrote that the community "was still considered peripheral to the city proper where most Han Chinese lived."<ref name=WangZhouFanp113/>
According to the [[China Internet Information Center]], a legend stated that the street Niujie was originally named "Pomegranate Street" or '''Liujie''' ({{zh|c=榴街|p=liú jiē|w=Liu-chieh}}) because the Muslims in the community grew pomegranate trees.<ref name=China.org.cn/> Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan stated the ''Liu'' meant "[[willow]]" (C: 柳, P: ''Liǔ'', W: ''Liu'') and that the similarity between ''liu'' and ''niu'' "might have given rise to the name change."<ref name=WangZhouFanp113/> Gladney wrote that the name may have originated from a concentration of beef butchers during the Qing Dynasty or from the homophonic similarity to the Liu River, where pomegranate and willow trees grew.<ref name="Gladneyp175"/> The name change of the community to Niujie occurred during the [[Qing Dynasty]].<ref name=WangZhouFanp113/> The China Internet Information Center stated that the street name changed when members of the began specializing in beef.<ref name=China.org.cn/> At that time, [[imam]]s had butchered both mutton and beef.<ref name=WangZhouFanp113114>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 113-114.</ref>
Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan stated that the Niujie Hui community continued to be distinct from the Manchu community in Beijing during the Qing Dynasty.<ref name=WangZhouFanp114>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 114.</ref>
In the late 1990s the neighborhood underwent a renovation and the majority of the 3,000 families living there relocated on a temporary basis as the renovations occurred.<ref name=WuWeipingGaubatzp254/> Reza Hasmath, author of "The Identification, Settlement, and Representation of Ethnic Minorities in Beijing," wrote that this "perhaps" was a reaction to the per capita GDP and economic growth rate of [[Xuanwu District, Beijing|Xuanwu District]] trailing that of [[Dongcheng District, Beijing|Dongcheng District]] and [[Xicheng District]].<ref name=Hasmathp95>Hasmath, "The Identification, Settlement, and Representation of Ethnic Minorities in Beijing," p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y0KlgRzs_RoC&pg=PA95 95].</ref> The renovations of a {{convert|36|ha|acre|adj=on}} area in the district began in 1997, 26,000 residents in about 7,500 households were affected by the renovations. The completion of the first phase occurred by the end of 2000.<ref name=WangZhouFanp117/> New apartment buildings had been constructed,<ref name=Hasmathp95/> and a government policy stated that displaced residents of Niujie only needed to pay a small price in order to move into the new buildings. At the end of phase one, 3,000 people moved into the new apartment buildings. The majority of residents who decided not to return were Han Chinese.<ref name=WangZhouFanp117/> Overall the non-Muslims had a tendency to remain out of the neighborhood. Almost all of the Muslim families returned after renovations ended.<ref name=WuWeipingGaubatzp254/> Overall 90% of the displaced families from the first phase of the renovation had returned.<ref name=WangZhouFanp117/>
In 2002, Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan wrote that Niujie "continues to be a thriving enclave, with a high concentration of Hui residents and economic activities".<ref name=WangZhouFanp116>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 116.</ref> The second stage of the renovation was scheduled to be completed that year.<ref name=WangZhouFanp117/>
==Demographics== Niujie district had 64,059 residents, 21.9% of them being Hui, in 2000. As of 2000 24,088 people lived in the Niujie core area, 54.1% being Hui. This gives it a higher percentage of Hui population than other areas of the district.<ref name=WangZhouFanp112/> The core area is one of Beijing's largest ethnic enclaves<!--The 24,088 figure in Hasmath's book comes from 2000--><ref name=Hasmathp95/> Reza Hasmath, author of ''A Comparative Study of Minority Development in China and Canada'', wrote that since the ethnic attractions of many areas in Beijing are not located in areas that have strong minority demographics, the fact that Niujie still is strongly Hui is "more remarkable".<ref name=Hasmathstudyp37>Hasmath, ''A Comparative Study of Minority Development in China and Canada'', p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=YZ_IAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA37 37].</ref>
As of 1996 the district had 55,722 residents, with 13,755, or 24.7% of the total population, being ethnic minorities. Of the minorities, 13,307, or 96.6%, were Hui. In the core area itself, there were 2,446 residents and 649 households resident. Of the individuals, 1,763 were Hui, making up 70.2% of the population. Of the households 475 were Hui, making up 69.3%, and the Manchu and Mongolian ethnic groups each had two households.<ref name=Gladneyp176>[[Dru C. Gladney|Gladney]], p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=_hJ9aht6nZQC&pg=PA176 176].</ref>
In the neighborhoods on both sides of the core area, as of 1996 about 50% of the residents were Han and 50% were Hui.<ref name=Gladneyp176/> In the Tang Fang neighborhood in the Niujie District, as of the 1982 Census, there were 3,107 individuals. Of them, there were 1,814 Hui, making up 58.38% of the population, 1,272 Han, making up 40.94% of the population, and 21 Manchu, making up .68% of the population.<ref name=Gladneyp179>[[Dru C. Gladney|Gladney]], p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=_hJ9aht6nZQC&pg=PA179 179].</ref> As of 1996 the communities closer to the core area have higher Hui populations than those further from the core area.<ref name=Gladneyp176/>
As of 2007, according to Nimrod Baranovich, author of "Inverted Exile: Uyghur Writers and Artists in Beijing and the Political Implications of Their Work," he had been informed that many [[Uyghur people]] live in Niujie.<ref name=Baranovitchp497>Baranovitch, Nimrod ([[University of Haifa]]). "[http://mcx.sagepub.com/content/33/4/462.refs Inverted Exile: Uyghur Writers and Artists in Beijing and the Political Implications of Their Work]." ''[[Modern China]]''. [[Sage Publications]]. October 2007 33: 462-504, doi: 10.1177/0097700407304803 - Cited: p. 497. "[...]and that many Uyghurs live today in the Hui Muslim quarter on Niujie (Ox Street)."</ref>
==Cityscape== As of 2011 the Niujie core area features various buildings decorated in an Islamic Chinese style, including the post office and apartment blocks. The apartments were painted in the Islamic-associated colors white and green and decorated with Islamic symbols<!--Relevant to the Hui character of the neighborhood-->. The core area includes a Hui primary school, a supermarket carrying [[halal]] products, and several Muslim restaurants.<ref name=Hasmathp95/> As of 1996 there were There were 51 Islamic meatshops, 51 Islamic restaurants, and several Islamic foodstuff stores in all of Xuanwu district. On Niujie Street at that time there were Hui ''getihu'' who sold fruit and pastries, 8 Islamic noodle and pastry shops, and 2 small Islamic restaurants.<ref name=Gladneyp175/>
The Chinese Islamic Association building, located southeast of the Mosque, has Arab architectural flourishes such as parapets and large green domes. It was built in the 1950s. The ''Huimin Yiyuan'' (S: 回民医院, P: ''Huímín Yīyuàn''), the Hui hospital, is at the south end of the Niujie street.<ref name=Gladneyp175/> The [[Communist Party of China]] (CPC) has erected various signs stating that the local government had helped improve the delivery of electricity, gas, and water to Niujie discussing the historic achievements of the Niujie community.<ref name=Hasmathp95/>
The Tang Fang neighborhood is west of Niujie Street on Beiruilu.<ref name=Gladneyp176/>
==Government and infrastructure== The Niujie Street Administrative Office governs the area in the community. In 2002 Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan concluded that based on the re-development plans stating that the Niujie Mosque would remain in its current location with its "centrality" in the community, the administrative office "has played an important role in preserving the Hui character of the enclave, making it possible for the Hui residents to return and live in a setting they are highly identified with, despite urban renovation and redevelopment."<ref name=WangZhouFanp117/>
==Economy== [[File:Niujie - halal supermarket - CIMG3720.JPG|thumb|left|A [[halal]] supermarket in Niujie<!--清真 means "Halal" and 超市 means "supermarket"-->]] Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan explained that the economy of the community is focused on "ethnic-specific activities" such as Jade processing, meat trading, and Islamic restaurants.<ref name=WangZhouFanp118>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 118.</ref> Tourism, including visits to the [[Niujie Mosque]], is a part of the economy of Niujie. A survey conducted by Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan in January 2002 concluded that the market and shops on Nanhengxi Street sold about {{convert|6000|kg|lbs}} of beef and mutton daily. The same survey counted over 30 Islamic restaurants on Nanhengxi Street. In addition, around 2002, there had been an increase in contractors, miscellaneous repair shops, and other services.<ref name=WangZhouFanp118/>
Reza Hasmath wrote that Niujie was "one of the last surviving, important ethnic enclaves in Beijing" because the rapid growth of Beijing had caused many ethnic enclaves to vanish.<ref name=Hasmathstudyp37/> Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan wrote that Niujie has remained to be an [[ethnic enclave]] because it continued to be "peripheral to the city’s core area of economic growth" with much of the expansion occurring in north Beijing instead of the portion of Beijing where Niujie resides.<ref name=WangZhouFanp114/> In an interview in August 2000 the head of a resident committee in the [[Madian, Beijing|Madian]] neighborhood in [[Haidian District]], which historically was a Hui community but faced a decline due to development, stated that even though going to Niujie from Madian meant a lengthy commute, many Madian Hui now preferred to travel there to purchase beef and mutton.<ref name=WangZhouFanp118119>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 118-119.</ref> Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan wrote that "This is evidence that Niujie’s role as a large enclave and major supplier for the Hui people in Beijing has been enhanced as the ethnic economy of Madian gradually declined."<ref name=WangZhouFanp119>Wang, Zhou, and Fan, p. 119.</ref>
Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan wrote that Niujie served in a wider ethnic Hui economy across Beijing as well as providing a local ethnic enclave economy in the period from the [[Ming Dynasty]] until 1949.<ref name=WangZhouFanp114/> In the pre-1949 period 75%<!--three quarters--> of the jade trade enterprises in the city were located in Niujie. Wenfei Wang, Shangyi Zhou, and Cindy Fan wrote that in this period a central component of Niujie was the food service sector, which consisted of beef and button stands, [[Hui cuisine|Hui food]] wagons and stands, and Hui<!--stated in the source as "qingzhen" which can refer to Hui people--> restaurants.<ref name=WangZhouFanp114/> They stated that residents of Niujie "gained a reputation for operating meat delicatessens in other parts of Beijing."<ref name=WangZhouFanp114/> Niujie was also adjacent to a major vegetable market, ''[[Caishikou]]''.<ref name=WangZhouFanp114/>
==Education== One school in Niujie, the Beijing Xuanwu Huimin Elementary School (S: 北京市宣武回民小学, P: ''Běijīng Shì Xuānwǔ Huímín Xiǎoxué'', "Beijing Xuanwu Hui People Elementary School"), serves the [[Hui people]] living in the area.<ref>[http://www.xwhmxx.cn/index.aspx Home page] ([https://archive.is/psEQG Archive]). Beijing Xuanwu Huimin Elementary School. Retrieved on January 10, 2014. "学校地址：北京市西城区牛街西里一区5号(北京市宣武回民小学)"</ref>
By 2011 a principal of a Hui school in Niujie had stated that the students are taught in the Chinese educational scheme and are given a supplementary Islamic education, but that "our first priority is to ensure that the Teaching Scheme is taught, as it is the case for all students in Beijing, so our students are not left behind."<ref>Hasmath, Reza. "[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01419870.2011.553238#.Usgm4vsSPOs The education of ethnic minorities in Beijing]." ''[[Ethnic and Racial Studies]]''. 2011. Volume 34, Issue 11. DOI: 10.1080/01419870.2011.553238. p. 1835-1854. Cited page 1840. "The Principal of a Hui minority school in the Niujie area of Xuanwu District elaborates on the operationalization of this Scheme in respect to her school:[...]"</ref>

{{primary sources|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox person | name = Pandora Braithwaite | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = January 1967 | birth_place = | education = [[Oxford University]] | occupation = [[Member of Parliament]] | spouse = {{ubl|Julian Twyselton-Fife <small>(1984–85)</small>|Jack Cavendish <small>(1985–97)</small>}} | relatives = {{ubl|[[List of Adrian Mole characters#Ivan Braithwaite|Ivan Braithwaite]] <small>(father)</small>|[[List of Adrian Mole characters#Tania Braithwaite|Tania Braithwaite]] <small>(mother)</small>}} }} '''Dr Pandora Louise Elizabeth Braithwaite''' is a fictional character in the [[Adrian Mole|''Adrian Mole'' series]] of books by [[Sue Townsend]]. In the books, Pandora is the love of Adrian's life. Pandora is beautiful (Adrian especially loves her 'treacle-coloured' hair) and intelligent, and in the first books, she and Adrian Mole are happy together. In the later books, Pandora resists Adrian's advances in favour of physically and intellectually powerful men, although Adrian remains attached to her.
==Character== As a youth she is precocious and outspoken with firm feminist and hard-left views. As she ages she becomes successful but also manipulative and devious, she is portrayed as being somewhat a champagne socialist.
== Life == Pandora's parents were called Ivan and Tania. She came to [[Leicester]] at the age of 13 and sat with [[Adrian Mole|Adrian]] during [[Geography]] classes, and soon became the most popular girl in their class. She started dating Nigel, but they soon broke up. A few weeks later, on Wednesday (June 10, 1981), Adrian and Pandora started dating together. They had many short break-ups, until they finally ended their relationship in ''True Confessions''.
She attended the [[University of Oxford]], studying [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]], [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Serbo-Croat language|Serbo-Croat]]. She graduated and married her first husband, Julian Twyselton-Fife, who was openly gay, as a "favour" done by Julian. They cemented their love at London's Astoria [[G-A-Y]] nightclub after he drove for hours to pick her up. Her aversion to germs meant that she was unable to take a train. She had several liaisons and drifted apart from Adrian. Eventually she cohabited with Jack Cavendish, an old professor of linguistics. After many years they split up, with Jack revealing many of her secrets.
Later, she entered politics in the [[New Labour]] era under [[Tony Blair]] and became a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] [[Member of Parliament (UK)|MP]] for [[Ashby-de-la-Zouch]], [[Leicestershire]]. She referred to herself as '''''Pan National''''' and '''''The Shiniest Star in Blair's Sky''''', nicknames that the media picked up and subsequently used. However, she vocally opposed the [[Iraq War]] and was seen to be one of the Labour Party's most left-wing MPs. As an MP she is criticised for her expensive French wardrobe and shows little concern for her constituents; declaring that 'democracy is wasted on them'.
===Nicknames=== * ''Box'' (in book 1) * ''Pan'' <small>(in private)</small> * ''The Peoples' Pan'' <small>(in media)</small> * ''Pan National'' <small>(in media)</small> * ''The Shiniest Star in Blair's Sky'' <small>(in media)</small>
== Portrayals == * [[Lindsey Stagg]] on ''[[The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole (TV series)|The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole, Aged 13¾]]'' (1985—1987) * [[Helen Baxendale]] on ''[[Adrian Mole: the Cappuccino Years (TV series)|Adrian Mole: the Cappuccino Years]]'' (2001)

[[Zane Buchanan]] }} '''Paul Cramer''' is a [[fictional character]] from the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] daytime [[soap opera]] ''[[One Life to Live]]''. Paul was originated on October 3, 2003, by [[Brock Cuchna]], who played the role until March 10, 2004.[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1492446/ Brock Cuchna - IMDb.com][http://www.soapcentral.com/oltl/whoswho/paul.php Paul Cramer profile - SoapCentral.com] The character was then recast with [[David Tom]] on March 11, 2004[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005495/ David Tom - IMDb.com] In August 2004, the role was temporarily played by [[Shane McRae]].[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0574460/ Shane McRae - IMDb.com] Paul crossed over to ABC's ''[[All My Children]]'' multiple times from December 30, 2003, to October 27, 2004, during a "baby switch" storyline involving both series. The character of Paul was killed off as part of a murder mystery storyline in October 2004,{{cite web|url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/2004-05/20041027.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (10/27/04)|publisher=ABC.com ([[Internet Archive]]) |accessdate=April 23, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080423055357/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/2004-05/20041027.html |archivedate = April 23, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/2004-05/20041102.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (11/2/04) |publisher=ABC.com (Internet Archive) |accessdate=April 23, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080423055428/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/2004-05/20041102.html |archivedate = April 23, 2008}} but lingered in newly created [[Flashback (narrative)|flashback]]s and other characters' dreams and hallucinations until May 2005. Tom is the real-life brother of [[Heather Tom]], who played Paul's half-sister [[Kelly Cramer]]. ==Storyline== ===Beginnings=== Paul Cramer first appears in [[Llanview, Pennsylvania|Llanview]] in late 2003 at the re-opening Crossroads, the bar formerly owned by [[Ben Davidson (One Life to Live)|Ben Davidson]]. In search of [[Sarah Roberts]], the daughter of [[Tina Lord]] and [[Cord Roberts]], Paul says he had known Sarah's brother [[C.J. Roberts|C.J.]] while serving as a pilot in the [[United States Navy|Navy]] and that he had made "the biggest mistake of his life." The nature of this mistake is never revealed as Paul never shares any scenes with Sarah and instead becomes embroiled in a storyline with [[Dorian Lord]] and the [[Cramer family]]. A local society maven, Dorian is shocked as Paul arrives on her doorstep and claims to be the son of Dorian's mentally disturbed younger sister [[Melinda Cramer|Melinda]] (who had recently confessed to Dorian that she had given birth to another child during her years in [[Europe]]) and therefore [[Kelly Cramer|Kelly]]'s brother. Paul was raised by an upstanding foster family and has only just recently learned of his true heritage. Dorian soon worries that this heretofore unknown Cramer could be the heir to her aging [[Betsy Cramer|Aunt Betsy]]'s fortune. Aunt Betsy, an eccentric old spinster, has very specific ideas on what a "real Cramer" should be and feels that almost all the women in the family have abdicated their power and self-esteem to men. Dorian and her other niece [[Blair Cramer|Blair]] are desperate to get their hands on Aunt Betsy's inheritance, and the matriarchal family is shocked when man-hating Betsy's favor turns to the dark horse: Paul, the newcomer, who also happens to be a man. A seemingly agreeable young man with his life in order, Paul is soon targeted for ruin by Dorian and her partner in crime [[David Vickers]]. Determined to get Aunt Betsy's inheritance, Dorian and David seek any information they can use against Paul to force him out of Betsy's good graces. They find just that in the discovery of Paul's connection to schemer [[Babe Carey]] from [[Pine Valley (All My Children)|Pine Valley]], and Paul and Babe's outrageous marriage from the recent past. With Paul out of Betsy's favor, Dorian and David are free and clear to use [[Carlotta Vega]]'s ward [[Adriana Cramer|Adriana Colón]] to gain control of the Cramer wealth once and for all. Paul, meanwhile, begins exhibiting shadier behavior, like working with Dr. William Long, then-Chief of Staff of Llanview Hospital, to sell organs on the black market, and [[blackmail]]ing [[Jennifer Rappaport]] for sex using a tape of [[Rex Balsom]] and Jen's mother [[Lindsay Rappaport|Lindsay]] in bed. === Crossover to ''All My Children'' === Paul's December 30, 2003 visit to his estranged secret wife [[Babe Carey]] on ''All My Children''{{cite web|url=http://www.soapcentral.com/amc/news/2003/1117-crossovers.php|title=''AMC'' News: ABC Plans ''AMC'', ''OLTL'' Crossovers|last=Kroll|first=Dan J.|date=November 12, 2003|publisher=[[Soapcentral]]|accessdate=February 19, 2009}} ultimately leads to an extensive "baby switch" [[fictional crossover|crossover]] storyline in 2004. Paul finds himself delivering the babies of both Babe and her friend [[Bianca Montgomery]] during a rainstorm in nearby [[Pine Valley (All My Children)|Pine Valley]] on March 24, 2004. Paul stages a crash with his [[MEDEVAC]] helicopter and takes [[Adam Chandler III|Babe's son]] for Kelly, who is desperate for a child to save her marriage after miscarrying her own. Paul initially tells Babe that her child had died in the accident; threatened at the scene by the powerful family of the child's father, Paul quickly changes his plan, giving [[Miranda Montgomery|Bianca's daughter]] to Babe and telling Bianca that her baby had died instead. Unaware of the child's origins, Kelly brings Babe's infant back to Llanview, passing him off as her child with Kevin. Kevin and Kelly name the baby [[Ace Buchanan|Asa "Ace" Buchanan II]] after Kevin's grandfather. Babe discovers that "her daughter" is really Bianca's, but remains silent for months and allows Paul to manipulate her and Bianca. Meanwhile, a devastated Kelly discovers that Paul had stolen Ace from his mother; Paul, desperate for cash, blackmails Kelly by threatening to reveal the secret to Kevin and Llanview. Armed with the truth, Kelly realizes they must return the child to his parents; though broken-hearted, they do. Bianca's family resents Babe for the baby switch, seemingly forgetting Paul's role in the incident.{{cite book |chapter=Babes 'N' Switch: Double Trouble (''AMC/OLTL'' 2004-2005) |title=[[Soap Opera Digest]] |first=Naomi |last=Rabinowitz |pages=72–75 |date=February 24, 2009 |publisher=(Vol. 34, No. 8)}} === Demise === After alienating nearly everyone in town, Paul has a mysterious meeting in a cemetery on 27 October 2004; his corpse is later revealed in an open grave, shot to death. A murder mystery plays out, and in 2005 the killer is revealed to be respectable [[District Attorney]] [[Daniel Colson]], new husband of [[Nora Hanen|Nora Buchanan]]. Paul had been blackmailing Daniel, who is secretly [[gay]] and carrying on a torrid affair with local college student [[Mark Solomon (One Life to Live)|Mark Solomon]]. When Paul learned the truth about Daniel's extramarital activities, Daniel eliminated him and attempted to pin the crime on Jennifer Rappaport. During the course of the storyline, Paul appeared to Daniel as a ghoulish hallucination, warning him that he would be exposed. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.soapcentral.com/oltl/whoswho/paul.php Paul Cramer profile - SoapCentral.com] {{OLTL}} {{All My Children}} {{All My Children characters}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cramer, Paul}} [[Category:One Life to Live characters]] [[Category:Fictional criminals]] [[Category:All My Children characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2003]]

[[Image:RobertoPayro.jpg|thumb|right|Roberto Payró]] '''Roberto Jorge Payró''' ([[Mercedes, Buenos Aires|Mercedes]], April 19, 1867–[[Lomas de Zamora]], April 8, 1928) was an [[Argentine]] writer and journalist.
Payró founded the newspaper ''La Tribuna'' in the city of [[Bahía Blanca]], where he published his first newspaper articles. He then moved to the city of [[Buenos Aires]] where he worked as an editor at the newspaper ''[[La Nación]]''. During this time he had the opportunity of frequently traveling both inside and outside of Argentina.
In 1895, he published a compilation of his articles in the book ''Los italianos en la Argentina'' (''The Italians in Argentina''). His diaries of travel and impressions gave rise to his novels: ''La Australia Argentina (Excursión periodística a las costas patagónicas)'' (''Southern Argentina – a Journalist’s Excursion to the Shores of Patagonia''); ''Tierra del Fuego e Islas de los Estados'' (''The Land of Fire and Islands of the States''); and ''En las tierras del Inti'' (''In the Lands of the Inti''). He also wrote for ''Caras y Caretas'', the literary Journal of [[Fray mocho]].
Payró was a correspondent in Europe during the [[First World War]]. He participated fervently in meetings with other [[socialist]] writers including [[Leopoldo Lugones]], [[José Ingenieros]] and [[Ernesto de la Cárcova]].
Payró was also the grandparent of Brayan and Maria.
In Payró's novels one can appreciate the unique ironic language style of the period. He utilized typical people and related common situations, showing the lives of the [[Italian people|Italian]] immigrants ('the feisty [[Creole peoples|creole]]s'). In his ''Divertidas aventuras del nieto de Juan Moreira'' (''Amusing Adventures of the Grandson of [[Juan Moreira]]'') he tells the story of a provincial and his political career. He also wrote historical novels such as ''El falso Inca, una serie de cuentos publicados bajo el nombre de Pago Chico'' (''The False Inca, a series of accounts published under the name of Pago Chico''). A posthumous work, ''Nuevos cuentos de Pago Chico'' (''New Tales of Pago Chico''), was published the year following his death.
== Novels == * Canción trágica (A Tragic Song), 1900 * Sobre las ruinas (On the Ruins), 1904 * Marco Severi, 1905 * El casamiento de Laucha (The Marriage of Laucha), 1906 * El triunfo de los otros (The Triumph of the Others, 1907 * En las tierras del Inti (In the Lands of the Inti), 1909 * Divertidas aventuras del nieto de Juan Moreira (The Amusing Adventures of the Grandson of Juan Moreira), 1910 * Vivir quiero conmigo (I Wish to Live With Me), 1923 * Fuego en el rastrojo (Fire in the Stubble), 1925 * Alegría (Happiness), 1928 * Mientraiga (As long as we have some), 1928 * Chamijo, 1930
== Historical novels == * El falso Inca (The False Inca), 1905 * El capitán Vergara (Captain Vergara), 1925 * El mar dulce (The Sweet Sea), 1927
== Stories == * Pago Chico, (Little Pago), 1908 * Violines y toneles (Violins and kegs), 1908 * Historias de Pago Chico (Stories of Little Village), 1920 * Nuevos cuentos de Pago Chico (New Stories of Little Village), 1929 * Cuentos del otro barrio, (Tales of Another Neighborhood), 1932 * El diablo en Bélgica, (Devil in Belgium), 1953
== Journalistic articles == * Los italianos en la Argentina (The Italians in Argentina), 1895, a collection of articles * La Australia Argentina (Southern Argentina), 1898
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox writer | birth_name = Samuel John Ross Jr. | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1971|7|15}} | birth_place = [[Cumberland, Maryland]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Writer, game designer, graphic artist | spouse = Sandra Ross | nationality = United States | period = 1990- | genre = [[Discordianism]], [[Role-playing game]]s, [[fantasy]], [[Wargaming|wargames]] | influences = }}
'''Samuel John Ross Jr.''' (born July 15, 1971),{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} known as '''S. John Ross''', is a game designer and owner of Cumberland Games & Diversions. He wrote the early [[Indie role-playing game]] [[Risus]].
==Career== Ross began writing professionally in 1990 writing role-playing material for [[Avalon Hill]], [[Flying Buffalo]], [[Guardians of Order]], [[Last Unicorn Games]], [[Steve Jackson Games]], [[TSR, Inc.|TSR]], [[West End Games]], [[White Wolf Publishing|White Wolf]], and [[Wizards of the Coast]] in addition to his own company, Cumberland Games & Diversions.<ref name="ross_pp">{{cite web |url=http://www.pen-paper.net/rpgdb.php?op=showcreator&creatorid=1019 |title=S. John Ross |year=2003 |accessdate=February 11, 2014 |publisher=Pen & Paper |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930200952/http://www.pen-paper.net/rpgdb.php?op=showcreator&creatorid=1019 |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="ross_sjg">{{cite web |url=http://e23.sjgames.com/credits.html?t=author&n=S.%20John%20Ross |title=S. John Ross |accessdate=Feb 11, 2014 |publisher=Steve Jackson Games}}</ref><ref name="starland">{{cite web |url=https://starland.com/wp/gamefest/tabletop/ |title=Special Guests |publisher=Starland |accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref>
Ross' ''[[Uresia: Grave of Heaven]]'' (2003) was an original setting published for the ''[[Big Eyes, Small Mouth]]'' role-playing game; it was reminiscent of ''Swords & Sorcery'' anime.<ref name="designers">{{Cite book |author=Shannon Appelcline |title=Designers & Dragons |publisher=Mongoose Publishing |year=2011 |isbn=978-1-907702-58-7 |pages=337}}</ref> Ross created ''[[Risus|Risus: The Anything RPG]]''<ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/wetpaint-launches-free-service-which-lets-anyone-start-their-own-click-and-type-website-70736777.html</ref> and ''Sparks'' paper miniatures. He also created the retro-science fiction-fantasy role-playing game ''Encounter Critical'', and maintains the All-Systems Library.<ref name="starland" />
His fonts have appeared on television, books and billboards.<ref name="devroye">{{cite web |url=http://luc.devroye.org/ |title=Cumberland Fontworks [Samuel John Ross] |author=[[Luc Devroye]] |publisher=Luc Devroye |accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> They have been used by [[Anheuser-Busch]], [[Atheist Bus Campaign]],<ref name="a_sherine">{{cite web |url=http://www.someoneoncetoldme.com/gallery/28092009 |title=Someone Once Told Me World Tour 28 Sept. |publisher=Someone Once Told Me |accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> [[Comedy Central]], [[Disney|Disney Italy]], [[Office Depot]], [[Penguin Books]] and [[Ariane Sherine]].<ref name="a_sherine" /><ref name="bluebio">{{cite web |url=http://www222.pair.com/sjohn/blueroom/bio.htm |title=S. John Ross: a brief bio |accessdate=February 11, 2014 |publisher=Cumberland Games & Diversions}}</ref>
In [[Discordianism]], he wrote ''Novus Ordo Discordia, the Gospel of St. Pesher the Gardener,'' which was included in [[List of Discordian works#Apocrypha Discordia|''Apocrypha Discordia'']],<ref name="apocrypha">{{cite web |url=http://appendix.23ae.com/apocrypha/ |title=Apocrypha Discordia |accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref> and the "foreplay" or foreword for [[List of Discordian works#Ek-sen-trik-kuh Discordia: The Tales of Shamlicht|''Ek-sen-trik-kuh Discordia: The Tales of Shamlicht'']].,<ref name="ek-sen-trik-kuh">{{cite book |last=Loveshade |first=Reverend |title=Ek-sen-trik-kuh Discordia: The Tales of Shamlicht |year=2012 |publisher=Anaphora Literary Press |isbn=978-1937536183}}</ref> both under the name Patriarch Wilhelm Leonardo Pesher-Principle.<ref name="apocrypha" /><ref name="ek-sen-trik-kuh" />
He was nominated for an [[Origins Award]] for a short stint as editor of [[Pyramid (magazine)|''Pyramid'' magazine]],<ref name="sjg_awards">{{cite web |url=http://www.sjgames.com/general/awards.html |title=Awards for Steve Jackson Games |publisher=Steve Jackson Games |accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> and was named to the Order of the Pineapple along with author Adam Gorightly in 2013.<ref name="pineapple">{{cite web |url=http://op.loveshade.org/2010s/2013/index.html |title=Order of the Pineapple 2013 |publisher=Order of the Pineapple |accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref> ''Risus 1.5'' was named Best Free RPG at [[RPGnet]] in 2001<ref name="rpgnet_risus">{{cite web |url=http://www.rpg.net/news+reviews/columns/awards05dec01.html |title=RPGnet 2001 Award Results |publisher=[[RPGnet]] |accessdate=2007-09-30}}</ref> and he contributed to ''[[Pulp Hero]]'' which received a Silver [[ENnies|ENnie]] for Best Writing in 2006.<ref name="ross_pp" />
Ross has been a named guest at several conventions including Technicon in 1995, 1997, and 1998; [[A-Kon]] in 2004<ref name="AC-2004">{{cite web |url=http://www.animecons.com/events/info.shtml/6 |title=Information on A-Kon 2004: Guests |publisher=AnimeCons.com |accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> and 2009;<ref name="A-Kon 2009 Guests">{{cite web |url=http://animecons.com/events/info.shtml/1715 |title=Information on A-Kon 2009: Guests |publisher=AnimeCons.com |accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> and [[Starland|Starland Gamefest]] in 2013. Ross was a special guest at GameFest held in May 2014.<ref name="starland" />
==Personal life== S. John Ross was born as Samuel John Ross Jr., in Cumberland, Maryland on July 15, 1971. He is the son of Sam and Donna Ross. While he lived in various parts of the United States and in Japan, as of early 2014 he lived in Denver, Colorado, with his wife Sandra Ross.<ref name="bluebio" />
==Works== S. John Ross wrote these works:<ref name = "ross_rpgnet">{{cite web |url=http://index.rpg.net/display-search.phtml?key=contributor&value=S.+John+Ross |title=Index contributor Search: S. John Ross |publisher=rpg.net |accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref>
*''GURPS Russia'' and ''GURPS Warehouse 23'' for Steve Jackson Games (also, co-authored ''[[GURPS Grimoire]]'' and ''[[GURPS Black Ops]]'') *''Among the Clans: The Andorians'' and the ''[[Star Trek role-playing game (Last Unicorn)|Star Trek]] Narrator's Toolkit'' for Last Unicorn Games *''[[Uresia: Grave of Heaven]]'' for Guardians of Order *''[[Encounter Critical]]'', originally published as hoax purportedly designed in the 70s. *''[[Risus]]: The Anything RPG'' and ''Points in Space'' for Cumberland Games & Diversions *The ''[[Pokethulhu]] Adventure Game'' for [[Squishy Brain Games]] *''Treasures of a Slaver's Kingdom'' which won the [[XYZZY Award]] 2007 for the best NPC<ref>[http://ifdb.tads.org/viewgame?id=8upuvdnsk4sho6ac Treasures of a Slaver's Kingdom] on ifdb.tads.org</ref> *[http://www222.pair.com/sjohn/blueroom/plots.htm “The Big List of RPG Plots”]
He was editor and developer of ''The Silicon Valley Tarot'', and the 2nd Edition of ''[[Murphy's Rules]]''.
Ross is the owner and creator of Cumberland Games and Diversions, a web-based electronic publishing company specializing in game-related documents and [[TrueType]] fonts.

'''Samir Feriani''' is a Tunisian official (sources variously described him as a police officer<ref name="MacKinnon2012">{{cite book|author=Rebecca MacKinnon|title=Consent of the Networked: The Worldwide Struggle For Internet Freedom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A1Ll03dPL1cC&pg=PA221|accessdate=13 April 2012|date=31 January 2012|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0-465-02442-1|pages=221–222}}</ref><ref name=hrw>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2011/06/09/tunisia-free-would-be-whistle-blower-policeman |title=Tunisia: Free Would-Be Whistle-Blower Policeman | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date=2011-06-09 |accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref> or a senior [[Ministry of the Interior (Tunisia)|Interior Ministry]] employee<ref name=humnew>{{cite web|author=Laura Vidal, Venezuela |url=http://globalvoices.org/2011/06/05/tunisia-an-official-arrested-for-criticizing-the-interior-ministry/ |title=Tunisia: Official Arrested for Criticizing Interior Ministry|publisher=Globalvoices.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref>). A [[whistleblower]], he was arrested in May 2011 and came to be known as the "first 'Prisoner of Conscience' in the post revolutionary Tunisia".<ref name=humnew2/> He was released in September 2011, and acquitted of most charges in March 2012.
==Arrest, trial and release== On May 29, 2011 Feriani was arrested in [[Tunis]],<ref name=humnew/> for allegedly "harming the external security of the state", "releasing and distributing information likely to harm public order", and "accusing, without proof, a public agent of violating law".<ref name="MacKinnon2012"/> Before his arrest Feriani sent two letters to Tunisia's internal minister, [[Habib Essid]], in which he named several senior officials, whom he alleged had committed human rights abuses during the [[Tunisian revolution]], and had since then been destroying the evidence.<ref name="MacKinnon2012"/><ref name=hrw/><ref name=humnew/> His accusations were reported in two independent Tunisian newspapers, [[El Khabir]] and [[l'Audace]], days before his arrest.<ref name=hrw/>
In response to his arrest, Tunisian activists organized a series of protests, many of them online (using [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]]).<ref name="MacKinnon2012"/><ref name=humnew/> Feriani's arrest was condemned by the [[Human Rights Watch]].<ref name="MacKinnon2012"/><ref name=hrw/>
On September 22, Feriani was released by a military court.<ref name=humnew2>{{cite web|author=Mark L Goldberg, USA |url=http://globalvoices.org/2011/09/24/tunisia-whistleblower-samir-feriani-set-free/ |title=Tunisia: Whistleblower Samir Feriani Set Free|publisher=Globalvoices.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref> In March 2012 he was acquitted of major charges, but fined for "accusing a public employee of violating law without proof".<ref name=aaf>{{cite web|last=Ghribi |first=Asma |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201203271129.html |title=Tunisia: Whistleblower Samir Feriani Acquitted of Major Charges |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2012-03-27 |accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref> Feriani was satisfied with the outcome, expressing his hopes that it will mark the start of a deeper investigation into the Ministry of Interior's corruption, and that he will be reappointed to his position with the Ministry.<ref name=aaf/>
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=33em}}

{{About||the biologist|Sean B. Carroll}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Sean M. Carroll |image = Sean Carroll 2017.jpg |image_size = |caption = Sean Carroll in 2017 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|10|05}} |birth_place = [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]]. U.S. |citizenship = United States |nationality = American |fields = [[Physics]], [[cosmology]], [[astrophysics]], [[general relativity]] |workplaces = [[California Institute of Technology]] |alma_mater = {{unbulleted list|[[Villanova University]] (BS)|[[Harvard University]] (PhD)}} |thesis_title = Cosmological Consequences of Topological and Geometric Phenomena in Field Theories |thesis_url = https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&q=%22Cosmological+Consequences+of+Topological+and+Geometric+Phenomena+in+Field+Theories%22&as_sdt=80000&as_ylo=&as_vis=0 |thesis_year = 1993 |doctoral_advisor = [[George B. Field]] |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = [[Dark electromagnetism]]
[[Poetic naturalism]] |influences = [[Albert Einstein]], [[Ludwig Boltzmann]], [[Richard Feynman]] |influenced = |awards = [[Andrew Gemant Award]] (2014) |spouse = [[Jennifer Ouellette]] |signature = |website = {{URL|preposterousuniverse.com/}} | module = {{Listen | filename = Sean Carroll Voice Intro.ogg | title = Sean Carroll Voice | type = speech | description = recorded in 2017 }} }} '''Sean Michael Carroll''' (born October 5, 1966) is a [[physical cosmology|cosmologist]] and physics professor specializing in [[dark energy]] and [[general relativity]]. He is a research professor in the Department of Physics at the [[California Institute of Technology]].{{cite web|url=https://burkeinstitute.caltech.edu/people/faculty |title=Caltech Walter Burke Institute for Theoretical Physics Faculty Page}} He has been a contributor to the physics blog [[Cosmic Variance (blog)|Cosmic Variance]], and has published in scientific journals such as [[Nature (journal)|''Nature'']] as well as other publications, including ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[Sky & Telescope]]'', and ''[[New Scientist]]''. He has appeared on the History Channel's [[The Universe (TV series)|''The Universe'']], Science Channel's [[Through the Wormhole|''Through the Wormhole with Morgan Freeman'']], ''[[Closer to Truth]]'' (broadcast on [[PBS]]),{{cite web|url=https://www.closertotruth.com/contributor/sean-carroll/profile|title=Sean Carroll - Closer to Truth|website=www.closertotruth.com}} and Comedy Central's ''[[The Colbert Report]]''. Carroll is the author of ''Spacetime And Geometry'', a graduate-level textbook in general relativity, and has also recorded lectures for [[the Teaching Company|The Great Courses]] on cosmology, the physics of time, and the Higgs boson.{{cite web|url=http://www.thegreatcourses.com/tgc/professors/professor_detail.aspx?pid=339|title=Professor Bio Page|publisher=}} He is also the author of three popular books: one on the [[arrow of time]] entitled ''From Eternity to Here'', one on the [[Higgs boson]] entitled ''The Particle at the End of the Universe'', and one on science and philosophy entitled ''The Big Picture: On the Origins of Life, Meaning, and the Universe Itself''. He began a podcast in 2018 called ''Mindscape,'' in which he interviews other experts and intellectuals on a variety of science-related topics.{{cite web|url=https://www.preposterousuniverse.com/podcast/ |title=Mindscape podcast}} == Career == Carroll received his PhD in [[astronomy]] and [[astrophysics]] in 1993 from [[Harvard University]], where his advisor was [[George B. Field]]. His [[dissertation]]'s title is "Cosmological Consequences of Topological and Geometric Phenomena in Field Theories". He worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] and [[Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics]] at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]],{{cite web|url=https://www.preposterousuniverse.com/cv/ |title=Sean M. Carroll CV |date= |accessdate=2017-06-27}} and as an assistant professor at the [[University of Chicago]] until 2006 when he was denied tenure.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/cosmicvariance/2011/03/30/how-to-get-tenure-at-a-major-research-university |title=How To Get Tenure at a Major Research University | Cosmic Variance | Discover Magazine |publisher=Blogs.discovermagazine.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-14}} He is now a research professor at [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]]. His most-cited work, "Is Cosmic Speed-Up Due To New Gravitational Physics?" was written with Vikram Duvvuri, [[Mark Trodden]], and [[Michael Turner (cosmologist)|Michael Turner]]. With over 1,900 citations, it helped pioneer the study of [[f(R) gravity]] in cosmology.[http://inspirehep.net/record/621682/citations inSPIRE High-Energy Physics Database] In 2010, Carroll was elected as a fellow of the [[American Physical Society]], for "contributions to a wide variety of subjects in [[cosmology]], [[Theory of Relativity|relativity]], and [[quantum field theory]], especially ideas for [[Accelerating expansion of the universe|cosmic acceleration]], as well as contributions to undergraduate, graduate, and public science education".{{cite web|url=http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/fellowships/archive-all.cfm?initial=&year=2010&unit_id=DPF&institution=California%20Institute%20of%20Technology|title=APS Fellow Archive|publisher=}} In 2014 he was awarded the [[Andrew Gemant Award]], a prize given by the [[American Institute of Physics]] for "significant contributions to the cultural, artistic or humanistic dimension of physics."{{cite web|url=http://www.aip.org/news/2014/outspoken-caltech-scientist-wins-2014-gemant-award |title="Outspoken" Caltech Scientist Wins 2014 Gemant Award}} In 2015 he was awarded a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]].{{cite web|url=https://www.caltech.edu/news/sean-carroll-awarded-guggenheim-fellowship-46621 |title=Sean Carroll Awarded Guggenheim Fellowship}} == Personal life == Carroll is married to [[Jennifer Ouellette]], a [[science writer]] and the former director of the [[Science & Entertainment Exchange]].Claudia Dreifus, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/20/science/20conv.html?_r=1 "Sean Carroll Talks School Science and Time Travel"], The New York Times, April 19, 2010 == Research == Carroll has worked on a number of areas of theoretical cosmology, field theory and gravitation theory. His research papers include models of, and experimental constraints on, violations of [[Lorentz covariance|Lorentz invariance]]; the appearance of [[closed timelike curve]]s in general relativity; varieties of [[topological defect]]s in field theory; and cosmological dynamics of [[Kaluza–Klein theory|extra spacetime dimensions]]. In recent years he has written extensively on models of [[dark energy]] and its interactions with ordinary matter and [[dark matter]], as well as modifications of [[general relativity]] in cosmology. Carroll has also worked on the [[arrow of time]] problem. He and Jennifer Chen posit that the [[Big Bang]] is not a unique occurrence as a result of all of the matter and energy in the universe originating in a singularity at the beginning of time, but rather one of many [[cosmic inflation]] events resulting from [[quantum fluctuation]]s of [[vacuum energy]] in a cold [[de Sitter space]]. They claim that the universe is infinitely old, but never reaches [[thermodynamic equilibrium]] as entropy increases continuously without limit due to the decreasing matter and energy density attributable to recurrent cosmic inflation. They assert that the universe is "statistically time-symmetric" insofar as it contains equal progressions of time "both forward and backward".Sean M. Carroll, Jennifer Chen, [https://arxiv.org/abs/hep-th/0410270 "Spontaneous Inflation and the Origin of the Arrow of Time"]Adam Frank, [http://discovermagazine.com/2008/apr/25-3-theories-that-might-blow-up-the-big-bang/article_view?b_start:int=1&-C= "3 Theories That Might Blow Up the Big Bang"], Discover, April 2008, pp. 57–58{{Cite news |first=Harold |last=Henderson |url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/pdf/050812/050812_scientists.pdf |title=The Cosmic Jiggle |publisher=[[Chicago Reader]] |date=August 12, 2005 |page=14}} Some of his work has been on violations of fundamental symmetries, the physics of dark energy, modifications of general relativity, and the arrow of time. Recently he started focusing on issues at the foundations of cosmology, statistical mechanics, quantum mechanics, and complexity. [[File:Sean Carroll on Computer.jpg|220px|right|thumb]] == Views on religion == Carroll, while raised as an [[Episcopalian]],Carroll, Sean [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bXE_YJzpw-o&feature=youtu.be&t=452]. Saturday 28th October 2017 — 02:30 pm. Retrieved February 21, 2018. is an [[Atheism|atheist]], or as he calls it, a "poetic naturalist". He turned down an invitation to speak at a conference sponsored by the [[John Templeton Foundation]], because he did not want to appear to be supporting a reconciliation between science and religion;Carroll, Sean [http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2013/05/i_won_t_take_money_from_templeton_science_and_religion_can_t_be_reconciled.html "Science and Religion Can’t Be Reconciled. Why I won’t take money from the Templeton Foundation."] Slate. May 9, 2013. Retrieved May 6, 2015. however he later took part in a discussion with Buddhist scholar [[B. Alan Wallace]] organized by an institution sponsored by the same foundation.http://ice.dartmouth.edu/blog/sean-carroll-and-alan-wallace-on-the-nature-of-reality Sean Carroll and Alan Wallace on The Nature of Reality In 2004, he and [[Shadi Bartsch]] taught an undergraduate course title at the University of Chicago on the history of atheism. In 2012 he organized the workshop "Moving Naturalism Forward", which brought together scientists and philosophers to discuss issues associated with a [[Metaphysical naturalism|naturalistic]] worldview. His article "Does the Universe Need God?" in ''[[The Blackwell Companion to Science and Christianity]]'' develops the claim that science no longer needs to posit a divine being to explain the existence of the universe. The article generated significant attention when it was discussed on ''[[The Huffington Post]]''.Walchover, Natalie. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/18/science-god-biology-astronomy-physics-deity_n_1894010.html "Science & God: Will Biology, Astronomy, Physics Rule out Existence of Deity?"]. Huffington Post. Retrieved 2012-09-19. His 2016 book ''[[The Big Picture: On the Origins of Life, Meaning and the Universe Itself]] ''develops the philosophy of [[poetic naturalism]]. Carroll occasionally takes part in formal debates or discussions with theists. In 2012, he teamed up with [[Michael Shermer]] to debate with Ian Hutchinson of MIT and author [[Dinesh D'Souza]] at Caltech in an event titled "The Great Debate: Has Science Refuted Religion?"Carroll, Sean M. [http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/cosmicvariance/2012/03/25/sciencereligion-debate-live-streaming-today/#.VIaF1GfZcS8 "Science/Religion Debate Live-Streaming Today : Cosmic Variance."] Cosmic Variance. N.p., March 25, 2012. In 2014, Carroll debated with philosopher and Christian apologist [[William Lane Craig]] as part of the Greer-Heard Forum in New Orleans. The topic of debate was "The Existence of God in Light of Contemporary Cosmology." Carroll received an "Emperor Has No Clothes" award at the [[Freedom From Religion Foundation]] Annual National Convention in October 2014.{{cite web|url=http://ffrf.org/outreach/convention/2014-convention|title=2014 National Convention - Los Angeles - Freedom From Religion Foundation|date=June 26, 2014|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626035855/http://ffrf.org/outreach/convention/2014-convention|archivedate=June 26, 2014|df=mdy-all}} == Publications == * {{Cite book |last=Carroll |first=Sean |title=Spacetime and Geometry: An Introduction to General Relativity |date=2003 |isbn=0-8053-8732-3}} * {{Cite book |last=Carroll |first=Sean |title=From Eternity To Here: The Quest for the Ultimate Theory of Time |date=2010 |isbn=0-525-95133-4}} It tackles a fundamental open principle in physics: the [[arrow of time]]. * {{Cite book |last=Carroll |first=Sean |title=The Particle at the End of the Universe: How the Hunt for the Higgs Boson Leads Us to the Edge of a New World |date=2012 |isbn=0-525-95359-0}} It describes the hunt for and discovery of the Higgs boson at the [[Large Hadron Collider]] at [[CERN]] and was the 2013 winner of the Royal Society Winton Prize for Science Books.{{cite web|title=Royal Society Winton Prize for Science Books|url=http://royalsociety.org/awards/science-books/|publisher=Royal Society|accessdate=November 26, 2013}} * {{Cite book |last=Carroll |first=Sean |title=The Big Picture: On the Origins of Life, Meaning, and the Universe Itself |date=2016 |isbn=0-5259-5482-1}}, where Carroll introduces the concept of [[poetic naturalism]]. * [http://inspirehep.net/search?ln=en&p=a+carroll%2C+s+m&of=hb&action_search=Search&sf=earliestdate&so=d Research publication list], from the [[INSPIRE-HEP]] digital library. == References == [http://www.thegreatcourses.com/courses/dark-matter-dark-energy-the-dark-side-of-the-universe.html Dark Matter, Dark Energy: The Dark Side of the Universe], lectures at [[The Teaching Company]]. * Video of Sean Carroll's panel discussion, "Quantum to Cosmos," answering the biggest questions in physics today, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QePNKlCpgl4 Part 1] at [[Perimeter Institute]]'s Quantum to Comos (Q2C) festival * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QonrrIjyMCg Video of Sean Carroll's lecture "The Origin of the Universe and the Arrow of Time"], Q2C, October 17, 2009 * [http://www.cc.com/video-clips/ski7ov/the-colbert-report-sean-carroll Interview] on [[The Colbert Report]] * {{cite web|last=Carroll|first=Sean|title=Higgs Boson with Sean Carroll|url=http://www.sixtysymbols.com/videos/higgs_sean.htm|work=Sixty Symbols|publisher=[[Brady Haran]] for the [[University of Nottingham]]}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carroll, Sean M.}} {{About|the boxer|other persons of the same name|Tom Morrison (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox boxer | name = Tommy Morrison | realname = Tommy David Morrison | image = Tommy Morrison cropped.jpg | caption = Morrison in 2010 | nickname = The Duke | weight = [[Heavyweight]] | height = 6 ft 2 in | reach = 76 in | birth_date = {{birth date|1969|1|2}} | birth_place = [[Gravette, Arkansas]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2013|9|1|1969|1|2}} | death_place = [[Omaha, Nebraska]], U.S. | style = [[Orthodox stance|Orthodox]] | total = 52 | wins = 48 | KO = 42 | losses = 3 | draws = 1 }}
'''Tommy David Morrison''' (January 2, 1969 – September 1, 2013) was an American [[professional boxer]] who competed from 1988 to 1996, and held the [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] [[heavyweight]] title in 1993. He retired from boxing in 1996 when he tested positive for [[HIV]], but returned for two more fights in 2007 and 2008. Morrison is also known for his acting role when he starred alongside [[Sylvester Stallone]] in the 1990 film ''[[Rocky V]]''.
Morrison had previously attempted a comeback to boxing in 2006, claiming he had tested negative for HIV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2850518 |title=Morrison's blood tests negative for second time – boxing |publisher=ESPN |date=2007-04-27 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> In August 2013, Morrison's mother announced that her son was in the final stages of [[AIDS]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1136426/tommy-morrison-ex-world-champion-dies-at-44 |title=Tommy Morrison: Ex-World Champion Dies At 44 |publisher=Sky News |date=3 September 2013 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> and he died on September 1, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/medical_examiner/2013/10/tommy_morrison_aids_death_hiv_denialism_victims_in_south_africa_and_the.html|title=Deadly Disbelief: The myth that HIV does not cause AIDS seems to have claimed another victim|publisher=Slate.com|accessdate=2014-02-20}}</ref>
==Early life and amateur career== Morrison was born in [[Gravette, Arkansas]]. His mother, Diana, was of Native American descent, while his father's side was of majority [[Scottish people|Scottish]] descent.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tommy Morrison obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2013/sep/11/tommy-morrison|accessdate=4 January 2015|publisher=The Guardian|date=11 September 2013}}</ref> Morrison was raised in [[Delaware County, Oklahoma]], spending most of his teenage years in [[Jay, Oklahoma|Jay]].<ref>[http://thecruelestsport.com/2013/09/03/soon-youll-see-stars-fevered-tommy-morrison-1969-2013/] Retrieved 2014-12-02.</ref> Morrison's nickname, "The Duke", is based on the claim that he was related to Hollywood star [[John Wayne]] (né Marion Morrison).<ref name="Doom">{{cite news|title=Doom Comes Whipping Down Plain|publisher=[[New York Daily News]]|date=February 14, 1996|first= Vic|last=Ziegel|authorlink=Vic Ziegel }}</ref> Morrison's older brother Tim Jr boxed and his father urged him to take up the sport at the age of ten. At the age of 13, Morrison claimed he used a fake ID and entered fifteen "toughman" contests (the minimum age for contestants was 21). He later told ''The [[New York Times]]'' that he lost only one of these matches.<ref name=NYTNotebook>{{cite news|title=Cayton's Corner Attracts Rising Heavyweight Puncher|publisher=New York Times|date=May 3, 1989|first=Phil|last=Berger}}</ref>
In 1988, Morrison won the Regional Heavyweight Title – Kansas City Golden Gloves from Donald Ellis and advanced to the National Golden Gloves in [[Omaha, Nebraska]], where he lost a split decision to Derek Isaman. Two weeks later, Morrison took part in the Western Olympic trials in [[Houston, Texas]] winning the Heavyweight Title and garnering the "Most Outstanding Fighter" of the tournament. Two weeks after that at the Olympic Trials in [[Concord, California]], Morrison lost a split decision to [[Ray Mercer]], who later won the gold medal at the [[Seoul Olympics]].<ref name=si/> His combined professional and amateur record is 343–24–1, with 315 wins by knockout.
==Professional career== {{further|Ray Mercer vs. Tommy Morrison|George Foreman vs. Tommy Morrison|Tommy Morrison vs. Michael Bentt|Lennox Lewis vs. Tommy Morrison}} Morrison started his professional boxing career on November 10, 1988,<ref name=si>{{cite web|author=Pat Putnam|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1138531/index.htm|title=Tommy Morrison – 06.21.93|publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com|date=1993-06-21|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref> with a first-round knockout of William Muhammad in New York City. Three weeks later, he scored another first-round knockout. In 1989, Morrison had 19 wins and no losses, 15 by [[knockout]]. In 1989, actor [[Sylvester Stallone]] observed one of Morrison's bouts. Stallone arranged a script reading and cast Morrison in the movie ''[[Rocky V]]'' as [[Tommy Gunn (character)|Tommy "The Machine" Gunn]],<ref>{{cite news|title= Rocky V' Has Drama Coaches in Its Corner : Film: Acting teachers are traditionally barred from movie sets. But for Stallone's latest boxing epic, a Studio City couple was allowed to show newcomer Tommy Morrison the ropes, scene by scene and blow by blow.|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=November 16, 1990|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-11-16/entertainment/ca-4790_1_tommy-morrison|accessdate=2010-10-29|first=Gary|last=Klein}}</ref> a young and talented protege of the retired [[Rocky Balboa]]. He took a six-month break from boxing to work on the movie in 1990.<ref name=si/>
In 1991, Morrison won fights against opponents [[James Tillis]] and former world champion [[Pinklon Thomas]]. He was given an opportunity to face fellow undefeated fighter [[Ray Mercer]], the WBO title holder in a [[Pay Per View]] card held on October 18, 1991. Morrison suffered the first loss of his career, losing by 5th-round knockout.<ref name=si/>
He had six wins in 1992, including fights with [[Art Tucker]] and [[Joe Hipp]], who later became the first [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] to challenge for the world heavyweight title. In the Hipp fight, held June 19, 1992, Morrison was suffering from what was later discovered to be a broken hand and broken jaw, but rallied to score a knockout in the ninth round. After two wins in 1993, including one over two-time world title challenger [[Carl Williams (boxer)|Carl "The Truth" Williams]], Morrison found himself fighting for the [[WBO]] title again, against heavyweight boxing legend [[George Foreman]], who was himself making a comeback.
Morrison chose to avoid brawling with Foreman and spent the fight boxing from long range. He was able to hit and move effectively in this manner, and after a closely contested bout he won a unanimous 12-round decision and the [[WBO]] title.<ref>{{cite news|author=TOM FRIEND|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/08/sports/boxing-morrison-defeats-foreman-by-decision.html?src=pm|title=BOXING; Morrison Defeats Foreman By Decision|publisher=Nytimes.com|date=1993-06-08|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref>
Morrison's first title defense was scheduled against [[Mike Williams (boxer)|Mike Williams]], but when Williams withdrew on the night of the fight, Tim Tomashek stood in as a replacement. Although Tomashek had been prepared to fight as a backup plan, some news reports created the impression that he had just been pulled out of the crowd.<ref>[http://www.doghouseboxing.com/Newman/Newman020404.htm Doghouse Boxing (2004-02-04)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091231045549/http://doghouseboxing.com/Newman/Newman020404.htm |date=2009-12-31 }}; retrieved December 3, 2011.</ref> The WBO later rescinded their sanctioning of this fight due to Tomashek's lack of experience. Almost immediately, talks of a fight with [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] champion [[Lennox Lewis]] began, but were halted when virtually unknown [[Michael Bentt]] upset Morrison in his next bout. Bentt knocked Morrison down three times, and the fight was stopped in the first round in front of a live [[HBO Boxing]] audience.<ref>{{cite news|author=Staff|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/30/sports/boxing-morrison-loses-fight-7.5-million.html?src=pm|title=BOXING; Morrison Loses Fight, $7.5 Million|publisher=Nytimes.com|date=1993-10-30|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref> Morrison recovered by winning three bouts in a row in 1994, but his last fight of the year, against [[Ross Puritty]], ended with a draw.<ref>{{cite news|author=GERALD ESKENAZI|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/29/sports/boxing-morrison-and-mercer-it-s-2-fights-2-draws.html|title=BOXING;Morrison and Mercer: It's 2 Fights, 2 Draws|publisher=Nytimes.com|date=1994-07-29|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref>
Morrison won three fights in 1995 before meeting former #1 contender [[Donovan Ruddock|Razor Ruddock]]. Ruddock dropped Morrison to his knees in the first round, but Morrison recovered to force a standing count in round two and compete on even terms for five rounds. In the sixth round, Ruddock hurt Morrison with a quick combination, but just as it seemed Morrison was in trouble, he countered with a tremendous hook that put Ruddock on the canvas. Ruddock regained his feet, but Morrison drove him to the ropes and showered him with an extended flurry of blows. Just as the bell was about to sound, the referee stepped in and declared Morrison the winner by TKO.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PBPB&p_theme=pbpb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF3F2C8185DDC1&p_field_direct-0=d|title=MORRISON'S WIN OVER RUDDOCK A CAREER BOOST|work=Palm Beach Post|date=June 12, 1995|page=2C|via=Nl.newsbank.com|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref>
The much-anticipated fight with Lewis, who had also lost his world championship, finally took place following the Ruddock match. Morrison was knocked out in the sixth round.<ref>{{cite news|author=CLIFTON BROWN|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/sports/boxing-lewis-back-in-picture-with-morrison-tko.html?src=pm|title=BOXING;Lewis Back in Picture With Morrison T.K.O.|publisher=Nytimes.com|date=1995-10-08|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref>
==Personal life== At one point in 1996 Morrison was married to two women at the same time, Dawn Freeman and Dawn Gilbert. Morrison had two children by age 19.<ref>''ESPN'', [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/magazine/archives/news/story?page=magazine-20030331-article28 That Was Then], July 10, 2012</ref> Tommy and Trisha Morrison were married in 2011. They had no children. He has two sons who are also professional boxers, Trey Lippe Morrison and James McKenzie Morrison.<ref>http://www.fighthype.com/news/article30425.html</ref><ref>http://www.espn.com/boxing/story/_/id/17548218/heavyweight-prospect-trey-lippe-morrison-making-tv-debut-month</ref>
===Health=== In 1996, Morrison was scheduled to fight against Arthur Weathers. The [[Nevada Athletic Commission]] determined that Morrison had tested positive for [[HIV]].<ref name=lat021696>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-02-16/sports/sp-36635_1_tommy-morrison|title=A New Fight: After Second HIV Test Is Positive, Reflective Morrison Takes Blame|work=The Los Angeles Times|first=Steve|last=Springer|date=February 16, 1996|accessdate=June 9, 2012}}</ref> The Commission suspended Morrison from boxing in Nevada.<ref name=nyt092096>{{cite news|title=Morrison Plans One More Fight Despite His H.I.V. Diagnosis|work=The New York Times|first=Selena|last=Roberts|date=September 20, 1996}}</ref> Several days later, Morrison's physician administered a test, which was also positive.<ref name=lat021696/> At a news conference on February 15, 1996, Morrison said he had contracted HIV because of a "permissive, fast and reckless lifestyle".<ref name=lat021696/> Morrison stated that he would "absolutely" never fight again.<ref name=nyt092096/>
At another news conference on September 19, 1996, in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], Morrison announced he wished to fight "one last time" when he could find an opponent, the proceeds of which would benefit his KnockOut AIDS Foundation.<ref name=nyt092096/> A spokesman for the Oklahoma Professional Boxing Advisory Board said Morrison would probably not be permitted to fight in [[Oklahoma]] because of his Nevada suspension.<ref name=ts092096>{{cite news |title=Morrison wants final fight to help children with AIDS|work=The Toronto Star|date=September 20, 1996}}</ref> To treat his infection, Morrison said he took [[antiretroviral]] medication, which reduced his [[viral load]] to almost undetectable levels.<ref name=nydn110701>{{cite news|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2001-11-07/sports/18356893_1_hiv-boxer-tommy-morrison-wbo-heavyweight-title|title=For Tommy, Life Has Been Rocky Stands Tall After Virus Scores Tko|work=The New York Daily News|first=Tim|last=Smith|date=November 7, 2001|accessdate=June 9, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028134534/http://articles.nydailynews.com/2001-11-07/sports/18356893_1_hiv-boxer-tommy-morrison-wbo-heavyweight-title|archivedate=October 28, 2012|df=}}</ref>
In 2006, Morrison said his HIV tests had been [[false positive]]s.<ref name=ESPNJune2007>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2899260|title=Morrison faces new allegations from former associate|work=ESPN Boxing|date=June 10, 2007|accessdate=June 9, 2012}}</ref> The Nevada commission's medical advisory board reviewed Morrison's 1996 test results and concluded they were "ironclad and unequivocal."<ref name="HIVTest2007">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/boxing/2007-06-21-Morrison_N.htm|title=Morrison fights claims of recent positive HIV test|work=USA Today|date=June 22, 2007|first=Chuck|last=Johnson|accessdate=June 9, 2012}}</ref> Morrison said he tried to get a copy of the original test result but was unable to do so, adding: "I don't think it ever existed." The Commission said Morrison could "contact the laboratory, and they would immediately release the results to him."<ref name="HIVTest2007"/>
Morrison tested negative for HIV four times in January 2007.<ref name=boxing011507>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/index.php?m=show&id=6947|title=Morrison tests negative for HIV, fight delayed|work=BoxingScene|date=January 15, 2007|first=Mark|last=Vester|accessdate=June 9, 2012}}</ref> That year, he began fighting again.<ref name=guardian022307>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/sport/2007/02/23/the_great_white_hope_climbs_ba.html|title=The Great White Hope climbs back between the ropes|publisher=The Guardian|date=February 23, 2007|first=Oliver|last=Irish|accessdate=2009-07-01|location=London}}</ref><ref name=ESPN2772386>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2772386|title=Morrison medically cleared to fight Thursday|work=ESPN Boxing|first=Dan|last=Rafael|date=February 20, 2007|accessdate=June 9, 2012}}</ref><ref name=ESPN2775863>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2775863|title=Morrison begins comeback bid with KO|work=ESPN Boxing |first=Dan|last=Rafael|date=February 23, 2007|accessdate=June 9, 2012}}</ref> After passing medical tests in [[Texas]], [[West Virginia]] licensed Morrison to fight in that state. In February 2007 he fought and beat John Castle.<ref name=guardian022307/><ref name=ESPN2772386/> In June, Morrison's former agent, Randy Lang, alleged that Morrison had tested positive in January and that the boxer had tampered with blood samples. Morrison responded that he had fired Lang when he discovered that Lang was not a lawyer.<ref name=ESPN>{{cite web|last=Merrill|first=Elizabeth|title=Morrison faces new allegations from former associate|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2899260|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=January 27, 2014}}</ref>
On July 22, 2007, the ''New York Times'' reported that Morrison took two HIV tests in 2007 and a third specifically for the ''Times''.<ref name=nyt072207>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/22/sports/othersports/22boxing.html?pagewanted=all|title=Morrison Says Error in H.I.V. Test Hurt Career|publisher=New York Times|date=July 22, 2007|accessdate=June 9, 2012|first1=John|last1=Eligon|first2=Duff|last2=Wilson}}</ref> HIV experts reviewed the three tests and concluded that the 1996 result had been a false positive. But ringside doctors, including Nevada's chief ringside physician, expressed doubt. They implied that the negative results were not in fact based on Morrison's blood. The experts agreed that no one is ever cured of HIV; if the negative tests from 2007 were performed on Morrison's blood, then he had never been infected with HIV.<ref name=nyt072207/>
The ''[[Kansas City Star]]'' described his early 2009 fight in [[Wyoming]] as a "staged" event and a "fake fight."<ref name=StarFeb2011>{{cite news|title=Morrison insists he can box and doesn't have HIV|work=Kansas City Star|first=Sam|last=Mellinger|date=February 13, 2011}}</ref> In January 2011, the RACJ, the boxing commission for the province of [[Quebec]], required that Morrison take a supervised HIV test in advance of a scheduled 2011 fight. Morrison declined to take the test because he said it would be the same kind of test administered by Nevada in 1996. Instead, Morrison invited the Quebec commission to attend a public test, but the commission did not come. Morrison stated that if Quebec refused to license him, he would "take the dog and pony show somewhere else."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/morrison-says-no-to-testing-72730|title=Morrison says no to testing|work=Fightnews.com|first=Dave|last=Spencer|date=January 19, 2011|accessdate=June 9, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110123070228/http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/morrison-says-no-to-testing-72730|archivedate=January 23, 2011|df=}}</ref>
===Legal issues=== In December 1993, Morrison was charged with assault and public intoxication when he allegedly punched a [[University of Iowa]] student. Morrison said that the student had been staring at him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Morrison KOs student in restaurant |work=Baltimore Sun |agency=Associated Press |date=December 8, 1993}}</ref> Morrison pleaded guilty and paid a $310 fine, but said he was innocent.<ref>{{cite news |title=Morrison pleads guilty to assault |work=Tulsa World |date=January 28, 1994}}</ref> In October 1996, Morrison pleaded guilty to transporting a loaded firearm in [[Jay, Oklahoma]]; he received a 6-month suspended sentence and a $100 fine.<ref>{{cite news |title=More Boxing |work=Orlando Sentinel |date=October 29, 1996}}</ref> In 1997, an Oklahoma jury convicted him of [[DUI]] in an accident that left three people injured; the court ordered Morrison to spend time in treatment.<ref name=cbs021109>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/1999/11/26/sports/main71883.shtml|title=T. Morrison In Trouble Again|work=CBS News|date=February 11, 2009|accessdate=June 10, 2012|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>
In September 1999, an Oklahoma court gave a two-year suspended sentence for a DUI elevated to felony level by his previous DUI conviction. On September 16, 1999, the police stopped Morrison for driving erratically and found drugs and weapons in his car, which resulted in various drugs and firearms charges. While awaiting trial on the September 16 charges, Morrison was again arrested on charges of intoxication and possessing a weapon while a felon in November 1999.<ref name=cbs021109/> On January 14, 2000, Morrison was sentenced to two years in prison on the September 16 charges.<ref>{{cite news|title=Morrison's release delayed because of discipline problem|work=AP Online|first=Melissa|last=Nelson|date=January 19, 2001}}</ref> On April 3, 2002, he was sentenced to another year in prison after violating parole in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], but was given credit for time previously served.<ref>{{cite news|title=Events in Tommy Morrison's boxing career|work=Kansas City Star|date=February 13, 2011}}</ref>
==Death== In August 2013, Elizabeth Merrill of [[ESPN]].com reported that Morrison's mother Diana disclosed that Tommy had "full-blown [[AIDS]]" and was "in his final days." She also stated that Morrison had been bedridden for over a year. The same article also stated that Morrison's wife, Trisha, did not believe Morrison had AIDS.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/9588582/tommy-morrison-latest-big-fight|title=Tommy Morrison's latest big fight|publisher=Espn.go.com|date=2013-08-23|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/9626860/ex-heavyweight-champ-tommy-morrison-dies-44|title=Tommy Morrison dies at 44|publisher=Espn.go.com|date=2008-01-01|accessdate=2013-09-04}}</ref>
On September 1, 2013, Morrison died at the [[Nebraska Medical Center]] in [[Omaha, Nebraska]] at the age of 44.<ref>{{cite news|last=Skretta|first=Dave|title=Ex-heavyweight champion Tommy Morrison dies at 44|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/boxing/2013/09/02/boxer-tommy-morrison-dies-at-44/2755083/|newspaper=USA Today|date=September 2, 2013}}</ref> According to the [[Nebraska Department of Health & Human Services]], Morrison's cause of death was cardiac arrest, resulting from [[multiorgan failure]] due to [[septic shock]] caused by a ''[[Pseudomonas aeruginosa]]'' infection.<ref>{{cite web|title=Morrison death certificate: No Mention Of AIDS|url=http://www.tmz.com/2013/09/05/tommy-morrison-death-certificate-blood-infection-aids-hiv|publisher=TMZ|accessdate=September 6, 2013}}</ref>

In [[Polynesian mythology|mythology]] of [[Mangaia]] and the [[southern Cook Islands]], '''Vatea''' is the father of gods and men. His mother is [[Varima-te-takere]], who lives deep in [[Avaiki]], the underworld. She plucks off a piece from her right side and it becomes Vatea or [[Avatea]].
In Mangaian myth, a beautiful woman visits Vatea in his dreams, and he is certain that she ascends from the [[underworld]] to his side, but when he wakes he can never find her. He strews scraped [[coconut]] about, and, at last, watchers see a slender hand reach for the delicious food. Vatea catches her and discovers that her name is [[Papa (mythology)|Papa]], and marries her. [[Tangaroa]] and [[Rongo]] are their twin sons. Rongo's wife bears a daughter named Tavake. Tavake gives birth to Rangi, Mokoiro, and to Akatauira. Rangi pulls up Mangaia from the underworld, and becomes the first king of the island. His wife's name is Te-po-tatango (Tregear 1891:392).
